PETITION.TITLE: Violent Television Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:
We are concerned about the increase in violent television programmes for children and particularly those programmes promoting violent toys that are available for sale in Australia.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray;

That you support the Broadcasting (Prohibition of Violent Programmes for Children) Act 1988 which has been presented by WA Independent Senator for Nuclear Disarmament, Jo Vallentine. This act aims to prohibit the broadcasting of children's TV programmes that are violent and that promote toys modelled on characters, weapons or other war accessories which are also available for sale in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Giles (from 26 citizens) and Patterson (from 13 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated and Violent Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Parliamentary Joint Select Committee on Video Material has concluded that ``Adverse effects upon people, and especially upon children, of exposure to material containing various degrees of violence, pornography or obscenity have been demonstrated''.
The majority of the Select Committee strongly opposed the proposition for a new NVE (non-violent erotica) category, which would have entrenched X-rated video pornography.
All six State Governments have, through their Attorney-General, expressed unanimous opposition to the circulation of X-rated videos.
We consider the continuing distribution of X-rated videos from the A.C.T. to be reprehensible and to be contrary to the wellbeing of the Australian community in general.
We strongly request urgent Government action to prohibit the distribution of X-rated and excessively violent video material.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Jones (from 601 citizens) and Stone (from 172 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Home Ownership
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:-
Recent huge rises in mortgage interest rates have pushed the cost of buying their own home beyond the reach of most Australian families.

Those Australians already paying off home mortgages are now suffering severely and unfairly through increased mortgage payments or longer repayment times so that many will never pay off their mortgage and go further and further into debt unless interest rates fall substantially.

Now, therefore, your petitioners request that the Senate in Parliament assembled require the Hawke-Keating government to cease its excessive reliance on high interest rates as its major economic policy weapon and instead to use other measures which would allow interest rates to return to levels that do not force most Australian home-seekers out of the housing market-and many Australians out of their homes-so that the traditional right of home ownership is returned to average Australian families.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Queensland: Disaster Relief Funds
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:

We are concerned that the National Party in Queensland is diverting money given by the Federal Government to the Queensland Government to alleviate natural disasters; that it might not be finding its way to its intended targets; and that is being diverted to the coffers of the National Party itself or otherwise to expansion projects promoted by members or supporters of the National Party.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray the Federal Government be asked to legislate for an audit of account from the Queensland Government for every dollar or cent provided by the Federal Government for any type of relief operation in Queensland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, at the conclusion of Question Time, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, came into this chamber and provided a supplementary answer to a question that I had asked without notice on the day before with regard to a meeting in Darwin between the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and members of the Fretilin rebel movement. It was claimed that I had asserted that the Prime Minister, by participating in that function in Darwin, had snubbed Indonesia.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday Senator Evans said that he believed that I was implying that there was some sort of shadowy gathering of insurgents in Australia's far north. This is a misrepresentation of the facts. The function on Saturday night in Darwin was held at the club rooms, as Senator Evans quite correctly said in his answer, of the Lafaek Club in Darwin. This is a Timorese organisation whose membership is broadly based but which also includes members of Fretilin. Senator Evans also said that the invitations had been quite widely extended, both by Senator Collins and by Mr Snowdon, MHR--

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tambling, this is supposed to be a personal explanation.
—Mr President, I would contend that it is a personal explanation in that the fact--
—I think the honourable senator ought to get to that part of it that affects him.

—Senator Evans claimed that I had attempted to imply that this was a meeting only of Fretilin and the Prime Minister. Senator Evans listed a number of other organisations invited to the function. Last night I checked with those organisations and ascertained that whilst some of them did receive an invitation from Mr Snowdon, none of those that I contacted attended. The important point that I wish to make is that Mr Snowdon at no time mentioned the Fretilin function in his newspaper column of 26 March.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I will wait until Senator Tambling resumes his seat.
—You should tell your colleague Senator Cook to do that when he is in that position.

—Those who cannot do, teach. I did not intervene earlier, even when you did, Mr President, because I could see that Senator Tambling was explaining how he was personally misrepresented and that he was laying some general groundwork. But for him to start a series on Mr Snowdon definitely is getting away from a personal explanation. I do not recall Senator Evans mentioning Mr Snowdon yesterday. Senator Tambling is entitled to show where he has been misrepresented. He has adduced some evidence-he thinks, at least-for that. That is fine; but he is now going, as most people do in personal explanations, into a new area.

—Mr President, I wish to speak to the point of order. It is quite clear that Senator Tambling is explaining where he has been misrepresented. Whether he has been misrepresented by Senator Evans, by Mr Snowdon or by an article in a newspaper is not relevant to the issue. He is entitled to explain where he has been misrepresented and why that misrepresentation is not correct. I believe that Senator Tambling is in the process of explaining how Senator Evans misled the Senate in relation to his answer yesterday over the matter that Senator Tambling had questioned him about, and how Mr Snowdon has also in some way or other misrepresented him. I believe that Senator Tambling has not in any way transgressed the rules at this stage.
—There are many points of order on personal explanations. The honourable senator is not allowed to debate or redebate the issue. He must get to the point where he has been personally misrepresented.
—Mr President, very obviously, this is an area of great sensitivity to the Labor Party.
—That is typical.
—Order! The rules are applied equally to every person who seeks to make a personal explanation.

—Mr President, I was in no way taking issue with your ruling on this matter; rather, I was taking issue with the interjections and points raised by those opposite. Senator Evans, of course, sought to broaden, in the supplementary answer that he gave yesterday, the question that I had raised the day before. The issue that I wanted to restate very clearly was that I had ascertained, and had quite rightly said, that the Prime Minister had met with members of the Fretilin movement. In fact, that was correct. At the function hosted by the Labor Party, for which proceeds did go to the Lafaek Club, a submission was made very directly in the form of a letter to the Prime Minister. That was outlined in further detail on a radio program yesterday in Darwin by a Fretilin representative.

SPEECH.PARA: The point that I stress at this time is that the Prime Minister did meet with members of the Fretilin organisation. He did receive submissions. It is very interesting to note that, despite Senator Evans's point that the function on Saturday night in Darwin, was jointly hosted by Mr Snowdon and Senator Collins, Senator Collins had the very good sense to stay at home because of family priorities rather than attend.

Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) agreed to:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of the Bill is to authorise the Treasurer, on behalf of the Commonwealth, to guarantee the repayment of loans and interest on funds raised by Qantas to purchase three Boeing 747-400 aircraft and associated spare parts and equipment.

The Boeing 747-400 is a new series aircraft offering improved operating efficiency and engine technology. A new technology cockpit enables the aircraft potentially to be crewed by two people, and its strategic value lies in the flexibility and competitive advantage inherent in its extra long-range capability.

Qantas needs the flexibility that these aircraft will provide in order to meet the requirements of the rapidly growing inbound tourist market. Inbound tourism, as measured by Short-term Visitor Arrivals, reached almost 2.2 million in the year ending October 1988, an increase of almost 28 per cent over the previous 12 month period. The Bureau of Tourism Research estimates that overseas tourists visiting Australia will reach two and a half million in 1990.
Other carriers serving Australia will also introduce B747-400s in 1989, and Qantas is likely to lose a significant share of the inbound tourism market if it is not able to operate similar aircraft.

Qantas will use the aircraft primarily to provide services between Australia's East Coast and London via Singapore (the Kangaroo Route), as well as additional Sydney/Los Angeles services, two of Australia's major markets. Deliveries of the aircraft are currently scheduled to commence in July.

The three aircraft that the Bill deals with are only the first of twenty that the company plans to acquire over the five years to 1992/93. In view of the magnitude of this program, Qantas's current capital structure is currently being examined by the Government, with the aim of ensuring its adequacy to underpin such a program.

The Bill limits the guarantee of borrowings by Qantas for the three aircraft to $US385m, or its equivalent in foreign currencies, which represent 85 per cent of the total project cost for the three aircraft. The guarantee does not involve the Government in any cash outlay, but does create a contingent liability for the Commonwealth.

While the Board of Qantas has yet to evaluate all the options, Qantas has advised that it wishes to enter again into so-called Japanese `cross-border' leases, to reduce the financing costs of these aircraft. Such arrangements, which were the subject of criticism by the Opposition during the debate on the Qantas loan guarantee legislation last year, allow Qantas to finance new aircraft at a significantly cheaper rate than would otherwise be available.

Such arrangements are common-place within the aviation industry, and I am advised that the National Tax Administration of Japan has published very tight regulatory guidelines, with which all leases of aircraft to foreign airlines must comply.

As regards the Australian tax position, I made it clear during the last debate that the Tax Office ruling, which Opposition members were concerned about, did not apply to this type of arrangements, which are tax neutral from the Australian Government's point of view.

Similarly, confirmation was obtained from the Government that its proposed legislation to overcome `double-dipping' schemes, was to be directed at schemes that operated to the detriment of the Australian revenue . As I have stated before, the Qantas arrangements are not of this nature.

I also indicated in the debate on the previous Qantas loan guarantee legislation that the appropriateness of guarantees for future Qantas aircraft is currently under review as part of the process of implementing the May 1988 reform package for Qantas.
I commend this Bill to the Senate and I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS TARIFF (COAL EXPORT DUTY) AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill proposes amendments to the Customs Tariff (Coal Export Duty) Act 1975 to continue an existing exemption from export duty in respect of certain coal, where that exempt coal is blended with other coal.

By way of background, the Act was introduced in 1975 to impose a revenue duty to channel to the community a proportion of the windfall profits then being made by coal export producers. Since then, our coal exporters have experienced intense com- petition on the international scene for their coal markets, and the Act has been amended on several occasions to introduce exemptions to the Customs duty, in order to maintain a competitive edge for our coal exports.

At present, the only coal which remains dutiable under the Act is high quality coking coal mined from depths no greater than 60 metres in open-cut mines in production before 1 July 1980-but even here there are exemptions to the export duty; in practice, duty is currently paid on production from six mines in Queensland.

Against this background, in 1983 the Government received representation from CSR and Theiss Dampier Mitsui for relief from the export duty on production from the Moura and South Blackwater mines located in the Bowen Basin in Queensland. Both mines must blend significant quantities of higher quality coal from their underground operations with coal from their underground operations with coal from their open-cuts in order to obtain a product of a quality suitable to meet export contract specifications. The addition of higher cost underground product to their open-cut coal increased costs to the point where the imposition of the export duty on the open-cut coal in the exported product was having a significant impact on the rate of return to the producers.

In order to assist the viability of these operations, the Government decided to exempt from duty open-cut production provided it contained a minimum 15 per cent underground coal, and was all produced from the same mine. This was effected by amendments to the Act in 1984. The 1984 amendments however were framed in such a way that Moura and South Blackwater coal blends would be exempt from coal export duty if exported as single blends, but would lose the exemption if they were further blended with coal from other mines before export. It now transpires that such further blending is indeed commercially advantageous and commercially possible, following recent corporate restructuring in the affected mines.
The Government is therefore proposing in clause 3 of the Bill that exempt coal from the mines mentioned will not lose its exempt status by reason of being blended with other coal.

This decision reflects the Government's commitment to the maintenance of underground operations in the Bowen Basin, in order to retain skills which will ultimately be of benefit to the industry as a whole in that region. It also demonstrates the Government's concern to assist employment security in the industry in the present difficult international marketing environment.
Financial Impact Statement

This measure has no direct financial implications, as its sole purpose is to maintain an existing exemption from liability to pay customs duty. There will be no overall coal export duty revenue loss as a result of the proposed change. I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1987[COGNATE BILLS:CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1988]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 15 December 1987, on motion by Senator Tate:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1987

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate now turns to debating cognately three Customs Bills: the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987, the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 and the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1988. The last of those Bills is in effect a formal Bill which deals with many tariff amendments and extends to 488 pages; but in effect, it is a formality and I shall be dealing with it only briefly. Nevertheless, the Government is including that Bill in a cognate debate with the other two Bills, which are of major importance to those people who are involved in the import and export trades of this nation. The Government alleges that it is very keen to assist such people-but it is introducing procedures which are quite draconian.

SPEECH.PARA: Over 15 months ago, in December 1987, this Government, including the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), tried to push through this Parliament the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1987, which totally changed the Customs system of Australia. The coalition parties objected to the Bill being rushed through the Parliament. Industry had not had time to consider these drastic changes to the scheme, and the Parliament had had little time in which to consult industry and little time to give the consideration that these Bills needed. At the time, Senator Button attacked the Opposition. He claimed that we did not understand the issues. He argued strongly against any deferral of the debate. On 15 December 1987, I moved to defer debate on the Bill. The purpose that I put in my motion was: `to allow Customs agents and the industry time to make appropriate representations in relation to the Bill'. I said that it was disgraceful that the Government should wish to deal cognately or in haste with the complex issues involved in the Bill.

At the time, the Government, as I said, complained bitterly about the deferral and, in effect, claimed that it was vital to the whole Customs system and the collection of revenue that the Bill be passed so that the new system could come into operation on 1 January 1988.
Senator Button said:

Any deferral of this Bill for a further three or four months, especially since the Bill includes consequential enforcement and penalty provisions to complement the reforms contained in it, could result in quite considerable Customs duty shortfall.
Senator Button also said:

The current legislation, of course, deals with penalties which are a necessary corollary to taking steps to close loopholes in the legislation . . . The figure estimated for fraud in respect of Customs valuation is about $146m. The Opposition is up to its old tricks again-if the taxman cometh, let us put every obstruction in his way to stop him collecting government revenue if we can find some reason for doing so.

That was back in December 1987. Thanks to the support of the Australian Democrats, the Bill was deferred so that industry could consider it and make its representations. Fifteen months later, not three or four months later, Senator Button brings the legislation back into the chamber. It is clear that Senator Button misled the Senate, the Hawke Government has been grossly negligent in not bringing the Bill back in earlier or there is no purpose in the Bill.

If Senator Button was correct in his statement that deferral of this Bill for even three or four months could result in quite considerable customs duty shortfall, the Government has been grossly negligent in not proceeding with this legislation for another 12 to 14 months. Alternatively, there has not been a quite considerable customs shortfall, in which case Senator Button's statement was misleading and there is no requirement for this legislation. Can Senator Button explain, in the light of his own statements, why without any obstruction from the Opposition parties he and the Government have seen fit to wait nearly 16 months to reintroduce the legislation? Either Senator Button misled the Senate or he and the Government have been grossly negligent in their failure to close what they claim are loopholes with legislation which it was absolutely essential to put in place in order `to crack down on fraud and avoidance practices in the valuation of imported goods'. Where was `the Government's firm resolve to stamp out valuation avoidance practice'?

The Senate may recall that Senator Button, who was not present during most of the 1987 debate on this Bill and subsequently entered the chamber and petulantly made a totally unwarranted personal attack on me in which he accused me of not understanding the issues, implied that I must decide whether I support people making fraudulent and false declarations as to the value of goods. He alleged that specious grounds were advanced for deferring the legislation until February of last year. The reason for that personal attack on me was Senator Button's well known propensity for personal attacks on people whenever he is under pressure. When in difficulty Senator Button plays the man, not the ball. He was in difficulty because I had demonstrated that the Bill was badly flawed and the Customs community was genuinely concerned about it. Senator Button made that attack well knowing that both customs associations had expressed concerns about the Bill, that importers, retailers and major manufacturers were making representations about it and that the Law Council of Australia believed that it was `most desirable that consideration of this Bill by the Senate should be deferred until the autumn session of the Parliament'.

The Bill now re-emerges almost 16 months later with 45 amendments although, as I shall demonstrate, it remains flawed and once again is to be debated cognately with other Bills-a 1988 Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill and a Customs Tariff Amendment Bill of 488 pages. I question whether either the 1987 or the 1988 customs and excise legislation amendment Bills are necessary. Under the Customs Act the Comptroller-General has far-reaching powers and has not hesitated to exercise them. In 1986-87 goods to a total value of $16m were seized and about $9m was recovered in fines, reparations and additional duty demands. The 1987-88 annual report of the Australian Customs Service indicates that $40.9m was received in additional revenue as a result of quality control checks or intense auditing procedures. The same annual report reveals that the main purpose of this Bill is `to support the entry audit system', which is part of the import control program for ensuring clearance through Customs of commercial imports, taking account of revenue collection and control requirements. Yet the 1987-88 annual report suggests that the entry audit system is operating quite satisfactorily despite the absence of the Bill, which it was originally argued was essential to take effect on 1 January last year.

The 1987 Bill proposed a series of amendments to the principal Customs Act, which would introduce an administrative penalty regime similar to that imposed by the tax Acts. The Government now proposes to amend that Bill so that the administrative penalty regime and the offences provided for the making of a false and misleading statement are transferred to the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1988, and clause 16 of the Bill relating to the proposed extension to three years, for the recovery of short paid duty, is deleted. Both these moves are sensible, but unfortunately they seem to be the only sensible alterations made. The 1987 Bill will now proceed with two substantive elements only: firstly, the redraft of division 2 of part VIII of the Customs Act relating to the valuation of imported goods; and, secondly, the audit and verification of information powers and the complementary provision relating to the requirement to keep documents.

The Senate may recollect that on 26 November 1987 the Government announced that the Law Reform Commission would inquire into the Customs Act, the Excise Act and 11 related Acts and report to the Government by 30 September 1989. The Law Reform Commission was specifically excluded from examining this draft legislation, as the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) specified that the review by the Commission was not to impede the progress of legislation in any way. Accordingly, the Commission is waiting for the legislation to be passed by the Parliament before examining it. So the Law Reform Commission has been waiting for over 16 months to consider the massive problems in this area which the Attorney-General has acknowledged as, and I use his words, `complex and labyrinthine'. Given the complexity of this legislative package and the concerns of Customs, it would not have been difficult for the Government to have amended the reference to embrace this proposed legislation during the 16 months.

The time for the Law Reform Commission's review of this legislation will now be minimal. The Government may have to extend that time. This is typical of this Government. It gives lip service to consultation but consistently leaves inadequate time for proper consultation and examination. In the intervening 16 months Customs has managed to operate efficiently and without the draconian provisions now proposed in this Bill. Furthermore, the Government appears to have taken the view that by burying the Bill for 16 months and allowing the tumult to die down the objections might disappear. They have not done so, and on 3 March this year the Law Council of Australia made a 17-page submission with 13 points of remaining contention.

These Bills are complex and should have been subject to review by the Law Reform Commission, which has the task of attempting to simplify the Customs and associated Acts. As I mentioned, the draconian provisions in the 1987 Bill adopt the same attitude towards revenue raising provisions in the Customs Act as those that apply in the taxation Act. These provisions have been taken out of the 1987 Bill and transferred to the 1988 Bill, so that all the penalty regime and offences provisions are within that Bill, which I will deal with later.

Clause 12 of the 1987 Bill, which deals with the valuation of imported goods, is intended to rearrange the various provisions in division 2 of part VIII of the Customs Act into a more logical and easy to follow sequence. It highlights the various types of costs, charges and agreements relating to goods which are to be included or excluded for assessing the customs value of goods. The Government claims that clause 12 is designed to give effect to Australia's obligation under an agreement on implementation of article 7 of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT). A number of different organisations have made representatives and expressed serious misgivings about this clause. The Law Council of Australia believes that this technical and complex legislation is conducive neither to good administration nor to fairness to users of the customs systems, particularly given the new self-assessment burdens imposed on them. The legislation in that regard is in line with the Government's taxation legislation which imposes severe penalties for any mistakes in self-assessed burdens in the returns.

Customs agents say that this is not commercial reality in their industry because agents are under such enormous pressure to document imports in great haste when an aircraft lands or a ship berths, whereas tax agents have time to check and recheck returns and assessments. Customs agents support more modern systems to improve the assessment system but argue that the result of these amendments will be to clog the system, as they, the agents, introduce double checks for their own personal protection. Their arguments in this regard seem valid to me.

The valuation provisions occupy about 38 pages, in marked contrast to Canada's Customs Act, which is far shorter. The interpretations section proposed by this Bill occupies over 18 printed pages and contains 56 definitions, many of which have composite parts. The complicated definitions require cross-referencing to other sections of the legislation. There is concern about the number of definitions and the negative impact they could have on users of the system.

I now turn to the duty on foreign freight and insurance in new subsection 154 (1) as proposed by clause 12. The inclusion of foreign inland freight and insurance in the customs value of imported goods will have the effect of increasing the duty imposed on some or many imported goods and can also discriminate against import manufacturers on geographic grounds. For example, if a United States manufacturer is located inland and we purchase goods from that manufacturer, more duty will be imposed on those goods than if the manufacturer was located at a seaport, unless the product is actually packed in the inland factory in some sort of sea container and transported in that sea container. Is that not absolute nonsense?

This provision also discriminates against small business. Full container load (FCL) shippers-shippers of goods packed at the factory-gain an advantage over small shippers where goods are packed at coastal container depots to make up an FCL. We have a particular example in Australia with regard to ACI. That company transports pulp bulk soda ash from Wyoming to United States ports. Duty will now be imposed on the freight cost of that soda ash because it is not packed in a sea container. It is shipped, I presume, in open rail trucks. Because of that, duty will have to be paid on that freight cost.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is crazy.

—It is quite crazy, as Senator Boswell said. The Government has said that importers and others who consider they may suffer hardship because of the provision will be invited to put their case to the Government or the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) with a view to reduction of the duty on their goods. Why then impose it in the first place? Industry does not consider this offer to be satisfactory due to the time element and discrimination involved.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the civil liberties implications. I previously voiced concern that this legislation gives the Australian Customs Service wide powers of entry, search and inquiry. All officers of the Customs Service will have the power to enter premises and inspect and copy documents without warrant. The Government argues that these powers are necessary to facilitate verification as part of the process of allowing quick clearance of goods. The Law Council considers these provisions may infringe Article 17 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which provides that no person shall be subjected to arbitrary or unlawful interference with his privacy or correspondence and everyone has the right to the protection of the law against such interference. The Comptroller or a collector can make application for a search warrant by radio, telephone or other means of communication. This amendment has resulted from the Government agreeing not to include justices of the peace in the definition of `magistrate' for the purposes of issuing of warrants for the new audit powers. There are at least two Acts containing provisions allowing officials to obtain warrants be telephone-the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Act 1987 and the National Crimes Authority Act 1984. However, these Acts stipulate that the telephone warrant can be issued only by a judge.

There are also extensive discretionary powers. There are 84 discretions in the valuation provisions of the legislation. Naturally, the Law Council is gravely concerned about the nature and extent of the discretionary powers contained in the legislation. The discretions granted to the collector or his delegate are vast and require him to be satisfied as to so many matters that it is very difficult for users of the system to predict the result of the use of the discretion. But we must understand that what is proposed is a self-assessing system, and yet the collector has these vast discretionary powers. How then can importers self-assess when they do not really know how the collector will apply his discretion? Importers will be required to guess as to how the legislation will be exercised in estimating duty payable. I put to the Senate that this is commercially unsound and legally unsatisfactory. The Law Council advises that the Canadian valuation provisions do not give the collector or authorities any discretion in relation to any matter.

The main problems with the 1987 Bill remain. The civil liberties ramifications are simply not acceptable. The discretion given to Customs officials is too vast. The legislation is far too complex, the inland freight costs will simply increase business costs, and the Government gave the Law Reform Commission the task of reviewing and simplifying a complex and over-amended customs Bill. This amendment Bill does nothing to advance that clause and could, in fact, delay that much-needed review. Accordingly, the Opposition will be voting against the 1987 Bill.

I turn now to the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1988. This is an omnibus Bill which was introduced late last year proposing miscellaneous amendments to the Customs Act 1901 and the Excise Act 1901. The Bill is to have added to it the administrative penalty regime from the 1987 Bill which I dealt with previously. This new Customs regime imposed in this Bill is quite different from what has been acceptable in the past. It takes the user of the system away from the protection of the courts and the Customs Service in effect becomes informant, judge and executioner. However, as sugar coating on a poisonous pill, forfeiture is to be restricted as a sanction for a false or misleading statement to cases where a guilty mind is proven or reckless indifference can be established to the satisfaction of the comptroller. This erosion of people's rights is a feature of this Government and, in particular, this Government's administration in the tax collection areas. The scheme proposed is certainly not the way that I would go. But I recognise that the Government is entitled to choose its own path and to cut its own throat. Accordingly, we will not be opposing this Bill, but we will be monitoring this new regime very carefully.

The coalition is, however, strongly opposed to the Government's words `or otherwise' in proposed section 243T, which provides, `that where a person knowingly, recklessly or otherwise makes a false statement or misleading statement to a customs officer' et cetera, certain penalties apply. The words `or otherwise' are a catch-all provision and offer no protection for unintentional errors. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee, in Alert Digest No. 16 of 1988, drew attention to the fact that clause 26 would insert these new clauses which would:
(a) give to a Collector a power normally reserved to a court, of determining whether a statement is false or misleading in a material particular, and then imposing a penalty for that falsity; and
(b) impose that penalty on a person, even though the latter was completely innocent of any intention to mislead.
I continue quoting from the Scrutiny of Bills Committee:
. . . this may be compared with the normal situation in the criminal law, in which a person may be convicted only if he or she has a guilty mind or guilty intent.

Although the penalty provisions, when you read them as a layman, appear to be quite mild, in fact agents talk in terms of penalties of tens of thousands of dollars under the `twice excess' provision. They argue that the clause gives too much discretion to the bureaucrats and that in the thousands of documents cleared on the run, particularly with air freight, genuine mistakes occur which should not expose them to the proposed penalty and time consuming appeal provisions.

The Government claims that it has introduced a fast track system for the clearance of goods and that there should be an incentive for importers to ensure that their documentation is accurate. But the Government's penalties for inaccuracy are such that its fast track system will slow down rapidly as agents cross t's and dot i's to ensure that they do not incur these crippling penalties.

An important amendment is section 243U which allows section 243T not to apply in certain cases. But to gain benefit to this exemption the information about which one is uncertain must be declared and the reason for uncertainty must be included. When there is uncertainty the goods go into limbo until there is a determination. Because of the inclusion of the words `or otherwise', the penalty for innocent error is outrageous. Customs have acknowledged the complexity of the customs tariff. I recollect being given examples of where different subcollectors have given different interpretations for the same or similar goods. Customs recognise and acknowledge that it is sometimes difficult to correctly classify the goods. Labor's solution is to transfer the onus for correct classification to the user and, whether this error is genuine or not, to penalise him if his or her interpretation is incorrect. It is all very well to say that the Australian Customs Service and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal have a discretion to remit the penalty, but the cost of going to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal is a penalty in itself and the ACS is left with enormous discretion in determining what is and what is not unintentional error.

Meanwhile, the importer has three alternatives: he can take the goods out of the fast track and seek a determination from Customs, thus delaying clearance. Alternatively, under section 243u, he can seek an exemption from section 243t, but the reason for uncertainty must be declared and it would, therefore, be imprudent to sell the goods until the issue was resolved. Finally, he could take the risk that his own determination is correct and expose himself to the risk of crippling penalty if his judgment is wrong. Many importers rely on fast turnover of imported goods for either fashion or seasonal reasons. Delays cost money, particularly under the Hawke Government's high interest rate regime. This legislation leaves the importers of these goods with Hobson's choice. In the committee stage I will be moving an amendment to delete the words `or otherwise' and insert the word `or' between the words `knowingly' and `recklessly'.

The Bill also covers a number of minor provisions such as the manner in which the quantity of beer produced is measured for the purpose of assessing both customs and excise duty. It also covers controls pertaining to prohibited goods so as to permit the Minister for Defence to suspend licences. It will also extend the duty free entry to the Australian mainland of goods from Christmas Island to those goods from CI which were 50 per cent produced on the island. The Opposition supports the remainder of the Bill.

I turn finally to the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1988. This Bill is a machinery Bill which includes seven schedules and enacts a range of changes to the Customs Tariff Act 1987 which imposes customs duty on the importation of goods. It covers 488 pages. Customs have consolidated the changes to ensure reference to only the one volume. There is merit in this procedure. This amending Bill illustrates the complexity and the continuously changing nature of the harmonised tariff and the difficulties to which customs agents are exposed. It implements tariff proposals made during parliamentary recess and includes decisions in regard to tariff reductions announced in the May economic statement together with tariffs that are already phasing the changes to the passenger motor vehicle plan and the textile, clothing and footwear sectoral policy.

This Bill also makes two amendments: first, it amends the operative date for changes relating to vinyl wallpaper as from 1 January 1989 to seven days after royal assent; and, secondly, it deletes the proposed new Customs duties for certain sugar products and restores the current duty arrangements as effected by the Government's announcement in the 1987 May economic statement. My colleague Senator Boswell will have some words to say about the sugar proposals.

The Primary Industry and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), which is due to be debated on Friday, if passed unamended, would leave our sugar industry unprotected. However, I am assured that this will not take place. I understand that the Government is prepared to undertake that the sugar embargo will not be repealed until after the current Senate inquiry. I ask the Minister to give this undertaking in his response to the Senate in due course. The list of Government amendments in the two legislation Bills significantly altered both Bills. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee therefore re-examined both Bills and made certain comments. The Senate ought to examine the Scrutiny of Bills Committee report on this matter which was tabled today. It raised certain matters of great importance that should have been addressed by the Government. The Opposition will not be opposing the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1988.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps the degree of complexity of the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987, the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 and the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1988 is indicated by Senator Lewis's reference on several occasions to `243U' when in fact he should have referred to `243V'. Let us begin, as Senator Lewis did, by going back to December 1987. As he indicated, the Bill then before us was the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 which, at that stage, was recognised by both the Opposition and the Australian Democrats as both a complex Bill and one whose provisions had not been adequately put to the Customs agents, importers and others involved in the Customs business. Therefore, it was strongly opposed. We believed it had significant flaws which could have been corrected. At that stage, the Democrats supported the Opposition in moving for deferral of the legislation despite the fact that the Government indicated that the Bill was to become an Act and, if I recall, operative from 1 January.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill again emerged during the closing stages of the 1988 autumn session. I was approached by the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, Mr Barry Jones, with what he said was the Government's response to the objections raised by Customs agents, importers and others involved in this industry. The Minister gave me a quite thick document which gave the response of the Department to a number of issues and indicated to me that he wished the legislation to proceed very quickly. He asked me to get in touch with those that had been lobbying me and see whether they were satisfied with these suggested changes to the legislation. I said there was a lot to communicate and it would take some time. He pressed me-and I am rather amused now at this fact-to get on the telephone and ring these people up. There were dozens of people with this document which, as I recall, was about 25 pages long. We were in the middle of a very heavy legislative program. Of course, it was quite impossible for me to do anything over the next few days. As a consequence of that, I photocopied this document and sent it to the various interested parties when I got back to Adelaide at the end of that week. I understand that they were extremely grateful because, again, this was one of the first imitations that they claimed that they had had from the Department in relation to this very complex matter and the changes which the Government was making.

As a consequence of that process, further representations were made to the Department. As a consequence of that, some of the material that was in that Bill was shifted to the 1988 Bill. There has been a further round of amendments and some more recent amendments have just hit the deck. So we are dealing with a very complex area. We are dealing with an amending Bill which itself has been amended. There are more recent amendments and, on top of that, the Opposition has foreshadowed amendments. In recent days I have made a couple of minor suggestions to the Department regarding further amendments. So we are dealing with a very complicated piece of legislative change.

The Australian Customs Service is attempting, through this legislation, to change to a fast tracking system which will be to the advantage of importers and those involved in any way with the necessary payment of duty. It is proposed under this system that approximately 90 per cent of goods will be fast tracked. It is intended that those goods will be cleared through Customs within approximately four hours. It seems to me that it must follow that for that system to work, and for agents and importers to be honest and diligent in their preparation of documents, one needs a comprehensive and discouraging set of penalties which will adequately protect the revenue of the country.

We are looking at an activity which is second only to taxation as a source of income for the Government. Under the system now in place approximately only 10 per cent of imports are routinely checked. This is similar to the sort of thing that happens at international airports. There will always be the suspicion that the documentation, the declaration of the type of goods and so on in respect of the goods that have not been checked, will have been done incorrectly or perhaps fraudulently. That is the background to the set of amendments at which we are now looking. So there is a need to buttress the system with adequate provisions and penalties to ensure that the system works well and so that the government revenue does not suffer. It can be seen, then, that the system is complex. Indeed, some people are opposing the legislation on the grounds of its complexity. But it seems to me that part of that complexity arises out of the intention by the Government and the Department to offer this speeded-up system.

I have indicated already that we have amendments, on amendments, on amendments, to the legislation. The Government has now included as many as 45 amendments to the original December 1987 Bill. So, I think one can fairly say that at this stage, although perhaps the Government and the Department have been a little bit tardy in communicating to those affected what they had in mind, we have a piece of legislation which goes a long way towards meeting the objections which were mounted at an early stage and, again, in May and June last year.

Objections to this legislation are still being voiced. Some of the objections which I have heard in recent days relate to the fact that the most recent amendments have not been communicated to those affected. There has been quite a flurry of activity in the last couple of days. Faxed copies of the most recent amendments have been sent to various affected people. By and large, one can say that it seems that, while they are not particularly happy with all of the provisions, nonetheless there is a willingness to accept that in many respects the earlier objections have been met. For instance, one of the strong early objections related to the period during which the Department could go back and make a claim for wrongly declared duty. This has been picked up in these amendments so that there is now a limitation of 12 months. That would seem to me to meet the objection which was originally made to that area.

The Department, nonetheless, is insisting that documents relevant to the declaration of customs be kept for a period of five years. There is still some objection to that on the ground that if penalties can be exacted only for up to 12 months why is there a necessity to keep documents for five years? It seems to me to be perfectly fair that in cases where declarations may have been wrongly made, for whatever reason, and there is a consistent pattern, the Department should have access to documents extending over a longer period. Even though the penalties may be exacted only with respect to those breaches which have occurred in the last 12 months, nonetheless the evidence that a person has been consistently under-declaring or wrongly declaring particular goods is surely relevant to the sort of penalties which should be exacted. In the case of the Australian Taxation Office, my understanding is that documents should be retained for seven years. I would not have thought that it was particularly arduous to retain the relevant documents for a period of five years. I see no conflict between that requirement and the limitation which has now been placed on the Department that legal action can be taken only for a period of up to 12 months.

There is still concern in relation to the issuing of warrants and whether the Department can go on fishing expeditions to importers' premises or customs agents' premises. Senator Lewis indicated that in the initial legislation, the 1987 legislation, it was suggested that justices of the peace be able to issue warrants and that that was objected to. We now have the requirement that only a magistrate can issue such a warrant, but that that warrant can be issued over the telephone. There seems to be some difference of opinion as to whether the Law Council or the Law Institute of Victoria originally made that suggestion. Somebody, apparently, made a suggestion, at the time that the objection was made about justices of the peace, that a quid pro quo for upgrading the quality of the warrants by requiring magistrates to issue them might be a provision that they could be issued over the telephone.

Objection is now made that, in the case of such a warrant, a person might be faced with a request to examine certain documents, and that that request may be legally refused. The Customs officer may then ring a magistrate, obtain a warrant, return with a warrant made out in the handwriting of the Customs officer, show it to the occupier, demand entry and legally gain entry. It is argued that that is objectionable on the grounds that the occupier of the premises need not necessarily know that the warrant is genuine. The provisions in the legislation at the moment allow for the verification of the warrant through a process which involves the agent writing out verbatim the instruction which the magistrate gives over the telephone and eventually sending that copy of the warrant back to the magistrate. The magistrate compares that warrant with the warrant which he made out and ensures that they are the same.

I have suggested-and I hope that the Government considers the suggestion-that as a further guarantee the officer should provide to the occupier of the premises the name and telephone number of the magistrate, invite the occupier to ring the magistrate and confirm that the warrant was correctly issued, and invite the occupier to make a photocopy of the warrant so that that copy can also be sent back to the magistrate and married with the original warrant made out by the magistrate. If that additional check were provided for, the complaints which are still being made regarding the issuing of telephone warrants would largely disappear.

An alternative approach, which is now available with modern technology, is to operate a fax machine from a 12-volt system in a car. It would be possible for Customs officers who have a fax machine in the car to get a warrant over the telephone and actually print a hard copy which could be shown to the occupier of the premises.

TALK.START.PARA: —There go their stereos.

—With the price of stereos these days, fax machines might be cheaper. Another complaint is about how a Customs officer, once he has gained access to the premises, where he can only look for documents which are relevant to a particular entry, knows where those documents are. Can the officer not then go on a fishing expedition? It seems to me that that depends very much on the cooperation of the person whose premises are being searched. If the standard documents associated with the entry are asked for and presented, it seems to me that that should complete the matter. If, on the other hand, the person whose premises are being searched is uncooperative, quite clearly the officer would need to go on some sort of fishing expedition to find the relevant documents. As I say, it seems to me that with the provision of the surety over the genuineness of the warrant those matters are adequately covered in this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Lewis referred to the penalty provisions under section 243t. He did not draw attention to the provisions relating to section 234d. I think it is worth drawing attention to the fact that the legislation makes a clear distinction between declarations which are wrong and which are made knowingly and recklessly, without any further qualification-those covered by section 234d-and those covered under section 243t, which contains the extra qualification that the declaration is made knowingly, recklessly or otherwise.

I think it is necessary to point out that there is now a 12-month limitation under section 243t, so that issue has been picked up. In cases of uncertainty-something that Senator Lewis referred to, but referred to incorrectly as section 243u-under 243v it is possible that if there is uncertainty as to any aspect related to the nature of the goods or the duty payable, the agent or importer can nominate that information as information of which the owner or agent is uncertain and set out the reasons for that uncertainty, and where the owner or agent does so, no penalty shall be imposed under section 243t in relation to that information. If one takes that together with the ability to get an indication from the Department before import of what duty should be payable on particular goods, it seems to me that that provision under section 243v adequately covers the situation with respect to the words `or otherwise'. In most cases one is dealing with people who hold themselves out as professional operators, people who are supposed to be expert in the area of importing goods, in the procedures and the duties and so on that are payable. Despite the complexity, they operate as professional people in an area no more and no less complex than many other professional areas, and one expects-quite rightly-a very high degree of professionalism from those people. There should be very few errors.

Section 234d, to which I referred a moment ago, quite clearly is a declaration which in every respect is far more serious than what is envisaged under section 243t. Section 234 says `knowingly or recklessly'. In other words, there is a much higher degree of proof required that the person concerned quite deliberately, or in quite serious disregard of the law, made out certain declarations which were incorrect. In that case as well as there being a higher level of proof required, the penalties also are much higher. The penalties in that case are a penalty not exceeding $5,000 and twice the amount of the total duty payable on the goods-a very significant penalty. I do not think anybody so far has said that that penalty is in any way excessive. However, there are situations in which one cannot achieve that level of certainty in a case against an importer, a level of proof which requires that the Department establish that the information was wrong `knowingly or recklessly', and the other provision under 243t covers the case where, although that level of seriousness is not involved, nonetheless information was wrongly set down. It seems to me that cases grade from the most trivial through to those cases which fall just short of those which would come under section 234. Then the penalties which are exactable are much less; a penalty of $20 or twice the difference between the duty which was payable and the amount which should have been paid, whichever is the greater. There is in section 243u provision for the remission of those penalties, and there are a series of clauses which set out the mechanisms and the factors which must be taken into account by the Comptroller of Customs in relation to remitting the whole or part of those penalties. Again, it seems to me that, remembering that in most cases one is dealing with professional people, people who hold themselves out as professionals, those provisions are indeed adequate.

Finally on that section, there has been a claim that there should be an upper limit on the penalty so that if one is importing a very large volume of goods even that penalty under 243t could be excessive. I think the answer to that, quite simply, is that if one is importing a large amount of goods with a large value on which the duty payable could be extremely large, the duty of care to ensure that the documentation is correct becomes even higher, and that therefore the penalties are appropriate. Honourable senators should bear in mind again the provisions in 243v, which presumably apply even though the value of the goods may be very high.

Another issue which has been raised-I think by Senator Lewis-is the duty on foreign inland freight. It seems that in this legislation the Government is attempting to clarify the situation. Essentially, it has said that the duty payable should be on the value of the goods free on board. The problem of containerised goods, to use and an absolutely horrible term, arises under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), that is that goods which are containerised are deemed to have been exported from the time they go into the container, even though the container may be packed inland. It seems that there are considerable advantages in clarifying the situation, of adopting the free on board convention and, of course, adopting the GATT convention with regard to containerised goods.

Whatever convention one adopts, that may have in certain instances-and Senator Lewis gave one example-certain disadvantages for particular goods. My understanding is that the Government has given an undertaking to refer instances in which this change will cause substantial changes to the protective duty to the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) and that those changes can be looked at. It is interesting that there is a contrast between what those people who have made representations on this matter are saying with respect to the possible disadvantage of small importers who, because they are importing only small amounts of material, do not have the material packed into containers inland in the country of export, and the claims that in relation to the exchange rate, the large importers can use forward exchange rates whereas the small importers cannot. One cannot help but contrast the arguments, which run in opposite directions.

Going back briefly to the matter of inland freight, there is a situation which is in every way comparable to the payment of local council rates, where the absolute amount one pays is arrived at by multiplying the valuation on the property by the rate. One might have a high valuation and a low rate or a low valuation and a high rate, but one may pay exactly the same local council rates. In this case, if the payment of duty on that element of foreign inland freight pushes up the value of the goods, it may be appropriate in certain circumstances to reduce the rate of duty payable, which would then bring the total amount paid, which is what the importers are interested in, back to the amount which is now being paid.

The claim has been made that the discretions which are included are excessive. Again it seems to me that on the one hand those who are complaining about this package of Bills are saying that the legislation should be simpler and more precise. It seems to me that there is a conflict of aims. If they want simpler legislation, it must necessarily include more discretionary powers. If they want the legislation to be more precise, it will be more complex. They also object to the complexity of the legislation.

I would briefly point out that section 8 of the 1988 Bill will be addressed by my colleague Senator McLean. In the brief time that remains to me in this debate, I shall refer briefly to the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 3) and draw attention to two matters. One is that the schedule still includes the importation of worked ivory. I understand that the importation of ivory into Australia is illegal. If it is not an illegal import in all circumstances, it certainly is in respect of certain sources of ivory. I understand that there is considerable illegal trade in ivory in African countries between dealers in South Africa and some of the other African countries. This is leading to illegal and continuous predation on African elephants.

Finally, I shall be moving an amendment to the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 3) which will relate to solar cells. The technology has moved on to a great extent and it would considerably benefit Australia to allow the importation of solar cells without duty. There are considerable advantages to the wider adoption of that technology in this country. The price of these items is coming down and they are now becoming quite competitive with centrally generated electricity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is now dealing with Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) and Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 3). I wish to confine my remarks to the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) and to sugar. Before I continue with my contribution, I wish to express my concern about and offer my best wishes to the sugarcane growers who have had their crops flattened and their houses destroyed by Cyclone Aivu, and also to the many mill workers who have suffered at the hands of the cyclone. I know that all honourable senators will echo my remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government in its May statement announced that it would remove the sugar embargo. The customs legislation which is now before the House originally introduced a tariff structure to give the industry some type of protection if the embargo is lifted. But because of the advent of an inquiry to be conducted the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology inquiry-it was referred to the Committee by the Opposition and the Australian Democrats-the proposal to remove the tariff is no longer contained in this amending legislation. If the legislation were passed to remove the embargo, as could happen by means of legislation that is about to come before the House in the form of the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2)-it is listed for consideration on Friday-the sugar industry would suffer and would have no protection at all. I ask Senator Bolkus whether he can give an assurance that the primary industry Bill will not be proceeded with, or if it does proceed that that part of the Bill which refers to sugar will be removed. I have sought an assurance from Senator Macklin-perhaps I should have sought it from Senator Coulter-and I have been assured that the Democrats will join us in blocking that Bill.

I am disappointed with the standard of representation given by Labor members, particularly Mr Courtice and Mr Gayler, who represent sugar seats. I believe that they have not looked after the best interests of the industry. They have ignored the industry to an extent. It is not unusual in Australian Labor Party circles to ignore farmers, but it is unusual that they should ignore the mill workers and those who give them traditional support. The Australian Workers Union (AWU) has made a submission to the Senate inquiry and that inquiry is now struggling to deal with some of the concerns expressed by the AWU.

The Labor Party is in disarray over the sugar industry and the lifting of the embargo. Mr Courtice, the member for Hinkler, and Mr Gayler, the member for Leichhardt, are toadying to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) in full support of his statement to lift the embargo and to bring down a tariff structure of 35 per cent on raw sugar and 25 per cent on refined sugar. In 1992 the tariff on new sugar will fall to 15 per cent. The State opposition spokesman on primary industry says that he will call for a reversal of the decision to lift the embargo. He said in a statement he issued to the Daily Mercury on 21 March 1989 that there should be no action in respect of an embargo on the sugar industry. It is very confusing when the Minister, Mr Kerin, is saying one thing, Mr Courtice and Mr Gayler are backing him up, the AWU is saying something totally different, and Mr Casey is saying that it will cause immense political damage to the Australian Labor Party. Mr Casey has done his sums-they are set out in the article I mentioned-and he says that the sugar industry plays an important role in 19 or 20 State parliamentary seats and in up to nine seats in the Federal sphere. At least Mr Casey can do his political arithmetic.

The tariff recommended on raw sugar is 35 per cent, phasing down to 15 per cent in 1992. On raw sugar the tariff becomes an effective tariff of 30 per cent phasing down to 10 per cent. In case of Fiji and some of the smaller developing nations, sugar will be allowed to come into Australia tariff-free. Mr Kerin claims in his submission to the Senate inquiry that that will not happen initially, but gives no guarantee that it will not happen in the long term. He has given no commitment into the future. The Minister also claims that if subsidised, dumped beet sugar were imported at a 10 per cent tariff, the Government would act. These vague promises by the Minister are not good enough. We are talking about legislation and tariff structures that will give some protection to an industry-not vague promises that if certain things happen the Minister might take certain steps if he feels like doing so. That is not the way to legislate and it gives no standing to an industry which provides many jobs and many export dollars. One cannot run a business, a farm or a sugar industry on promises. People want to know what is in the legislation so that they can plan for it.

The sugar industry and I believe that the tariff structure of 35 per cent phasing down to 15 per cent is not good enough in times of extremely low prices. The industry is climbing out of the worst sugar price slump in history, when prices fell to as low as 2.3c and averaged about 4c a pound from 1982 to 1985. What is the use of a tariff of 15 per cent on 4c a pound? The present tariff on a pound of sugar is 0.6. That is not going to stop dumped sugar, subsidised sugar and corrupt sugar, which affect world prices, from entering Australia. It is not going to stop countries that are desperately seeking hard Australian currency selling sugar at any price. They will almost give it away so that they can come up with some hard currency. Only a month ago Cuba made considerable sales to New Zealand at almost give away prices so that it could get hard currency. Most of Cuba's sugar is sold to the Eastern bloc countries on contra deals and, if it can get access to markets just to attain hard currency, it will place its sugar in those markets.

These are the things that I do not believe this Government has considered. It is cheaper to ship to Australia sugar from places like Cuba, Mauritius and Fiji than it is to send sugar around the coast of Australia. It is cheaper to bring sugar in on ships from overseas than it is to put raw sugar on a boat and send it around to Western Australia for refining.

The Government is always gung ho in making farmers bear the cost of the wharf charges and shipping costs and it is always up front in removing any benefits from the rural community. We have seen that over the six years of this Government. It has really stuck the knife right into the heart of rural industries in Australia, and this is yet another example. If it is fair dinkum about wanting deregulation, it must bring it in uniformly right across Australia; then it will not have any opposition from this side of the Parliament. It has to address the problems on the wharves. We heard a lot about that yesterday. It also has to address the problems in shipping and rail. But it must not pick out just one sector of the community and take the stick to it because it does not vote for the Government, because then it is being discriminatory and is catching in the net a lot of people who do vote for it, as a lot of AWU members work in the sugar mills. Probably all sections of the union movement are represented in the mills. These are the people that the Government is inflicting these proposals on.

Mr Kerin's proposed tariff may be effective and reasonable when sugar is around 11c a pound, as it is now. Not a lot of tariff is required then. But we do not legislate only for the good times; we do not legislate when sugar is 11c a pound. Sugar is the most corrupted and subsidised commodity in the world. We have had prices as low as 2.3c a pound and it is now hovering at 11c and could go as high as 15c. The devastation caused by the cyclone will probably lift prices. But Mr Kerin cannot guarantee these high prices; no one can. If sugar prices fall to the previous low of around 5c a pound, and they will as surely as night follows day, the refining industry in Australia will be able to bring in sugar at 5c a pound, with a tariff as low as 10 to 15 per cent in 1992. It would be delighted to pay even 10 to 15 per cent tariff, which would bring the cost of sugar up to a little under 6c a pound. That is what the refining industry will be able to purchase sugar for if the corrupt prices on the world fall. We will see imported sugar setting the bench mark for Australian sugar sold on the domestic market. In effect, the Australian refineries will tell the Australian sugar producers-and they are the most efficient producers in the world-that they can buy raw sugar from Thailand, Cuba, Fiji, or some nation that is dumping or subsidising sugar, for about 5c a pound. The refineries will say that is what they are going to pay the sugar producers and the millers of raw sugar in Queensland and northern New South Wales.

The price for domestic sugar will be forced down so that we can compete with countries that are subsidised by governments or countries that will sell at any price to get foreign currency. We have been caught right in the cross-fire of the biggest trade war in the history of the world, and there is no sign of that trade war lessening. Some of the headlines that we are seeing daily in the newspapers are: `Our future imperilled by US-EC trade war', `Alerting America to the dangers of subsidies', `Australia to seek a way out of subsidies', `Scepticism over talks of free trade', and `Hooked on subsidy fixes'. Mr Duffy, the Minister for Trade Negotiations, is becoming very despondent. He cannot see any progress at all against the trade wars, the subsidies and the corrupt world markets. I am a realist in politics. I have always believed that politics is the art of the possible. I understand the problems of the embargo, but surely this is not the time when we should be looking at lifting the embargo.

I have mentioned that the price of domestic sugar will be forced down so that we can compete with countries which are subsidised by governments or countries that will sell at any price. If the Australian Labor Party believes that the refiners will pass the savings onto the public, it believes in the tooth fairy. It will not happen. The savings will go into the general revenue of that company because there is effectively only one refiner in Australia. It will not have to meet competition in the marketplace to keep the price of sugar down at the retail level. What is in it for that company?

The proposed tariff system will transfer $80m from the farmer to the refiner, at current prices. That is a $80m loss if prices fall. I ask the Minister to look at the worst scenario. I have been accused by Mr Courtice, Mr Gayler and the Minister of making whacky and wild statements that the industry could lose up to $300m a year. I do not retreat from those statements. My statement about the loss of $300m to the industry was made on the worst possible scenario. Having been in politics for six years, I am a great believer in Murphy's law: the worst thing will happen at the worst possible time. If the price falls to 1985 levels of around 4c a pound-that is, the world parity-plus a tariff of 10 to 15 per cent, that will then set the price that the refiner will pay to the sugar mills. That is when a loss of $300m becomes possible. If the refiners were able to import sugar at 5c a pound and then say to the industry, `We can bring it in from all over the world at 5c a pound. That is the world price and that is what we are going to pay you' that will result in a loss of $300m. The Minister and his two backbenchers Mr Courtice and Mr Gayler know very well that if the price of sugar falls to 1985 levels and refiners set those world parity prices as domestic prices for raw sugar a loss of $300m will result and thousands of unionists will join the dole queue. It is no good for Mr Kerin and his two handmaidens Mr Courtice and Mr Gayler to rubbish me in the press and in speeches, saying that it cannot happen. It can happen; it has happened.

The only thing that held the sugar industry together was that it had a reasonable domestic price. The Government is not prepared to guarantee the price, and we are not calling on it to do that. The Government cannot do that. Nobody can guarantee a price in the corrupt world market. The Minister knows it can happen. So does Mr Courtice if he is in any way realistic. He was a sugarcane grower. He should know these things can happen. The AWU is telling him that it can happen, the farmers are telling him that it will happen, but he is not prepared to accept the representations from his electorate. Mr Gayler has already stood by with his hands in his pockets and seen 2,500 jobs destroyed in the timber industry in his electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. My point of order is that the honourable senator on his feet is attacking a member of another place. I think that is against Standing Orders.
—Senator Boswell, I hope you are not attacking somebody in the other place.

—Far be it for me to attack anyone in this Parliament. Mr Courtice and Mr Gayler attacked me unmercifully in their speeches and I am merely replying, so you can rest assured, Madam Acting Deputy President, that I will not continue any form of attack. I believe that these people are elected to represent people in their electorates and that they have failed absolutely miserably to do so in respect of the timber industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Not content with that, Mr Gayler is now prepared to back the Minister's statement and not stand up for the mill workers in his electorate. Mr Casey, in a press release, disagreed violently with him. At least he has the courage or the political sense to do that because he knows members of parliament must represent their electorates if they are going to survive. He has been around a long time and he is prepared to make a statement supporting the sugarcane growers and the sugar industry workers. It is a pity that Mr Courtice and Mr Gayler do not follow suit.

A set ad valorem tariff cannot and will not work on a commodity that can fluctuate from 2.3c to 15c a pound in two years. That is a fluctuation of over 550 per cent. The price can fall just as quickly. There is a need to have some sort of value tariff on sugar. Many minds on both sides of this Parliament are struggling with that question at the moment. Senator Childs and Senator Burns are on a committee that is investigating that question. I am not going to set up any proposal because I know that these matters are exercising the minds of these particular senators as well as senators on this side of the House. Senator Brownhill and Senator Coulter are also trying to propose something that will give some form of equity. Some protection is needed when prices fall as low as 2c a pound. We are caught in a crossfire of two giant nations warring on subsidies.

I was extremely disappointed by Mr Kerin's submission to the Senate inquiry. He said he was giving up on the sugar industry. Those are the words of a tired Minister and a Minister that wants to get out, give it away. I say to Mr Kerin that, if he wants to be relieved of duties, he should go to the Prime Minister and say, `I have had enough'. I know the 150,000 farmers in Australia who still remain would share the relief. He has lost the fire in his belly. He should do what Senator Walsh did and say that he wants to be relieved.

Apart from generally bagging the National Party for having the support of the sugar industry, Mr Kerin pointed out that there were between 6,000 and 6,500 cane growers and that only a hundred of those went out when the price was down as low as 2.3c per pound. He asked why cane growers would not survive when they received 15 per cent tariff on 2.3c to 5c a pound. Mr Kerin misses the whole point, the whole crux of the argument. Cane growers survived on domestic prices. When they were selling sugar overseas at 2c per pound they had a domestic price that underpinned their industry. These domestic prices were not corrupted by trade wars or subsidies.
