Cane growers also survived on a few long term sugar contracts and by sending their wives out to make beds in hotels and motels, by applying for family allowances, by living off their land, growing their own food, running up gigantic overdrafts and by hanging on with their fingernails until better times came.

That is the way most rural producers live. In a drought they hope that every day that goes by is a day closer to rain. They hope that every day there are low prices is a day closer to price rises. When rural producers get better prices they run into 18 per cent interest rates. But one thing that sugar farmers never did was to stop planting. They always provided jobs for their AWU mates. They never lost faith with the people in the mills. Mill workers received full pay. Even at times when it was uneconomical to plant sugar the farmers kept planting. They kept faith with the industry; they kept the mills running even when it became unprofitable for them.

Mr Courtice made mention in his speech that the embargo has cost the sugar industry a lot of money. I suppose that argument could be advanced if world prices were way up, high in the sky. The sugar industry said, `We will share with the Australian community and we will not go for world prices'. When times were good overseas the Australian sugar industry shared those good times. But in bad times-and we have good and bad times in rural industries-we have got to give some sort of protection against dumped sugar and corrupt prices, which are now widespread. Every day we see statements in the papers about corrupt world markets. Mr Duffy is spending months of his time overseas trying to straighten out the international trade situation but he is making no progress. We have got to give some sort of protection in bad times.

Australian sugar growers are prepared to go out and meet the world market price of 2.3c a pound. Even as low as that, they will meet the world markets. The sugar industry is worth $700m to the Australian economy. But sugar growers have got to have a stable domestic price to underpin their industry. Domestic sales represent 20 per cent of sugar grown in Australia. Eighty per cent of sugar grown is exported. Australia's share of the world market is 3 per cent. If the industry cannot get the commitment of a stable price for domestic sales then the next sugar catastrophe-and there are always catastrophes-will do immense damage to the industry and will cause the loss of the jobs of many unionists working in the sugar mills throughout Queensland and northern New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —Kerin does not care.

—I know Mr Kerin does not care. He is an academic. He did have the respect of the farmers at one stage but, sadly, he has squandered that over the last six years. To make a statement, as Mr Kerin did, that he is giving up on the sugar industry is an absolute disgrace. I say to Mr Courtice and Mr Gayler, `For goodness sake put a bit of steel in your backbones and stand up for your people; don't go around like handmaidens to the Minister, toadying to him on every word he says because you are neglecting the very people who elected you to this Parliament and you are selling your constituents out'.

SPEECH.PARA: I make a strong plea to the Government to listen to the Senate inquiry when its report comes down. I believe these people are making a genuine effort to solve some of the problems. I ask Senator Bolkus while he is on the telephone to talk to the Minister responsible for this Bill and get some sort of assurance that the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) will not go through until the Senate inquiry submits its report to this House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating cognately the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987, which the Opposition will be opposing, the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1988-I have much pleasure in supporting the amendment moved by Senator Lewis to the motion for the second reading of that Bill-and the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1988. I do not wish to cover the points that have already been covered very well by speakers on this side of the chamber. We are quite opposed to the second Bill. In essence, it lumps crooks and honest people together and makes the penalties for both classes the same. It is the old Labor syndrome of the very ethos of its political life-that is, to trust no-one. The Government certainly does not trust the Customs agents in Australia. I will go on to that in more detail in a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: The Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 has as its purpose to combat the practice of understating the value of imported goods so as to minimise or avoid Customs duty. We support the Bill's intention but we do not think the procedures that it lays down are acceptable. The Bill amends the Customs Act 1901 and the Excise Act 1901. The main provisions of the Bill, in clause 12, deal with the valuation of imported goods. The value can be determined in a number of ways-the transaction value, which is the simplest method, the identical goods value, the deductive contemporary sales value, the deductive later sales value, the deductive derived goods sale value, the computed value and the fall back value. The owners are to be advised of the determined value of goods and can request information on the method used to calculate the value. It strengthens the powers of officers to inspect documents and requires documentation to be kept for five years. One of the underlying things that Senator Lewis mentioned is the belief that Customs officers are to be given exactly the same powers as the taxation officers. While they are both taxing functions in a way, the way the taxes are collected is quite different in practice. They really demand different methods, and not what the Government is trying to do in this case: to transfer some of the more stand and deliver highwayman tactics of Messrs Boucher and company of the Australian Taxation Office into the Customs Department, where they are really quite inappropriate.

Our objection centres to a large degree on the penalties for false statements. I will go into that in some detail in a moment. This is a reasonably complex piece of legislation and, as Senator Lewis has said, it has had a long delay. It first saw the light of day in 1987. It has only now come back to the Parliament. There have been serious points raised by the Law Council of Australia, a responsible body representing the National Council of Lawyers. It has written several times on this matter. Its first letter puts the matter quite succinctly where it says:

The Bill is extremely complicated as evidenced by the somewhat tortuous and often extensive definitions contained in the Bill which are almost certain to cause great uncertainty and concern to ordinary users of the Customs system. The fact that the draftsman has resorted to setting out hypothetical examples in order to illustrate the operation of some of the provisions of the legislation is evidence enough of the complexity of many of the provisions and the difficulties likely to be experienced in their practical operation.
Although the Bill has been amended since the Law Council wrote that letter in December 1987, the generality of its claims still apply. Its points of criticism have not been met.

The second area of concern has come from the Australian Customs Agents Federation, which is a responsible body: it is a national body supporting customs agents. In a letter of 8 February 1988 from the Executive Director of that body, protest is made about the way the debate was carried out in the Parliament, when some members of the House of Representatives attacked the standing of Customs agents. The Executive Director points out in the second paragraph of his letter to Senator Button:

In the first instance we reiterate, our members do not support duty evasion. It is neither morally acceptable to us or commercially sound. We take strong exception to the temperate and false accusations made in the parliament reflecting on the honesty and integrity of Customs Agents. It may be worthy of note that while barristers, solicitors, magistrates, accountants, politicians and customs officers are at this moment serving criminal sentences, not one licensed customs agent is in gaol nor to the best of our knowledge has one been gaoled. For people who individually handle millions of dollars of other peoples funds we believe that this is a fair testimony for our professional integrity.

I certainly support the Customs Agents Federation in its claim that customs agents have an enviable record of integrity in the discharge of their duties. It is very wrong for the Government-Senator Button and some speakers in the other place-to attack the integrity of the customs agents of Australia, saying that they are conspiring to defraud the Commonwealth of its due charges. The letter goes on to say:

We, like any other professionals providing commercial advice, have a duty to our clients not only to pay the correct duty but to ensure that it is the minimum amount payable under the law. If the law is so poorly framed that it allows different interpretations which require courts to settle disputes, it is quite improper to label as ``shonky'' those who take advantage, quite legally, of its existing format.

That is a statement of fact. If the law is the governing thing and if it is badly drafted and there are loopholes in it, we should correct the loopholes in a practical way. Let us not impute dishonesty to people who still act within the letter of the law. That is not the central point of this matter. The central point of the objection to this legislation relates to the fact that it lumps honest people who genuinely make mistakes with those who set out to intentionally defraud.

I have had some experience of the practical side of Customs Acts over 20 years now. I have imported a considerable number of items for my personal use that have required Customs clearances. There are international customs declarations and all the other rigmarole must be gone through. There are certain thresholds. It used to be up to $80 worth of goods which came in duty free. Between that and about $200 there was one form to fill in and beyond that there was another one. From all of those clearances I did myself I have some insight into the enormous complexities of the by-laws that cover importation into this country. It annoys me that a private citizen who is prepared to take an interest in what should be an elementary procedure finds that Customs officers on many occasions will not give any help. On some occasions they will. I suspect that they are far more ready to give me help now that they know I am a senator-not that I tell them; the goods come in directed to `Senator MacGibbon'. I find that on the rare occasion I import things now, there is always a courteous Customs officer available to tell me what the by-law numbers are. But for 10 or 15 years before that I used to do it as a private individual, and it is very difficult because there are thousands and thousands of Customs categories that we have to fit in with. We make a declaration and the relevant duty is paid on that basis. It is really a complex and arcane process. The possibility, even with the best of care and intention, that a genuine mistake will be made is very high.

It is always part of our law that we differentiate between those who, in a premeditated way, set out to defraud and break the law and those who make genuine mistakes. Beyond that is the doctrine of being able to pay for our crimes, but that takes me down another pathway again. It is quite wrong to impose, as this legislation does, those draconian penalties on those people who genuinely make mistakes, particularly in the nature of modern customs clearances.

A lot of the things that come in that attract high duty are high value components. They are important to the purchaser or the end user in Australia. For that reason, they often come in by air. For example, an aircraft might have a component failure or it might be in for maintenance and a part is required. The owner of the aircraft rings up the parts supplier in the United Kingdom or United States. Although the part supplier is phoned on the same day as the part is required and he promises immediate delivery, it could be 10 or 15 days before that package is actually made up on an aircraft coming into Australia. Someone may have an aircraft or a piece of equipment that costs half a million dollars or several million dollars. It is down for two or three weeks. When that part comes in it is wanted straight away because, quite naturally, the operator wants that equipment back in service to get its revenue earning potential. So the pressure is on the customs agent to get that package out of Customs and into the workshop straight away. It will not be only one case; the customs agent might have 10 or 20 cases to clear in a hurry. He does his best but, inevitably, there is a high probability that the wrong tariff section will be named.

The present legislation says that the duty that is short paid shall be paid, which is fair enough, but it also says that the short paid duty will be doubled. The net effect of that is that there is a tripling of the amount short paid. It might not matter if it was only for $4 or $5, but some of these things can run into many thousands of dollars. The only thing that the customs agent can do in these circumstances is to pay under duress and then appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Anyone who has dealt with the Administrative Appeals Tribunal knows that there is a fair bit of time involved. Of course, there is a big economic penalty on the interest in the money forgone which has probably been incorrectly charged. It is also an unwieldy and unreasonable process to go through where someone has made a genuine mistake. I am advised that if one looks at the history of appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, one finds that the break down is fifty-fifty. In other words, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal finds that in about 50 per cent of the cases the Australian Customs Service was correct but that in the other 50 per cent of cases the customs agents were correct. So it looks as if the error rate lies pretty close to the midline. But even if that does not sway us, the fact that the figure is about 5 per cent in favour of the customs agents is highly significant. It is on those grounds that we oppose this legislation.

I now move to the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1988. I have much pleasure in supporting Senator Lewis's amendment. This amends the Customs Act 1901 and the Excise Act 1901. It contains a range of amendments relating to beer, the measurement of volumes, defence exports, goods from Christmas Island, offence provisions, the imposition of excise duties on Government instrumentalities and other minor, technical amendments. Most of those have been covered by other speakers, and I do not wish to take up the time of the Senate on them, except to make reference to clause 8 which relates to licensing procedures for the export of military and dual-use technology goods, that is, goods that have both a commercial and military application. As I said in the Senate some weeks ago, I very much support the move to increase Australia's exports of defence equipment. It is long overdue and there is no simple fix, but the Government is to be applauded for the legislative steps it has taken, principally in another Act and not this legislation, to increase our ability to export military equipment.

Clause 8 provides licensing powers for exporters and details the way that those powers can be withdrawn in times of need. Without entering into a protracted debate on the value of military exports to Australia, I would make two very brief points: first of all, if we develop our own production facilities for military equipment, it will lead us to having more appropriate equipment for the Australian defence forces. Secondly, there is some good economics in it. Most of the equipment that the Australian defence forces use is developed for the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation forces. That means that it is optimised for cool, temperate climates in Europe. While some of it works very well there, it does not necessarily work as well in conditions of very high temperature, and sometimes very high humidity and dust as we have in Australia. It is also designed for very high threat scenarios where there are always a great number of countermeasures for any piece of equipment. So the inherent cost of that equipment is always very high. I believe that there is scope to develop military equipment that is suitable for the tropical, subtropical and dry areas of Australia. It can often be simpler and more effective in that particular environment than a great deal of the material we import. For us to do that, it is important that we have access to bigger markets than those of the Australian defence forces.

That leads me to the second point which is the economics of it. To develop any sort of effective weapons system at all requires very big expenditure on research and development. We simply cannot justify it on the short order runs that we have. A third point that occurs to me as I say this is the matter of self-sufficiency. The Fraser Government in its White Paper on defence set out the premise that we ought to move to be as reliant as we can in our defence needs. That was picked up by this Government in a 1987 defence of Australia White Paper and reinforced. If we are going to be self-sufficient, then we have to have our own production capability to the extent that it is possible to do that. Of course, the bigger the market that we have through export sales the easier it will be for us to bring that about. It is one of the very great tragedies that the defence of this country has been completely reduced to impotence through diminished defence financial votes under this Labor Government and through extremely poor leadership from defence Ministers. One of the real tragedies, quite apart from the resignation rate and all the rest of it, is that we have no reserve weapons, ammunition and stores in this country that we will need in an emergency. In fact, we do not even have enough weapons for training in many cases. I would instance the fitting of the Pave-Tack to the F111s. We do not have any GBU15s, which is the precision guided munition that has been designed to optimise the Pave-Tack. For a small country like Australia, we have to go down a high technology path to get the force multiplier effect that high technology brings to give us, as a small nation, a credible Defence Force. We just do not have any reserve weapons stock to train with, let alone use in an emergency. The development of our own industries within Australia is crucial if we are going to overcome those difficulties.

The third Bill before us is the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1988. My understanding is that the Senate has agreed to delete the reference to sugar. I will have quite a bit to say about sugar in what I think is the proper place for a debate on that, which is the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) which, I am assured, will come on for debate after the Senate inquiry. This final Bill before us contains a number of amendments including seven schedules to the Customs Tariff Act 1987. The amendments to schedules 1 and 2 deal with walnuts, large machines, deerskin leather garments and paper cutting machines. Schedule 3 deals with the import embargo on certain raw and refined sugar, which we will deal with later when the Senate inquiry report is considered. Importantly, it deals with the reduction of duty rate applicable to kerosene for use in aircraft. The other schedules relate to various imports which are technical matters that I do not propose to discuss this afternoon.

I want to say a few words about the removal of the excise duty on avtur. This is one of the great mistakes that this Government has made in its management of aviation in Australia. For some years now, we have had the user pays doctrine applying in aviation. No other section of the Australian community is subject to the user pays principle. Within the transport field, the road transport users-the people driving all those semi-trailers around Australia-however much they might complain about what they are paying for diesel fuel, road tax and road licences, do not have to meet full cost recovery.

A member of the Australian Democrats pointed out earlier in the year that there was, through the courtesy of the Australian taxpayer, an effective subsidy of, I think, about $30,000 or $40,000 a year on each prime mover and semi-trailer. No other area of Government activity in the Australian community-education, health and all the other services that the Government provides-is subjected to the user pays principle. This is quite properly so because there is a wider community benefit. After all, the reason why we pay personal income tax and company tax and why the Government raises taxation generally is to pay for services that it provides that have a community benefit as opposed to a personal benefit.

I argue very strongly that the aviation industry definitely provides a community benefit. It is not confined to those people who fly between Sydney and Melbourne every day to clinch big business deals. The benefits relate to the whole community. Nevertheless, putting that aside, we have the user pays doctrine with 100 per cent cost recovery applied to the aviation industry. The aviation industry is prepared to accept that.

Up until the introduction of the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) and the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) those costs were recovered in a number of ways by the former Department of Civil Aviation. This Government set up the Bosch Independent Inquiry into Aviation Cost Recovery two or three years ago. The Bosch Committee recommended that, provided efficiencies were introduced into the administration of the Department, it would be correct to go for 100 per cent cost recovery from the aviation industry within five years. This Government, in true style and in its rapacious way, did nothing to correct, one iota, the inefficiencies. It went to 107 per cent cost recovery within 14 months of receiving the Bosch report-a pretty fair achievement. There were a few cries from the aviation industry. Nevertheless, the aviation industry accepted that. One of the ways this was done was by putting an excise levy on fuel: avgas, the petroleum used in reciprocating engines, and avtur, used in jet and prop jet aircraft.

I am glad that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) has come in here because, as Minister for Transport and Communications, he would have had a hand in it. This Government, in a burst of ideological insanity, decided that it would transfer the whole of the aviation world off budget because it was all too hard for the Government to manage. In this ideological purity concept, it would have no part of collecting any levy through avtur or avgas for the CAA or the FAC. The consequence of that is the reason why we have this inquiry today before the Senate into the organisation and management of the CAA and the FAC. The whole of the aviation industry is now in revolt. That Committee has received 99 submissions. This is one of the biggest responses to a public advertisement that any committee of the Parliament has ever had and reflects the great unrest in the community. The whole of the economic base on which cost recovery was grounded has been cut from underneath it.

It is not correct for the Government to claim that, because the CAA and the FAC are statutory authorities, they cannot collect the money; of course they can. They are collecting billions of dollars through personal tax and other levies which they are paying to the State governments. It is quite competent for the Government, without perjuring one iota of its ideological purity, to go back to collecting avtur and avgas levies. The industry will support these imposts.

If one believes in the false ideology of the user pays doctrine, the levy on fuel is the fairest way of doing it. If one does not fly, one does not use the facilities and one does not burn fuel. If one does fly, one does burn fuel. There is a direct relationship between the user and the charge. The great difficulty with the user pays doctrine is that organisations such as the CAA and the FAC have direct access to the cheque books of users. It is all very well to say that if one uses something one should pay for it. But, in the aviation industry, the users-the people who own and operate aircraft or use air services-are never consulted by the FAC or the CAA in any meaningful way as to what they require.

There is now a great imbalance because the great airfield developments at the primary city airports are a consequence of the operation of civil transport passenger aircraft. For safe operations, those facilities are required. The greatest amount of flying in Australia-three or four times or maybe 10 times the number of hours and traffic-is done by the general aviation sector. The general aviation sector does not need the massive facilities that we must have for commercial airline traffic. Under the present system the general aviation sector is being taxed increasingly unfairly to support facilities that it does not need. Most importantly it has no say in whether it needs them.

I come back to the virtue of the fuel tax. It is a direct user pays system. If one flies, one pays. If one stays on the ground, one does not pay at all. Of course, if a plane is sitting on the ground, it is not costing anyone anything for services. The other great advantage of it is that there is no cost to the Government. We do not need Customs officers and bureaucrats because the oil companies supply the fuel. They pump it in; they do the invoicing. At the end of the month, they pay the Government whatever the levy is for the amount of fuel they have sold. There are no administrative costs to government. There are no bad debts. More than anything else, I emphasise that this concept is accepted by the industry. The way the Government has gone back to the old system of eliminating the levy on fuel, which was so efficient in paying for the aviation services in this country, is one of the elements I find objectionable about this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise as the Australian Democrats spokesperson on defence to address only one of the three Bills-the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1988-that we are debating cognately. Honourable senators will be aware that this Government seeks to implement its new policy in relation to military exports through this Bill. Indeed, clause 8 of that Bill is the instrument of the Government's intention to become one of the grubby producers and exporters of arms and join a select club of countries that choose to use arms exports, as Senator MacGibbon said, to seek certain economic advantage. To our way of thinking that is a little bit along the same lines as saying, `There's money to be made from the export of heroin. Why don't we get into that business. In fact, why don't we treble or quadruple the number of acres in Tasmania where we are currently growing poppies to produce heroin for medical use?'.

SPEECH.PARA: That same rationale and mentality are applied by this Bill to our entry into the arms race. We might as well say, `Let's be producers and exporters of drugs as well because it will put money into our depleted coffers'. Indeed, the Australian Democrats are disgusted by the Government's position in relation to the production and export of arms which it will attempt to implement through clause 8 of the Bill. We believe that it appears to have no ethical basis whatsoever. In a previous debate on an urgency motion several weeks ago, we stated that it stands in absolute contradiction to the statements made by the Government in global forums in relation to arms production and exports.

Australia has made many statements recently in the United Nations and elsewhere, calling for the curtailment of the international arms trade. In those statements it has acknowledged the link between military expenditure and social hardship, particularly in developing countries. In fact, it has urged nations to embrace non-military approaches to guaranteeing their security. Of course, those statements completely contradict the principles which the Government has enunciated as its new policy on military production and export. Despite this, the Government has now announced a policy of targeting developing countries for arms sales; a policy of reducing controls on the sale of Australian arms and commercial explosives; a policy of defining whole categories of products and services as defensive, irrespective of the military position of the purchasing country; and a policy of making the presumption that we will export to any country to which our allies export and that exports to our allies will be unrestricted.

The Democrats are disgusted by the Government's stand on this issue. We will push for parliamentary scrutiny of Australian arms exports. Details of military exports are currently not reported to Parliament. We will push that the necessity for approvals for arms exports be the subject of joint decisions by the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Above all, we will seek that these departments implement the completely new policy that the paramount consideration in Australian military exports be an ethical one rather than the current, purely mercenary one. I will focus specifically on clause 8 of one of the three Bills before us because it is the instrument by which the Government intends to implement its new policy; a policy which contradicts and compromises numerous recent Government statements in United Nations for a policy which defines whole categories of exported goods differently from the way in which they have been defined previously.

The specific provisions of clause 8 of the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill warrant our attention. We argue that the clause cannot be assessed in isolation from the regulations which will use the power that it creates. In other words, the Senate is being asked to make judgments about the implications of the clause without having any insight into the nature of the regulations which will be the instrument of its application.

The Senate may not agree with the Government's definition, which is not yet clear, of lethal non-military goods. We already know that the Government is having great difficulty in arriving at such definitions. We argue that clause 8 of the Bill opens the door to the export of social violence through the use of firearms by private individuals. The Bill increases the risk that Australian arms and explosives will reach the black market and become available for non-government terrorism, particularly when one considers that real controls over re-export or unforeseen use are non-existent. It creates a power, which the Government already exercises, by allowing Customs to approve small shipments of sporting firearms to specified countries. Clause 8 creates a false illusion of parliamentary control. Its inclusion in an omnibus Bill is a cynical attempt to minimise the political damage associated with legislation that enacts the Government's policy of arms production and export.

One can only wonder at the position in which Australia's new Ambassador for Disarmament, Mr David Rees, finds himself when he is confronted with a Government policy which flies in the face of statements made by his predecessor in overseas forums in recent times. One would anticipate, therefore, that in future the Foreign Minister will be unable to make such statements in international forums. Let me refer to some of those recent statements by our previous Ambassador for Disarmament, Mr Richard Butler. It is an interesting contrast that the title includes the word `Disarmament' yet this piece of legislation will put us into the club of countries that produce and export arms. He stated:

It is becoming clearer than ever before that excessive outlays on military goods weakens national economies and distorts wider patterns of economic cooperation and potential beneficial interdependence. The disturbing factor has been the nature and growth in international arms transfers, with the consequent negative impact on regional security situations and the potential for improvement in the standards of living.

We constantly hear the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) refer to the need for us to be vigilant about security in our region, yet the very processes that are enabled by one specific clause in this piece of legislation allows us to proceed along lines of action which our former Ambassador for Disarmament says render our region insecure and run contrary to our efforts in relation to the development and promotion of economic cooperation. It is interesting to look at statements that have been made by a former Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Bill Hayden. He said:

Arms transfers must not become a new cash crop. It should be recognised, especially by those whose development needs are great, that the purchase of arms is at the cost of the purchasers of the investment goods essential to the creation of employment and economic growth.

In other words, he is saying that if one encourages underdeveloped countries to expend their limited resources on arms one is discouraging them from expending those limited resources on far more valid requirements. This was stated by a recent Minister for Foreign Affairs. Yet the Government of the day, several months after those statements were made, is using one of the three pieces of legislation before us today as the means of implementation of policies which are contrary to those enunciated by the former Minister for Foreign Affairs.

What is the current system? Let us see how it will be varied by clause 8 of the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1988. Under section 112 of the Customs Act 1901 the customs Minister can make regulations to prohibit the export of goods from Australia. Those regulations can allow for export licences or permissions to be granted, made subject to conditions, varied or revoked. A licence allows for exports by its holder, over a specified period; permission applies to a particular shipment only. A subsequent shipment of the same goods can only take place if permission has been given anew. So they are very exclusive provisions. In fact, they are provisions which were designed to ensure that Australians are inhibited in their ability to take part in the sort of activity that is being promoted by the new policy-namely, the production and export of arms.

What are the effects, therefore, of the proposed changes. The Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill, which was introduced by the Hon. Barry Jones in the other House on 7 November, includes a specific clause, clause 8, which of course throws all that aside and enables, surreptitiously, the Minister for Defence to issue regulations which allow us to become the producers and exporters of arms, despite the quotations I have given from our Ambassador for Disarmament and our Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade.

The remainder of the Bill relates to the duty on beer, the duty-free status of goods from Christmas Island, Customs offences, and excise on government instrumentalities. Hidden in that Bill relating to beer, exports from Christmas Island, et cetera, is this clause which is the legislative base upon which the Minister, under regulation, can create possibly the most abhorrent industry that Australia could become involved in. Clause 8 allows the Minister for Defence to suspend arms export licences and permissions if he or she judges that they will be `contrary to the national interests'. What an extraordinary phrase under which to hide or legitimise this process. Licences to export arms to country A can be suspended if `a situation' in that country means that the exports will threaten Australia's interests. It can also be applied to countries B and C if there is a `reasonable likelihood' that goods exported to B and C will then be re-exported to A, et cetera. But regulations to be issued after the Bill passes will give the Minister for Defence the power to issue export licences for potentially `lethal non-military goods' such as sporting firearms and commercial explosives. According to the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones), each such export currently requires case by case ministerial permission. However, there are anomalies built into the provisions of those regulations. Even though Minister Jones claims that the Minister for Defence currently vets each proposal to export lethal non-military goods, an instruction issued by the capital procurement organisation in 1985 claims otherwise. The instruction, for use by departmental officers, states:

. . . commercial explosives, sporting firearms, and ammunition . . . is not normally subject to export control as applied to defence arms and ammunition. Controllers of Customs are authorised to permit export of such items except to certain specified countries.

If this is true, Minister Jones has inadvertently misled Parliament, and the Bill is giving the Defence Minister a power he already exercises. In a phone conversation in November 1988 Olin (Aust) Ltd-the Winchester Division-said that it seeks ministerial approval for each shipment of firearms except where five or less are being shipped, and in such cases Customs is authorised to let them through to approved destinations. In other words, it is only a matter of how the things are packaged as to whether they can be legally exported under the provision of the regulations.

Customs is now consulting Defence and other departments about new regulations which will follow this legislation. It appears that those regulations will purge all non-lethal goods from schedule 13, hence from export controls-presumably including training equipment, communication equipment, uniforms, et cetera. It appears that those regulations will divide schedule 13 into two parts, with part 1 containing lethal military goods and part 2 containing lethal non-military goods. It appears that those regulations will allow the Minister for Defence to issue export licences for goods in part 2, with goods in part 1 still requiring shipment-by-shipment permission.

In essence, the Australian Democrats say that clause 8 of the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 is, in fact, the instrument by which the Government will be committing this nation, through regulations of the Minister for Defence, to the club that produces and exports goods overseas, in the pursuit essentially of very limited economic returns, which flies in the face of statements made by our Ambassador for Disarmament, our Ministers for Foreign Affairs and our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)-as he did recently on his visit to India-in relation to the impact of the production and export of goods on underdeveloped countries. In fact, the Democrats say that the Government has been fundamentally hypocritical in its position in that it is trotting around the world saying that it is prepared to lead disarmament discussions focusing on chemical arms, and it is making statements and pontificating about the need for limiting the sale and transfer of arms from one country to another, particularly between underdeveloped countries, yet it is hiding and burying within an omnibus package of legislation, which is currently before the Senate, the powers by which it intends to pursue the production and export of arms. We say that that is not only being logically contradictory but also is unethical and hypocritical. We oppose clause 8 of the Bill. If clause 8 is not struck from the Bill, we will be opposing the whole of the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1988.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

I am very disappointed in Senator Boswell's contribution, in the sense that he used this debate on customs legislation to canvass his views on assistance to the sugar industry. He mentioned that the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology is undertaking an inquiry into assistance to the sugar industry. It was Senator Boswell, on 14 December last year, who proposed that the Committee conduct that inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: I am a member of that Committee, as you are, Mr Acting Deputy President. The Committee has been working long and hard to come to grips with that industry and to come to an understanding of it-particularly for my own part, as a Western Australian senator, because it is an industry which has no impact on or connection with my home State. We have worked very long and hard to reach an understanding of the problems besetting that industry and problems that may occur if the Government's plans for deregulation go through. I recognise Senator Boswell's interest in the industry and I take no umbrage at his expressing that interest. But during the time the Committee has been working and investigating, he has not seen fit to inform the Committee of his views on assistance to the industry. From his contribution this morning, he obviously holds fairly strong views; but even though he felt the need for the Committee to inquire into the assistance, he did not feel it important enough that he should express his views to the Committee so that it might in turn take his views into consideration when formulating a final recommendation to the Parliament and to the Minister.

Senator Boswell had ample opportunity to do so. He was fully aware that the Committee was undertaking this investigation. He has been in contact with the Secretariat of the Committee. He has actually attended one public hearing of the Committee-the hearing during the last sitting of the Parliament three or four weeks ago when the Committee heard evidence from the Minister. He did not attend any of the public hearings that we conducted on two separate visits to Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. We are debating certain matters dealing with Customs legislation. Not once has Senator McKiernan bothered to address himself to any of the Bills that are before the chamber. If he wishes to get into a disputation with Senator Boswell, there are plenty of opportunities for him to do so during adjournment debates and at other times. But he is required by the Standing Orders to relate his remarks to the Customs and Excise Bills that are before us. In terms of talking about what Senator Boswell may or may not have done in relation to a Senate committee inquiry, I fail to see the relevance to the particular legislation which is before the chamber. If Senator Boswell was allowed to make remarks which, in Senator McKiernan's view, were not germane to the Bill, that is a matter Senator McKiernan should have taken up at the time with the then Acting Deputy President.
—I think Senator Puplick has raised a valid point of order. I would ask Senator McKiernan to relate his remarks to the Bill.

—I will, Mr Acting Deputy President, and I take Senator Puplick's point. I was otherwise engaged in my office when Senator Boswell was speaking. I will relate my remarks to the legislation that is before the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 3) deals with the sugar industry and I am particularly speaking about assistance to that industry. I do not want to go into the fine detail about what my views are in terms of the protection to the sugar industry because I have not yet finally formulated them. I have not done so because I am a member of the Senate standing committee which is currently--

TALK.START.PARA: —They have not given you your instructions-that is why.

—That committee is currently examining assistance to the sugar industry. I have taken on board Senator Puplick's point that we have not been given our riding instructions. I reject the inference that he has made by way of interjection. The Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology is made up of eight members-four Government members under the chairmanship of Senator Childs, Senator Brownhill from the National Party of Australia, two Liberal Party of Australia members and an Australian Democrat. So the membership covers a broad spectrum of political party representation. I think you would agree, Mr Acting Deputy President, that members of the Committee have worked very well and have cooperated together despite the differences of ideology that exist.

SPEECH.PARA: I had intended to speak for only a couple of minutes merely to make a point on this very important piece of legislation that is before the chamber. I wanted to express disappointment that Senator Boswell did not see fit to inform the Committee of his views. He did not see fit to put those views before the Committee that is examining, of his volition, a very important reference.

But more importantly-and I express this fear to the Senate-I think Senator Boswell's actions this morning make a farce of the Senate committee system. Senators who serve on a variety of committees are all proud of the committee system. Our Committee is due to report on the first sitting day next month. This is only a few short weeks away. We are working desperately hard to finalise our report to meet the deadline which was imposed by Senator Boswell's motion to refer this matter to our Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —By the chamber.

—I am sorry-it was imposed by the chamber. He has not bothered to give us a submission, to let the Committee know his views. Yet, he canvassed those very same views during debate on an important piece of legislation, notwithstanding the fact that his comments were not relevant. I am disappointed. I think we will have to work very hard in the future if we are to protect the committee system of the Senate. We have to be aware that there is a need to protect the committee system. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I intend to address my remarks in this debate to the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 and the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1988. Specifically, I want to deal with three aspects of those Bills: the question of warrants, the question of inland freight and the question of penalties. Firstly, there is a great concern within the Opposition parties about the question of warrants. There is a concern that the power being given to Custom's officers is an infringement of civil liberties and, indeed, that this is setting a new precedent which outstrips powers that are given, perhaps, in respect of more serious areas.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the proposed legislation, although justices of the peace have been excluded from the definition of `magistrate', magistrates are still empowered to give warrants to enable officers to enter premises and to search for documents. It is proposed that their warrants be given by telephone. There is precedent for telephone warrants under the Telecommunications (Interception) Act and the National Crimes Authority legislation. But in both those cases the telephone warrants are required to be given by a judge, and not by a magistrate.

The Australian Customs Service says that it needs speedy and easy access to warrants and, therefore, it needs to have telephone access to a magistrate. However, I do not find that argument convincing. I would have thought that this would leave the way open for fishing expeditions to be conducted. There are no safeguards. Even if the occupier is cooperative with the agent and says, `Look, these are the documents that you wish to have', there is no restraint upon the agent saying, `Well, I think there are more, you have not given them all to me, and I propose to search for them'. The Law Council of Australia is very concerned about this initiative. I think it is a very serious matter which the Government ought to reconsider.

On the question of penalties, although the three-year retrospective period during which records can be overseen and penalties imposed has been brought down to one year, many concerns still remain. The requirement that documents have to be maintained for five years does not seem to be in line with the proposal to reduce the review period to one year. But we are more concerned about proposed new sections 243t and 234d of the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987. It is interesting to note that although one of the provisions is supposed to deal with matters that are more serious than the other, the penalty in what is seen to be the lesser category can in fact end up being greater than the penalty imposed under the so-called more serious provision. Proposed new section 243t, which uses the words, `knowingly, recklessly or otherwise', and attempts to impose a strict liability, provides for a penalty of $20, or twice the difference of the duty paid and payable, but has no limit at all. I heard Senator Coulter in his address deal with this question. He simply thought that if an importer were dealing with a large amount of goods of considerable value, that therefore somehow imposed a greater duty of care. He argued that the need for accuracy was greater simply because the value of goods was greater. I did not really find much logic in that argument.

We are also concerned about the way in which penalties seem to be dealt with-indeed, this applies to much of the rest of the legislation-in that the expertise of the people who draft taxation legislation seems to have been borrowed. With 84 discretions in the legislation, we are again seeing the law rendered more and more uncertain. The Australian Taxation Office takes the view of shifting the onus of proof to the taxpayer and these pieces of legislation are again using that technique of shifting the onus. The method of saying that one can be liable without intent is a very serious innovation in this area of the law.

I want to deal with the question of inland freight and the intent of the Government to clarify what is meant by value. The Customs (Valuations) Amendment Bill 1981, which was introduced by the Fraser Government, specifically omitted any inland freight or inland insurance unless they were paid or payable directly or indirectly by the purchaser to or for the benefit of the vendor. The intention of that legislation was quite clear. It was a specific interpretation by the then Government of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade definition of values set out in the multilateral code of conduct entitled Agreement on Implementation of Article 7 of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. A paper produced by the then Government stated:
The Code seeks to achieve its main aim by basing the Customs value (value for duty) on imported goods as far as possible on the transaction value of the goods'.
There was no uncertainty about the intent of the law. Article 1 of the code of conduct describes the transaction value as:
The price actually paid or payable for the goods when sold for export to the country of importation adjusted in accordance with the provisions of Article 8'.

Article 8 makes it clear that the matter of the inclusion or exclusion from the Customs value of freight, insurance and other associated charges is entirely a decision for the signatory country itself, depending on the manner in which the goods were sold and the country's national legislation.

The Government, in its present legislation, takes advantage of that article in dealing with `other associated charges' when it specifically exempts advertising and warranty costs from dutiable value. It is quite at liberty to do so with regard to inland freight as well. But it is simply not true to claim that the Government has introduced this provision on the basis that it is complying with the GATT agreement. In 1981, when the legislation was framed, the then Government said quite specifically that Australian authorities had canvassed the community and for many reasons, including the enormous increase in protection that would result if a c.i.f. system were adopted, it decided to exclude freight costs. So the intention of the law has been quite clear.

When the Australian Customs Service began to examine this situation in 1986, it started to talk about abuses of the system by people who were trying to avoid paying duty which they properly ought to pay. But to say that people abused the inland freight exemption is to besmirch the reputation of companies which do use it in a bona fide way. Indeed, if the law goes through as it is presently proposed, we could very well see large increases in manufacturing costs.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., under sessional order the Senate will now proceed to matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Smoking is one of the major health issues of our time. Indeed, the United States Surgeon General, Dr Koop, has announced the goal of making the United States of America a smoke-free society by the year 2000. In his most recent report he points out that biomedical researchers, physicians and public health authorities in more than 80 countries have generated over 50,000 studies on smoking and health. About 2,000 more are added every year. The overwhelming majority of these studies conclude that cigarette smoking is either a contributing or primary cause of illness or death. Dr Koop says that while the major emphasis to date has been on research into the health risks of people who smoke-that is, mainstream smoking-the dangers of `sidestream' smoking-that is, cigarette smoke that is inhaled by non-smokers-have been increasingly documented.
—Passive smoking.

—That is right. Presently in the United States there are 53 million smokers and some interesting research has pointed out the types of costs to that society. In particular, Larry White points out in his book entitled Merchants of Death, that five health economists led by Dr Dorothy Rice of the University of California at San Francisco made an estimate that the cost of cigarette smoking to the United States was $53.7 billion in health care costs and income lost by smokers. Direct medical costs for smokers were found to be $23.3 billion more than for non-smokers. Those costs included hospital and nursing care outlays, doctors bills and drug charges. Salary losses attributable to smoking by people who were sick with smoke related diseases totalled $9.3 billion and lifetime earning loss was put at $21.1 billion. The authors of that study said:

SPEECH.PARA: A total of 270,269 deaths in 1980 were due to smoking, resulting in 3.9 million person years lost.
They go on to say:

Our estimates are conservative for several reasons. We have not taken into account the adverse affects of passive smoking, risks of abortions, stillbirths and neo-natal deaths, or deaths under age 20 that might be associated with smoking.
Other estimates of the costs have put this exercise far higher.

In terms of the Australian material there was an interesting study released in October 1987 by the Health Department of Western Australia indicated that the costs to Australia were of the order of $2.5 billion dollars a year. The study by the Department's epidemiological branch concentrated on 1984 data for which death and hospital material were readily available from all States. There were 19,000 deaths attributable to smoking. The total cost, as I said, was $2.5 billion nationally, of which New South Wales contributed $941m, Victoria $708m, Queensland $411m, and so on. Direct health costs were put at $877m a year Australia wide.

A study undertaking by Kate McAllister of the Victorian Smoking and Health Project found that it was difficult to do a cost-benefit analysis because of the lack of data but stated that many points were clear: first, smoking results in productivity losses; secondly, there are hospital costs; and thirdly, deaths are the major cost of smoking. It is extraordinary that, whereas each year in Australia smoking is responsible for between 16,000 to 19,000 deaths, alcohol is the cause of about 3,000 deaths and all other drugs, both illegal and prescribed, are the cause of less than 1,000 deaths, the hypocrisy in the community still allows advertising for these lethal drugs.

The survey found that smoking caused productivity losses of about $670m. It put direct hospital or medical costs at $276m. Other costs, such as fire damage, which were directly attributable to smoking amounted to $95m. Anti-smoking education cost $8m. These costs are on the loss side. What about the benefits to society? As recently as this morning, the Tobacco Institute of Australia was talking about the enormous benefits to the revenue that flow from the tobacco industry, somehow or other suggesting that this was a reason for the industry being allowed to continue. Presumably, the amount of revenue would be greater if all of the drug industries were allowed to advertise their products.

The problem here, of course, is that there is a great deal of conflicting evidence. The Tobacco Institute, for example, makes outrageous claims with regard to the number of jobs that have been created-it started at 30,000 and I think this morning a figure of something like 68,000 was mentioned. In terms of a more reasonable estimate, I think that the figure would have to be far lower. McAllister was able to pinpoint only 5,244 people directly employed in the industry at the end of 1988. But, of course, one must in fairness say that there are downstream jobs, certainly in terms of distribution and in the retail sector. At the end of the exercise McAllister found that there is a monetary benefit of some $1.4 billion as against the cost of something like $1.1 billion. However, in that study no account was taken of the types of non-monetary losses, such as losses that result from death. But, in any event, it seems to me quite extraordinary that we should have now got ourselves into a situation where, on the one hand, we are able to contemplate allowing the advertising of two legal drugs-that is, tobacco and alcohol-to continue although they are responsible for the deaths each year of over 20,000 Australians, and yet, on the other hand, we not only ban the advertising of other drugs but declare them illegal.

I believe that while one can certainly point, as was done in a recent document, to the links between alcohol and crime, there is no conclusive evidence that the advertising of alcohol necessarily increases the number of consumers. Likewise, it is somewhat difficult to get conclusive evidence with regard to tobacco. But I believe that in making it permissible to advertise those two drugs, we are in fact creating an environment in which people will believe that by consuming drugs they will become richer, healthier, happier or whatever else. I would include in this category not only tobacco and alcohol but all sorts of other drugs. For example, people are told that if they pop a few dieting pills they will suddenly become attractive on the beach; if they take some other drug they will suddenly overcome a problem and be able to work twice as fast. In other words, we allow advertising which suggests directly to the community that popping a pill is a way of overcoming a problem. We are then sanctimonious about the fact that our young people-and it is largely our young people-become addicted to lethal drugs such as speed, crack-thank goodness at the moment there is very little of this drug, but it is starting to come in-and heroin, which is the mainstay of illegal drugs in this country. I believe that at some stage the community really has to confront this issue. I do not believe that it is any longer reasonable or permissible for us to allow tobacco and alcohol advertising.

I am particularly concerned about the shift in the consumption of tobacco. While there has been a drop in consumption overall, unfortunately the female consumption rate has risen dramatically, particularly amongst young women. An extremely interesting study entitled What will we tell the public, deals with cigarette smoking advertising by Australian magazines. The nine publications surveyed were the Women's Weekly, Cleo, Cosmopolitan, Family Circle, People, Women's Day, New Idea, Playboy and Penthouse. Two publications which are not advertisers of cigarettes-that is, Reader's Digest and Dolly-were surveyed. The survey found that of the 11 magazines five did not run feature articles on smoking. In other words, they did not publish articles putting an opposing case. Of the 10 articles in the remaining magazines, only two articles could, in any circumstance, be classified as anti-smoking. The remaining eight articles out of the 10 were either `pro-smoking'-that is, either generally favourable to smoking and its proponents-or `not anti-smoking', that is, non-committal, neutral or equivocal. Reader's Digest, on the other hand, which does not take cigarette advertising, ran five articles during the same period advertising the dangers of smoking. I think this certainly puts this publication in the category of the most responsible of the magazines.

I am worried because the vast bulk of this material is, in fact, in women's magazines. I think it is not beyond the wit of anybody to work out that the increase in smoking and, in fact, the increase in the consumption of alcohol by young women might be traced to the influence of these magazines and the way they tend to present information as distinct from the way they present their advertising. The report concluded:

Australian readers of magazines, young and old, deserve to be given the full information on this clear and present danger of cigarette smoking, but under current conditions they are likely to receive very little . . . The challenge for Australian magazines, particularly women's magazines, is to face up to this issue conscientiously. If they can find a way of giving due attention to the health aspects of cigarette smoking, they can have a major impact on the well-being and survival of millions of Australians.

I believe that if those magazines wish to be held to be responsible, they ought to be involved in this vital campaign. We have to do all that we can in terms of this pernicious drug, tobacco, which has dramatic and terrible effects on our society every year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to give to the Senate a brief report on the recent Inter-Parliamentary Union (IPU) delegation to Budapest, of which I was a member. That delegation was led by Mr Tom Uren. The deputy leader was Mr Roger Shipton and the other members were Steve Dubois, Michael Cobb and Senator Walters. The IPU visit to Budapest was interesting enough in itself, particularly for a person like me who had not been to eastern Europe before. On some other occasion I will say something about my impressions of my visit to eastern Europe, to the changes that I think are occurring in Hungary and to the palpable nature of those changes. Even a visitor like me could hardly fail to notice at least some emerging optimism for the future of that country by its people. I suppose that was best evidenced by a demonstration on the 15 March, a very important day for Hungarian people. It was reported in the newspapers that over 500,000 Hungarians marched and demonstrated on that day for the changes I think that they would like to see happening in Hungary. I also had the opportunity to visit Prague and I will say a few words about that shortly. Again, I would like to compare and contrast the impressions that I got from visiting Hungary and Czechoslovakia.

SPEECH.PARA: In particular I want to thank those people who assisted the delegation. We were ably assisted by Mr Fred Peppinck from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade; Mr Rob Diamond from the Senate, who was Secretary to the delegation; and Mr Russell Howard who came from the Australian Embassy in Vienna to provide assistance. As well as that we were assisted by Mr Townsend, our Ambassador in Hungary. I also enjoyed the assistance of our ambassadorial people in both Prague and Vienna.

On the Sunday before the conference started I was able to attend the meeting of the IPU women. Women are now turning up to the IPU conference in ever increasing numbers and it was interesting to hear the history of the emergence of an informal women's committee that is associated with the IPU. I cannot tell the Senate how many women were delegates to the IPU, but some 60 or so attended the meeting on that Sunday. I think there is the prospect of considerable interest in issues of particular concern to women and of the women's perspective on all issues being debated at the IPU. I would say, though, that it is very rare for the same delegates from countries to attend different IPU meetings. So the IPU and delegates have to contend with the challenge of dealing with a lack of continuity.

I had the opportunity to speak at the conference on item 5 entitled `The protection of the rights of children'. I want to take the opportunity to read my speech today into the Senate. Dying children seem not to be the same worry as pollution of the air, water and land and other questions of the environment or the recent worldwide interest in protecting our ozone layer. Is this because dead children are bio-degradable and if not renewable, at least easily replaced? For many years now international forums like the League of Nations, the United Nations, the IPU and others, have addressed the rights of the child. Thousands of words have been written and many resolutions passed, yet children throughout the world still starve to death each year, sleep with no coverings or shelter, have no education, cannot read or write, suffer awful ill-health, disease and deformity and have a limited life expectancy and very limited opportunity. While clearly the facts and figures vary from country to country, no-one and no one country can take comfort in his or her own country's record. There is room for improvement across the world in all countries.

In my own country, Australia, the infant mortality and the under-five child mortality rate is very low but these figures mask the Aboriginal figures which are quite unacceptably high. Recent figures show that Aboriginal babies were five times more likely to die at birth than non-Aboriginal Australians. To its credit, Australia not only recognises the problem-it acknowledges it and is addressing it. A recent government document Women's Work reports the extensive consultation by and with Aboriginal women around Australia and includes recommendations for addressing not only children's health but also women's health so necessary for children's health. As well our Prime Minister, Mr Bob Hawke, has set as a goal for Australia the challenge that no child shall live in poverty by 1990 and we have committed dollars and programs to that goal. Each year in our world 500,000 women die from childbirth and related maternal causes. Each year in our world over 13 million children under five die of starvation and easily preventable causes. Nothing exotic kills them, simply appalling priorities of governments that spend hugely on arms and minutely on food supplies, food production and basic health care and education.

Page 18 of the recent United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) publication, The State of the World's Children, contains a chart showing that the developing world spends approximately 30 per cent more on the military than on health and education combined and that recent cuts in spending have fallen more heavily on health and education than on the military. The source for that is from the World Development report 1988, World Bank, Washington D.C.

The deaths of 500,000 women each year is not only an appalling loss of human life; it also leaves over one million children motherless. I do not believe that we can go on ignoring or disregarding such horrific statistics, reflecting as they do such human misery, pain and loss; nor can we salve our consciences or justify our concern by updating the statistics each year. This data is a measure of our failure to this point and our appalling priorities but it is also the base and the basis for future action. When we add these figures to the latest estimate of the numbers of people who are absolutely poor, now totalling over one billion men, women and children, that future action is huge, daunting and imperative.

However, the changing arms build-up and some lessening of regional tensions may make possible the transfer of dollars from arms to assistance. The following statement is made at page 69 of the UNICEF 1989 report:

The transfer of only 5 per cent of today's total military spending of over one trillion dollars a year by developing in industrialised countries could release the 50 billion dollars a year that would be enough to overcome the worst aspects of absolute poverty on this planet by the year 2000.
Further, the World Bank President, Barber Conable, said in September 1988:

Poverty on today's scale prevents a billion people from having even having minimally acceptable standards of living. to allow every fifth human being on our planet to suffer such an existence is a moral outrage. It is more: it is bad economics, a terrible waste of previous development resources..
Now that there is a clear understanding of the dollar costs of this poverty and death, perhaps we can hope for action.

I said at the outset that many words have been written and many proper attitudes expressed. None of them has fed the starving. No longer can we afford the comfort and complacency of correct moral attitudes. I challenge every country here present to return to the eighty-second IPU conference in London later this year with the hard evidence of budgetary commitments to health and education for our children, preferably by taking from defence budgets. Let us return in this centenary year of the IPU with the news that commitment to our children is in dollars, not words. We do not have to wait for the adoption of the draft convention by the United Nations General Assembly; we can begin by anticipating it.

Another important, indeed vital, way that this problem of absolute poverty can be addressed is to involve women in the process. At every stage-at the local level, district and state levels, country and international forums-women must be heard. They have a particular need and a special contribution to make towards the solution. Often they are not able to contribute because of insufficient education or opportunity, often because of persistent and pervasive sexism and discrimination. In turning our attention to children, let us not use this as an excuse to forget or ignore the continuing struggle for women and women's rights. And let us acknowledge that much of the suffering and injustice experienced by our children is directly due to the suffering and injustice experienced by our women, closed out of any real opportunities to contribute to their communities or manage their own lives.

I am impressed by world action that has been mobilised so quickly along with the huge commitment of dollars to combat the acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS). The same mobilisation of a worldwide campaign, backed by adequate funds from both domestic budgets of member states, especially defence budgets, and aid allocations, to reduce maternal mortality, would have a dramatic effect not only on women but also on the world's children. It would lend substance to our recommendations. Some say we must hasten slowly but we were not slow to respond to the AIDS problem. I want to know that our commitment to the weak and the poor and hungry at least matches our commitment to the rich and the powerful.

I want to raise one point about the rights of children in the United Nations (UN) draft convention. Article 4, headed `Non discrimination', refers to the state's obligation to protect children from any form of discrimination. The obligation of the states in this matter should cover all concerns about discrimination as it affects children. However, I am concerned that still in this world being born a girl is often a serious disadvantage. I know of no justifiable reason to support any discrimination against our girls, where they be denied food, or even given less; where they are not able to expect an education at all or a comparable education; where they cannot expect to read or to grow up and to vote; and where they can expect to work harder at a younger age and for less pay or none. If article 4 addresses protection from these and all other discrimination for our daughters-our girls-then my concern is needless. If not, then it will need amendment to address discrimination within the family or within a culture.

I acknowledge the efforts over the years of men and women who have fought for these same issues against far greater odds and hardships, whether of distance, ignorance or lack of support and finance. In urging a new focus on an immediate world campaign for women and children I believe we can solve the problem and provide a memorial for those who have battled before us.
That was the contribution I would have made if I had had sufficient time. I made most of it at the IPU but the IPU is fraught with the challenge of many speakers and a very tight time constraint.

I wish to make a few points in my closing remarks about the opportunity I had to visit Prague and meet there a very splendid man, Father Vaclav Maly. He is a human rights worker and I benefited very much from meeting with him and talking with him over about four hours about the challenge of human rights facing Czechoslovakian people. Indeed I raised yesterday in the Senate the name of a person he brought to my attention, and I hope that that person, and all those others currently languishing in gaol, still many of them without trial, can be summarily dealt with in Czechoslovakia. As I said earlier, though, my impression of Czechoslovakia was that one would not have the same optimism as one might have about Hungary, and I think that was reflected somewhat in the people that I saw and met in Prague.

I did want to mention Father Maly. I think he is one of those countless people around the world who could be called unsung heroes or heroines. He has already done time in gaol in defence of human rights and I would be concerned if my mentioning his name in this Parliament should in any way be held to account against him or further disadvantage his campaign for human rights, along with the campaign of all those other people who are championing the cause of human rights in Czechoslovakia. I made the point to him that in some ways, though, he is lucky; his issue is very clear. Human rights in Czechoslovakia is a black and white issue.

I appreciate that many people in this country have their own struggle for human rights. I am referring to the domestic violence problem in this country. In April we have a campaign against domestic violence in this country, and I hope as a result of our campaign against domestic violence we will see a different focus on the rights of women in this country. In some ways, women who live in a domestically violent situation have their own struggle for human rights. They live, if you like, in a gaol; they may not speak freely; they do not have access to the same opportunities of income or education; they are not unlike the victims of the infringement of human rights in Czechoslovakia. But because they are living in a so-called free society their human rights are often missed or overlooked. It is sometimes said that a man's home is his castle and that of course he is free to do what he likes within the castle. I think one of the challenges for our society, particularly associated with the campaign against domestic violence, is the taking of the civil liberties and human rights arguments inside the walls of the castle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will be aware that this is the fifth occasion on which I have risen in the debate on matters of public interest to draw the Senate's attention to dissatisfactions in the Australian community in relation to banking. On previous occasions I have taken the opportunity to table sworn statements or affidavits or other documents which I had hoped would have attracted the attention of honourable senators as proof and evidence of the fact that we indeed have a crisis in our community. However, I am forming the opinion that perhaps those tabled documents have not been perused by many of my colleagues. I am drawn to that opinion by the contributions that were made in yesterday's debate on my proposition to refer this whole question, this crisis-this national crisis, as I see it-to a Senate standing committee. That proposition was rejected by the combined vote of the Government and the Opposition. I believe that that will be a judgment which they will return to later as a bad judgment of what the feeling of the Australian people is about the crisis of confidence that is occurring in banking.

SPEECH.PARA: I am about to seek leave to table a further six affidavits in relation to the allegations of malpractice and corruption which I have been putting forward on behalf of in excess of 100 constituents now who have approached me on this matter. As I have said on a number of occasions, I now have in excess of 150 files in which people have made very serious allegations about banking practices. I have previously tabled 27 affidavits which have cited 35 cases. I have attempted to place before honourable senators a cross-section of cases ranging from those affecting millionaires down to ordinary battlers. Those further six affidavits will extend upon that sample. I hope that my colleagues will have sufficient time to peruse them, to see the dimensions of the problem and the nature of the problem that I am attempting to alert them too. I seek leave to table those documents.

TALK.START.PARA: — (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)-Is leave granted?
—If I could have a look at those affidavits while Senator McLean is speaking, I will indicate at the end of his speech.
—Senator McLean can raise the matter again at the end of his speech.

—In the remaining minutes I would like to draw the Senate's attention to a matter which I raised at a press conference on Monday in the context of banking. On Monday, I alerted the public and, therefore, the Senate informally or indirectly to the fact that there have been opinions of senior lawyers, respected QCs and others, that there are anomalies within the taxation practices of banks whereby they are in fact in breach of the Income Tax Assessment Act by collecting withholding tax in relation to some foreign currency borrowings that are backed by mortgages. I was alerted by senior lawyers to this illegality which is being practised by some banks. They attended the press conference with me. We, in fact, presented the proposition publicly and I will seek leave shortly to table, for the perusal of the Senate, legal opinion to the effect that some banks are acting illegally within the Income Tax Assessment Act. I will simply explain what is occurring.
