SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators will be aware that between 1984 and 1985 approximately 1,500 Australians borrowed foreign currency and, as a result, with the movement of the exchange rates against them, they incurred great financial loss. Many of them have subsequently become bankrupt. This was known as the foreign currency loans or the Swiss bank fiasco and is acknowledged by banks themselves as having been an extremely unfortunate development on the banking scene. In that process of obtaining foreign currency loans, many of the loans were secured by mortgage. I am advised by legal advisers that somewhere in the vicinity of 90 per cent of such loans were secured by mortgage.

The minimum loan that was normally advanced by banks who were acting as agents for the foreign lenders was in the order of half a million dollars. Because the loans were being made by overseas agencies, usually Swiss banks, and because they were being made through Australian banks, who were acting as their agents, to Australians, who were the borrowers, those loans incurred withholding tax in the order of 10 per cent. Those taxes were paid, so there was no question of taxes being avoided-the taxes were in fact paid by the banks as the agents of the foreign lenders-but almost all banks passed that withholding tax on to the borrower. The legal advice I have, and it is from eminent Queen's Counsel, is that is prohibited under section 261 (1) of the Income Tax Assessment Act in the case where those loans are secured by mortgage.

The proposition that has been advanced to me by the Queen's Counsel who has advised me in this matter is that those taxes will have to be repaid to the borrowers. The taxes will not be collected back from the Department of Taxation because they are legitimate taxes. It was the passing on that was illegal and it will now be the responsibility of the banks to reimburse those payments to the borrowers. That is the legal opinion that has been offered to me. That is a very complex and very complicated development in this process. If we do the sums they are quite extraordinary. If we take a borrower who borrowed the minimum sum of half a million dollars and paid the overseas lenders the average interest of 6 per cent, which was the going rate, and who then paid 10 per cent of that in withholding tax. We are talking about their having paid to the bank $32,000 that they should not have paid and which they should now be entitled to receive back.

The majority of those people are now bankrupt. Many of them have been sold out by the banks because of the circumstances into which they were drawn. They are people to whom $32,000-I do not say that $32,000 is not a significant sum to almost anybody-is particularly significant. So we have a potentially very complicated situation on our hands. It is complicated because of, it is argued to me at least, the breach of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

Some borrowings were in the order of millions, and I know of one borrowing that was $14m. We are therefore looking at withholding tax on that loan, of 28 times $32,000. I have not done that sum but it is a very substantial sum of money. When we consider that 1,500 people made such borrowings, we see that banks have in fact collected and passed onto the Australian Taxation Office, which should have received it, withholding tax possibly in the order of hundreds of millions of dollars. Those hundreds of millions of dollars should in fact be passed back to borrowers who should not have been required to pay it.

I am simply alerting the Senate to the fact that legal counsel, eminent Queen's Counsel, has drawn my attention-I in turn am now drawing the Senate's attention-to the fact that this set of circumstances exists. It has been disputed by the Australian Bankers Association which has a separate body of legal opinion which says that this was all legal. But that will probably now have to be resolved in a court of law and the courts will have to determine which of these two interpretations prevails. Yet again, and I will be doing this on a regular basis, I will continue to build what I believe is an irrefutable case for there to be eventually some form of public inquiry into not only the specific aspects of banking which I have cited over a period of five consecutive weeks but also into numerous other aspects of banking.

As was pointed out in the debate that occurred here yesterday, there has been no inquiry into banking in this country since 1935 and yet we have had profound developments which necessitate such a requirement. I have cited only two of them on previous occasions. Since the deregulation of banking in 1985 onwards, there have been extraordinary changes in the ethos of banking in this country. Of course, there have been dramatic increases in the levels of personal indebtedness. Some authorities say that personal indebtedness has increased sevenfold in the last decade. We all know that we are all in debt-there are very few people who are not in debt up to their necks. Most of us incur some degree of substantial indebtedness regularly. In the case of many families, that indebtedness is in excess of $100,000 which renders them extremely vulnerable because debt means vulnerability and vulnerability means opportunity for sharp operators. Whether those sharp operators are corrupt bank officers or corrupt officers within finance companies is beside the point. The generalisation still stands that most Australians are vulnerable because of indebtedness and that vulnerability presents opportunity to ruthless operators.

The proposition I have been advancing to the Senate and which was denied yesterday-unwisely I believe-by the Government, with the support of the Opposition, is that this problem has reached crisis proportions and warrants a major public inquiry. Today I wish to table further evidence of that. I therefore seek the leave of the Senate to table six affidavits in relation to the matters of Patricia Poulos v. Elders Pacific Ltd; Barbara Hunt v. Westpac; Adrian William Batten v. the Commonwealth Bank; Dr Terry Gavagan v. the Commonwealth Bank; Mr David Wallander v. Westpac and Edward Bride v. Elders and the Australian Bank Ltd. When I say `versus', these cases are not all in courts, some of them have not been to court; I am simply saying that there is a point of dispute between the parties named and that these are sworn affidavits in relation to those disputes.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I further seek leave to table a copy of the legal advice which was given to me in relation to the question of withholding tax.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take the opportunity afforded by this debate on matters of public interest to refer to certain issues in the pharmaceutical benefits area. Increasingly, we are finding interference by the bureaucracy in the prescribing of medication by a doctor for a patient. At the same time we are also seeing the withdrawal of certain medication and its replacement with substitutes. This is causing a lot of concern to patients, particularly the elderly. They become stabilised on certain drugs and prescriptions and become used to the size, colour and shape of pills. I wonder what has happened to the previous bipartisan policy on prescription medication.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the past year in particular, especially since the establishment of the super Department of Community Services and Health, we have seen an increasing socialisation of medicine, particularly prescription medication. I, for one, have had numerous letters, visits and telephone calls from people who have for long periods received medication under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS) and who now have to be told that, due to the deliberate policy of the Hawke Labor Government, certain drugs have been removed from the PBS scheme. Dr Blewett and his Minister responsible for the scheme, Mr Staples, have repeatedly said-and quite erroneously-that no medication has been removed from availability; only brand names have been restricted. This is not the case as in several cases similar but not identical drugs have been removed from the PBS and only one drug for that complaint has been retained.

Recently, my colleague, Senator Reid, asked in this chamber whether or not people develop a psychological dependence on a brand name, apart from the physiological reliance on the drug itself. Senator Cook, the Minister who replied, gave this question a cursory dismissal. Perhaps Senator Cook's office has not been swamped, as have the offices of other honourable senators, with distressed people who have been taking a particular drug for sometimes up to 30 or 40 years, only to find that it is now not currently available. Elderly people, in particular, have become very concerned when drug A, which they have been taking twice daily for many years and which they know is a little round white tablet, suddenly becomes drug B which is orange and, say, diamond-shaped.

Although five years on, George Orwell's book 1984 seems to be the manual used by the Federal Government in relation to health policy. What we are witnessing at the present time is an insidious restriction on the confidentiality of the patient-doctor-pharmacist relationship. It is not for Dr Blewett, Mr Staples or anyone in the Commonwealth bureaucracy to decide which medication suits a particular individual. This must solely be the responsibility of the particular patient's doctor. Each person is different in physical, psychological and physiological characteristics and the short-sighted restriction on the PBS schedule does not take into account this individuality. I think it is appropriate in the light of the growing and very strongly justified concern in the community that these grave concerns be raised in this debate and in this chamber here today.

Tasmanian pharmacists recently held a strike-the first ever in the history of the profession-and every chemist shop in the State, except I think four, closed to deliver a very strong protest message to Dr Blewett and to Mr Staples. I strongly implore the Government to heed the thousands of pharmacists and doctors, and the millions of Australians who are dependent on regular medication and restore the removed drugs to the PBS list.

Pharmacists have another cause for concern. This Government encouraged pharmacists around Australia to move into expensive computer networks in order to raise their productivity. There is nothing wrong with that; it is something that we all endorse. This challenge was taken up by the pharmacists themselves. But we now find that they have been penalised by this Government, by the tribunal, with a reduction in their national health scheme (NHS) fee. This reduction is quite contrary to the philosophy in the second-tier wage negotiations which were supposed to reward productivity gains. I ask the question: why has a segment of Australian society, the pharmaceutical chemists, been singled out for special treatment-not for an increase but actually for a reduction in their fee? This is quite a discriminatory act by the Government on a segment of society that performs a valuable service. I deplore the action of the Government on two scores-the removal of certain prescribed drugs from the list and its reduction of the NHS fee.
Sitting suspended from 1.36 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Has Mr John Friedrich been given access to any discussions, briefings or documents by any officer of the Attorney-General's Department, particularly those who might be responsible for anti-terrorist planning or operations or the protection of vital installations or VIPs? If so, what briefings, discussions or documents were they, who provided access, when and for what purpose, and on whose authority was such access granted?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am unable to say whether an officer of the Attorney-General's Department was involved in briefing Mr Friedrich in relation to the matters canvassed in Senator Newman's question which, I take it, basically concerns counter-terrorism measures. The fact is that the document which the Opposition alleges was found in the possession of the former Director of the National Safety Council of Australia (NSCA) appears to be part of a report prepared by Mr Holdich, the Deputy Secretary to the Department of the Special Minister of State, of a review of counter-terrorism activities in Australia. Senators will know that Mr Mick Young, who was then Special Minister of State, on 17 October made a ministerial statement in the Parliament in which he gave an extensive summary of the contents of that report. Indeed, quite fortuitously, in answer to a question from Senator Archer earlier this week, I drew on the recommendations of that report in regard to uniform policing at airports. If that report, which was allegedly found on the desk of the former Director of the NSCA, is the report to which Senator Newman is referring or has in mind and is of that status, it was not a classified operational manual, but a report relating to the structure and a review of counter-terrorist capabilities in Australia. Those arrangements were reviewed and certain recommendations were made.

ANSWER.PARA: That is the only document I know of which might in any way fill the description indicated in Senator Newman's question. I have no reason to believe that that particular document was made available to Mr Friedrich from an officer of the Attorney-General's Department. Clearly, I am unable to know how that document came to be on Mr Friedrich's desk at this time. The document was widely circulated and I think that it has already been indicated that it was made available to many Commonwealth and State agencies which had a need to know about its findings.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I put a supplementary question to the Minister. Will he undertake to look at the detail of my question, and if he has any reason to amplify his answer to bring it to the Senate's attention as soon as possible?
—Of course I will do that.

—Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce aware of media reports that the South Australian based car manufacturer, Mitsubishi Motors Australia Ltd, has won lucrative new export orders in Japan worth $52m? Will the Minister comment on the export performance of the automotive industry under the car plan?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The export performance under the car plan is not particularly good, but it is a lot better than it used to be. I welcome the announcement in Adelaide by Mitsubishi about its export contracts for automotive components to Japan which are projected to be worth $14m a year. That development is of importance to South Australia and Senator Foreman takes a keen interest in the industrial welfare of the State from which he comes. South Australia has established a significant automotive manufacturing base with two car manufacturing plants and a number of major export oriented automotive component producers. The new Mitsubishi component contract involved the creation of some 70 new jobs and an investment of $2.5m. The Magna plant has a stated aim of achieving export of $100m by 1992. That is consistent with the objectives of the passenger motor vehicle plan.

ANSWER.PARA: I would make the point that automotive exports by the industry have doubled since the plan was introduced in 1985. This success is expected to continue with projected exports of $1.2 billion by 1992-I add that those are the industry projections, not mine. The importance of these exports is that they are evidence that the industry is adopting a more refreshing approach to pursuing export markets. This is helping the structural change process within the industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs to the instructions that he issued to his Department on 6 March to cease accepting requests for immigration review panel proceedings and collection of the $240 fee as at the close of business on 7 March. Will the Minister explain why the Government did not take heed earlier of the Opposition's warning in 1987 that supporting legislation was needed to give the $240 fee a legal basis? What guarantees will the Minister give to those people whose eligibility to apply for a review expires between 8 March and whenever he finally brings in the regulations designed to legitimise the $240 fee the Department has imposed on review applications that their rights of appeal will be extended? Finally, does the Minister not agree that the Department has acted improperly in continuing to collect the fee between 13 December 1988 and 7 March 1989 while being fully aware of the Attorney-General's advice that he had grave doubts about the legality of the fee?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that rather than 6 March I would have taken 3 March as the date when I expressed my view in this chamber, and I expected as of that moment that that should be the cut-off point. That was not necessarily translated into action, but I take that as the cut-off point when I answered a question in this chamber-not 6 March. It means that any fee collected between 3 March and 7 March will be refunded on my direction. I believe that the moment one makes a public announcement on these things one intends them to come in from that moment. It reinforces Senator Short's point a little further-it is not just from 6 to 7 March but it will be from 3 March.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Short said that the Opposition had warned the Government. There is, of course, a difference between statutory fees and administrative fees, and that is where the distinction is. There was not a view in my Department, nor by me as Minister, that these fees were illegal in any sense, until I received correspondence from the Attorney- General on 12 December-correspondence that I initiated on 24 October. I remind Senator Short that we had a legal opinion from Michael Black, QC-certainly no dummy if he is on the short list any time High Court appointments are in the air-that argued that the fee was legal. Other legal opinions were sought later.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have now decided that you were wrong on that decision.

—I have made no such decision. At no stage have I ever stated that the fee is unlawful. People have quoted me to that effect, inaccurately. The most substantive next piece of legal opinion came between the time that I wrote to the Attorney-General and before the Attorney-General wrote back to me. So I do not believe that my attitude or that of my Department was unreasonable at any stage up until 12 December, when we were entitled to believe that the legal opinion by Michael Black, QC, was sustainable. Probably the key argument thereafter is: What is our view from 12 December onwards? That is something I will be discussing in just on an hour's time with the Ombudsman. So I will not canvass that matter further here.

ANSWER.PARA: Generally, I might point out also the positive side of the review fee; it is not all negative. The time for review has been reduced from an average of 12 months to five months. The massive backlog has been reduced. In summary, in answer to the three parts of the honourable senator's question, no, in that period up until 12 December we did not have the opinion that the fee was illegal. Secondly, anyone who paid the fee between 3 March and 7 March certainly will have it refunded, because I regard my public announcement as the cut-off point. In respect of any other matters relating to that, I will obviously be making some public pronouncement after having discussed the matter with the Ombudsman today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Without pushing further on the matters the Minister will discuss with the Ombudsman, I again ask the second part of my question, which I do not think the Minister touched on. What guarantees will he give to those people whose eligibility to apply for a review expires between 8 March and whenever he brings in his regulations? What guarantees will he give that those people's rights of appeal, which would otherwise have expired, will be extended?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Short for his supplementary question. I am sorry I overlooked that matter as I was trying to deal with the other ones. I can give an absolute guarantee that appeal rights will be in no way prejudiced. As Senator Short will realise, 90 days are given in which to appeal against a primary decision. That twilight zone-the time from 3 March until the regulations come into effect, which will not be longer than a week away; it could be shorter because I have already signed them and they await only Executive Council approval-will not be taken into account. So it will not affect the 90 days. If the 90 days expire in that period between 3 March and whenever the regulations are finally ratified it will have no effect whatsoever; we will take that into account.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a report in the Brisbane Courier-Mail of Tuesday, 4 April, and several subsequent publications in print and electronic media, on the subject of a raid involving police and Customs officers on five premises in Brisbane relating to the importation of pornography? Did the raid lead to five men being interviewed in relation to paedophilia or child pornography? In view of the suggestion that Queensland State police, on political instructions, aborted the exercise and will proceed no further against some senior officials involved, including a very senior member of the National Party, will the Minister assure the Senate that any involvement in this matter by the Australian Customs Service will continue until the case is brought to its legal and logical conclusion?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question really relates to my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business. I am aware of the report to which Senator Jones referred. I understand from Customs that the Queensland police sexual offences squad made contact with Customs in Brisbane to seek its cooperation for a proposed joint operation involving imported child pornography. No elaboration was made at that time because of the sensitivity of the alleged targets, understood to be public figures. There was no suggestion of drug involvement.

ANSWER.PARA: On Monday, 3 April, Queensland police made arrangements to raid five targets, accompanied by Customs officers. The raid took place on a Monday night. Quantities of videos, books and other publications were seized from all five premises. Four persons were interviewed and released. The fifth person targeted was overseas. The Customs Service is currently examining the seized videos and publications to confirm whether they fall within the ambit of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulation 4a. After that examination has been completed, any action considered appropriate will be taken. Honourable senators may be assured that if any contravention is proven legal action will then proceed by way of summons.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I draw the Minister's attention to the report on the Science Show on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio on Saturday, 1 April, concerning at least one Japanese submarine sunk during World War II in Darwin waters. Is it a fact that the Commonwealth Government has forbidden diving on the submarine on the ground that it constitutes a Japanese war grave? Is it a fact that the submarine contains some 16 tonnes of mercury as ballast in its keel? Is it a fact that the mercury ballast of this type of submarine was normally contained in chamois leather bags? If so, is the mercury in these submarines contained only in leather bags? Is the Minister aware of the horrific consequences of mercury poisoning, as in the case of Minimata in Japan, when mercury enters the human food chain through marine organisms? Finally, what steps has the Government taken, or will the Government take, to prevent the leaking of this mercury, or mercury from other sunken submarines, into the surrounding waters?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the Science Show report. The submarine referred to is I-124, which I think as far back as 1977 was declared a historic wreck under the Historic Shipwrecks Act. It is a Japanese war grave and has been respected as such by the Australian Government. However, the question of mercury in the ballast is another matter. As yet we have been unable to ascertain all of the facts. I cannot confirm that mercury has been used as ballast in that submarine. I can say that it would not have been uncommon for that to have been the case, but it was not always the case in those submarines. So as yet we do not know.

ANSWER.PARA: Given that I do not know whether mercury was used as ballast in that ship, it follows that I do not know whether it was contained in leather bags or in some other way. That is something we are endeavouring to find out. The Japanese Embassy has undertaken to provide information on this as soon as possible, and my Department is gathering advice from the Australian War Memorial, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, the National Health and Medical Research Council, the Australian Government Analyst and the Northern Territory Department of Primary Production. There is now a restricted zone around the reef, so divers are being kept out. I undertake to inform Senator Sanders as soon as possible when the Japanese Embassy comes back with some harder information.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. What action will the Minister take if mercury has been used as ballast in the submarine? Can the Minister give us any information on that?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —If the Japanese Government advises that mercury was used as ballast and is therefore present we will take whatever steps are necessary to protect the environment. No doubt that would involve the removal of the mercury. I cannot say right now exactly how that would be done. Obviously that would have to be worked out at the time. But, if it is necessary, it will be done quickly.

—I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services in the wake of the Government decision about Wesley Vale, a decision for which I believe there was no alternative, given the serious nature of the expert advice about pollution of Bass Strait. I refer to the problem of excessive dependence on highly bleached paper, including by the Government, and the environmental consequences of chlorine discharge in the course of its manufacture. Does he agree that not all the paper we use needs to be whiter than white? Do manufacturers in Australia produce unbleached paper of suitable quality for general office use? Could it be made in sufficient quantity if the demand for it was created? Is recycled paper a feasible alternative for some of the Commonwealth's paper requirements? Finally, will the Minister discuss with the Minister for Administrative Services, in the interests of environmental safety, whether the Commonwealth, with its major purchasing power, could set an example by substituting at least some of its orders with ones for paper made by methods which are less polluting?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is true to say that the Government has followed a white paper policy over a number of years. I do not think it is a matter that the Government has yet concentrated on to the degree that Senator Coates would like. But as he has drawn it to my attention, I will certainly pass it on to the Minister for Administrative Services to get a full response. It is possible, as we already know, to substitute a whole variety of paper to get the unbleached results. These days toilet paper is unbleached. It is something we will have to look at seriously. I would have thought that, from a cost perspective, in the long term it would be a lot cheaper to use unbleached rather than bleached paper. It follows the old conundrum, as honourable senators know. Conservationists write to me about the misuse of various processes and another thousand trees have to be chopped down for them to do so. In this case I hope that will not be the case and that we can expedite this matter without a lot of correspondence. I will certainly draw all of this to the attention of the Minister for Administrative Services.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. I remind the Minister of my question to him on 12 October last year about the Government's decision to move the nutrition section of the Health Research and Services Division of the Department of Community Services and Health to another area and, as I said to him at the time, to reduce the section's scientific functions. Does the Minister recall that, having given two answers on that day, he returned to the Senate on 17 October with a prepared answer which, when it appeared in the daily edition of Hansard, contained the following words: `However, the scientific positions will be retained.' Is the Minister aware that in the weekly edition of Hansard these words, which were central to the question I asked him, have been deleted? Did the Minister, or any member of his staff acting on his authority, direct Hansard staff to alter the transcript of 17 October, thereby seriously altering the sense of his answer? If so, why was this done?

—I do not recall, but I accept Senator Reid's words for those dates and for the wording that she has referred to in her question. I probably have a major fault as a Minister in that I do not read the pinks.
—That is not your major problem; that is one of your problems.

—No, that is the major fault I have, Senator Chaney; otherwise I give a rather faultless performance. But I do not read the pinks and therefore I do not fiddle with the corrections. As the honourable senator has raised a specific point, which I accept is an important and serious one, as to what did happen, I will inquire whether there was any change and give her a fuller answer as soon as I have done so.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is the Minister aware that the Government has been criticised for not adopting a tighter monetary policy between the time of the stock market crash and April-May 1988? Is that criticism reasonable? What are the consequences for Australia of the current monetary policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the sort of criticism to which Senator Giles has referred. The publication of the December quarter national accounts this week did show very strong growth in private domestic demand in the second half of 1988, which has led to some commentators, with the benefit of perfect hindsight, arguing that the Government should have moved to tighten monetary policy much earlier than the autumn of last year.

ANSWER.PARA: I want to make three points about that. Firstly, hindsight is always the most valuable analytic tool in economics. The Government recognised earlier than most other governments that the stock market crash had not sparked off a major international recession, and therefore tightened monetary policy in the autumn of 1988 rather than the spring of 1988, as most other governments did. To argue that we should have done it earlier, I repeat, relies entirely on the wisdom of hindsight. On Tuesday morning of this week on the local Australian Broadcasting Corporation program John Howard was asked this question:
But isn't the real problem that everybody predicted, post the stock market crash, that growth wouldn't be as high as it is-the real problem is that we under-estimated growth?

Mr Howard did not give a straight answer to that question. But I can, however, refer to one fairly well-known economic and political commentator who wrote this on 28 October 1987, with his usual convictions or implicit assertions of infallibility:
It is true that the detailed consequences of recent events cannot yet be fully foreseen. Their general consequences, however, already are perfectly plain: 1988 now will see a world recession . . .
I repeat: 1988 now will see a world recession.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who wrote that?

—Senator Stone. It was published in the Australian of 29 October 1987. It ill becomes him, without any qualification at all, to say with absolute certainty, speaking ex cathedra as he normally does, `One thing is now perfectly plain, 1988 will see a world recession'. He of course was not alone in being wrong on that score. It ill becomes anybody with that sort of record to say, with the wisdom of hindsight, that the Government should have picked the direction in which something was moving six months before the Government did in fact pick that direction.

—My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the article in today's Canberra Times concerning public servants who have left the Public Service under the Government's early retirement package announced in January this year? Is it true that a public servant aged 54 with at least 20 years service could have received up to $170,000 more under the Government's one-off early retirement scheme than if he or she had retired at the age of 55 under the normal retirement benefits provisions? What is the maximum amount that a public servant can receive under the early retirement scheme? What safeguards has the Government taken to ensure that those beneficiaries are not merely re-employed later as consultants or in other ways?
—The question relates to a number of matters of detail and I will obtain an answer for the honourable senator as soon as possible.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. I refer the Minister to his public statements that the first responsibility of the National Energy Consultative Council (NECC) would be to consider the implications of the greenhouse effect on the Government's energy policy, and to examine how the greenhouse effect might alter demand for and supply of energy fuels. Is the Minister aware of the formation of the Hill River Power Development Co. by CRA Ltd and Barrack House Resources for the purpose of building a private coal fired power station? Is he also aware that the two companies involved have formed a special promotion unit to procure the necessary market for such a venture? Is the Minister aware that the coal fired power station proposal is based on mining coal from the Hill River area, better known by the Australian Academy of Science and the Western Australian Environmental Protection Authority as the proposed Mount Lesueur National Park, because it is the prime conservation area for terrestrial fauna of the northern sandplains? Can the Minister assure the chamber that this proposal, which poses major costs to conservation values in Western Australia, and the greenhouse effect in general, will be given high priority for examination by the National Energy Consultative Council? Finally, can the Minister assure the chamber that details of the process and the results of such an examination will be made available to conservation groups in Western Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to see that the honourable senator follows the National Energy Consultative Council report. It is true that, at its first meeting last year, we spent a long session on the greenhouse effect and, as a consequence, published a discussion paper on that subject, which I am happy to supply to the honourable senator. The Council undertook, through the States, to compile an inventory of measures being taken at State level to combat the greenhouse effect.

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware, not by official advice but through general publicity, that CRA proposes to develop a new coal fired power station in Western Australia as a private enterprise operation, and I understand that the State Energy Commission of Western Australia is open to such a development-it has not ruled the development out; in fact, it may have even encouraged it-and it proposes to do so to meet a rising demand for power in the State of Western Australia. As I recall, CRA is proposing a feasibility study which will include an examination of techniques of mining, of coal burning, of coal fired generation, a sociological and economic impact statement, an environmental impact statement and, I think, a regional study on the local economy as well. Those steps have been announced as steps to be taken in the lead-up to forming the final proposal. Again, that is not official advice; that is as I read my briefs on the matter.

In relation to the general comment the honourable senator has made about whether we will intervene in terms of the specific regional Mount Lesueur National Park, I have to say that yesterday in answer to a question from Senator Dunn I tried to make a distinction between Commonwealth and State powers on these things. There is a broader view that the Commonwealth has absolute powers. The Constitution suggests a contrary view. We do not. This type of operation is entirely State based and is not something over which the Commonwealth has any powers; therefore it is not for us to intervene and interfere with the States' obligations on that subject.

The final two questions asked whether we would take the matter up on the National Energy Consultative Council. I do not think it is appropriate to do so because it is entirely a State matter. The National Energy Consultative Council, as its name implies, is a body that looks at national energy policy. The States are represented on the Council but I think that the day the States all vote together that the Commonwealth shall take an interest in a peculiarly and uniquely State operation will be the day that Parliament House is clouded over as a squadron of pigs flies past.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer. I wonder whether, in the event of CRA and Barrack House Resources getting to the stage of building their coal fired power station, the matter will come back to the Minister's attention as a Federal matter if export licences are requested. Would it not be fair to these companies now to signal, in line with the Government's often stated policy to take into account possible problems in relation to the greenhouse effect, that such export licences would not in future be granted? Do I also take it that it is up to the State Ministers who are part of the National Energy Consultative Council to bring this forward to that Council on a State basis?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot imagine how anyone would apply for an export licence for a powerhouse. We do not export energy in that sense-unless it is argued that aluminium is frozen energy, but that is a different matter entirely. If the companies concerned were to export coal, obviously they would wish to apply for a coal export licence. In that case the matter would properly come before my colleague Mr Kerin for approval. The NECC is not a State ministerial representative body; it is a State departmental or operational representative body. As I say, I do not believe State Ministers would in any way approve of the Council dealing with a specific State matter, and I do not think it is appropriate that I initiate that either.

ANSWER.PARA: The final question refers to the greenhouse effect. I think it is drawing a long bow indeed to identify what is a prospective development as influencing the greenhouse effect when, as I have said in this chamber and elsewhere, the CO2 is only half the total number of greenhouse gases and the amount of CO2 contributed by coal fired power generation is a much smaller component of that and is not the main offender. It is drawing a long bow to focus all of that down on a specific project in Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Prime Minister to the Prime Minister's attempt to reopen the privatisation debate last month. Does the Minister agree with the Prime Minister's push to change the Labor Party's anti-privatisation policy before the next election, or does he believe that it is `absolute political suicide', to quote the reaction of the Federal Secretary of the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association, Mr Peter Robson, to the Prime Minister's proposal? Does the Government intend to convene an extraordinary national conference to reconsider the Labor Party's anti-privatisation as suggested by the Prime Minister? If so, how will the Government overcome the entrenched opposition to privatisation of the parliamentary left, which described Mr Hawke's reopening of the debate as `debilitating' and said, `We affirm our opposition to privatisation in all its forms'?
—I call on the Minister representing the Prime Minister in the Senate. Senator Button will answer those parts of the question with a ministerial component and not those of a party nature.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answering the question I should say that the question of privatisation-commercialisation, if I may use another term-or otherwise of various enterprises is shared across various portfolios in the Government, and different considerations apply to different government instrumentalities. For example, quite a few organisations within the Department of Defence, formerly statutory authorities of government, have been commercialised under the present Government. I think perhaps the most successful example of that would be the Williamstown Naval Dockyard, but there are others. One can go from portfolio to portfolio to see where, in appropriate circumstances, organisations previously fully in the public sector have been partly taken out of the public sector by the commercialisation or privatisation process.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not think the Prime Minister or anybody else in this Government believes in the sort of universal panacea view of privatisation which has been offered by Margaret Thatcher in Great Britain and served up from time to time by her ideological acolytes in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not like Walsh.

—Not like Walsh. I do not believe anybody in this Government thinks that public assets should be sold or flogged off in order to satisfy ongoing expenditure of the Government. I think the Government has to face up to the fact-any government does-that it is a question of how additional funds can be injected. This is particularly so in relation to the airlines because of their forward demands for puchasers of aircraft and so on.

ANSWER.PARA: Having said all that, I do not think I need to respond to the allegation by Peter Robson that any such suggestion would be `absolute political suicide'. In my portfolio, if I had accepted all Peter Robson's suggestions over the years, I would be long dead. I do not think it is necessary to accept that as a description of any consideration of these matters. In so far as there is any question of an extraordinary national conference or any- thing like that, that is a matter for the Australian Labor Party and not a matter for ministerial responsibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In his response, which I found not very definitive, the Minister indicated that we must face up to the facts. He cited the example of the airlines. The simple question I ask is this: Is privatisation, as we all know it and understand it, back on the Government's agenda as stated by the Prime Minister or not?

—Certainly my answer was correctly characterised as not being definitive. It was not intended to be definitive. In relation to the question of privatisation, as Senator Parer calls it, being back on the agenda, I thought my answer was pretty clear. It is not a question of putting a label on particular things and saying, `This is an intrinsic good in policy or economic terms'. It is a question of how we achieve particular results. I referred to the airlines because I simply wanted to make the point that a particular result has to be achieved there. It is the Government's responsibility to work out how to do it and we will discharge that in due course.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy confirm that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, stated at a press conference earlier this week that, if his legislation relating to the deregulation of the Australian Wheat Board does not pass both Houses of Parliament by the 30 June deadline, then the Government will not introduce new legislation to retain the Australian Wheat Board? Does he acknowledge that this will result in the Wheat Board having two years to wind up its operations, with growers probably receiving only 60 per cent of returns for their crops in the next year's first advance payment? Is this part of the Government's continuing negotiations with the Liberal Party on the coalition's package for deregulation of the industry? Finally, does the Minister believe that it is appropriate behaviour for a responsible government or a responsible opposition to hold a major Australian industry to ransom in this way?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know what Mr Kerin said at his press conference but I do know that the Act has expired, ever since World War II, every five years and is going to expire automatically if there is no replacement legislation. I do know, though, that Mr Kerin said in the House the other day that this issue has shown Mr Howard in his true colours-yellow for courage and white for the National Party. I do not know whether that helps Senator Powell in that part of her question.
—What is the colour for the Democrats?
—Any colour one cares to nominate at the time. On the subject of wheat deregulation, in one of this morning's papers I read:

ANSWER.PARA: Wheat is not a one-off problem for the Coalition. Traditionally, the Nats are socialists and similar situations will occur. The Liberals must establish the few really important principles now. Continual deregulation is one of these. If they cannot even hold the Nats to free-market principles when all they must do is allow Labor to do the deregulating, then they are not tough enough to deregulate the labour market.
Then the Coalition's fine policy is, as some fear, little more than wind.

It is easy to understand why Mr Howard does not want to divide the Coalition but he can't govern by appeasement. The price he would pay for inconsistency and lack of purpose will, in the end, be even higher than the cost of a row.

These words were uttered not by some Labor scribe but by John Hyde, a former member of the House of Representatives, an erstwhile soulmate of Senator Stone. I am not sure whether Senator Stone stands in exactly the same spot as Mr Hyde. As this debate unfolds I will be very pleased to see Senator Stone tacking his colours to the mast and sticking by his previous deregulatory comments as the senior coalition figure. Next Thursday the Government will introduce into the House of Representatives a Bill on deregulating the domestic wheat market.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you mean to say we will get a chance to see it?

—Members of the Opposition just have to wait a week and it will be there to see. That Bill will propose deregulating the domestic marketing arrangements for wheat in Australia. It will terminate the compulsory acquisition of crops and the administration of pricing arrangements. We believe it will create a more competitive domestic market. It will cause more market efficiencies and will ensure that returns to growers more accurately reflect the value of their product. As far as the international wheat market is concerned, we will not be removing the monopoly from the Australian Wheat Board (AWB) on milling and industrial wheat. That will be left intact, although feed wheat, which is internationally a different market, will be deregulated.

ANSWER.PARA: The Bill will provide a strengthening of the commercial capabilities of the Australian Wheat Board by allowing it to buy wheat for cash to trade in other grains and to operate more flexible pooling and payment arrangements. It will continue AWB control of exports of milling and industrial wheat. It will provide changes to the structure of the Board membership to assist its commercial competitiveness. There will be a Government guarantee on borrowings to fund initial advances for wheat being marketed through the Board's pooling operation to begin at 90 per cent of expected annual returns, phasing down to 80 per cent of expected annual returns over five years. There will be a Government guarantee of $100m to help finance the Board's commercial activity, the guarantee to be dependent on the industry introducing a levy to establish a wheat industry fund to help finance the Board's commercial activities.

I hope the Australian Democrats find it in their souls to support the Government on this matter. One of the positive arguments the Democrats have put forward in this debate has been to espouse the concerns of organic wheat growers. If we did not deregulate, organic wheat growers would be paying up to $60 per tonne extra for facilities that they cannot use because the storage facilities in this country classically contain some pesticides.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Can the Minister answer the question as to whether, if the legislation does not pass the Senate, further legislation to continue the operations of the Australian Wheat Board will or will not be introduced? Does he agree with the sentiments expressed by Senator Button in answer to the earlier question that questions of privatisation and deregulation should relate to achieving results and that the achievement of certain results is really what is before the Government? Can he confirm that surely the result that we are all after is the continuation of a viable wheat industry in this country, which would not be possible if, upon failure of the passage of that legislation, there were no continuing legislation for the Australian Wheat Board?
—Part of that supplementary question was a completely new question. I ask the Minister to answer only the supplementary question.

—Part of the supplementary question asks whether I agree with Senator Button. I always agree with Senator Button. Getting the best deal for growers is certainly a concern. Balancing that deal against the interests of the wider economy is also a concern. Senator Powell asks what will happen if the Bill expires. That is a speculative question. I am not prepared yet to concede that the Bill will be defeated in this chamber. I therefore do not want to speculate on what would happen if it were to be defeated. I note that Senator McGauran has succeeded in getting endorsement for position No. 4 on the Victorian Senate ticket, which seems to guarantee that the Bill may pass.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support seen the Australian Associated Press report of 5 April which indicates that the Chamber of Shipping has disclosed that more than $36m was lost in Australia's ports during the past month despite the Federal Government's summit of 1 March between itself, the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the waterfront unions and the Association of Employers of Waterside Labour? Did the summit achieve any solutions to overcome the constant delays, labour disputes and hold-ups in loading and off-loading cargo and containers, apart from lifting limits on overtime? Does the Government acknowledge that the continual chaos on our waterfront is an embarrassment to the export industries? Will the Minister undertake that the recommendations of the eagerly awaited report by the Inter-State Commission, now in the hands of the Government, will be implemented urgently so as to overcome the scandalous loss of income to the economy as well as excessive costs to companies involved in coastal transport and exporting?

—The Government frankly acknowledges that the waterfront is in need of reform. We have made it clear that that is very high on our micro-economic reform agenda. We have taken over a long period of time steps to develop, through appropriate consultative mechanisms, a strategy to handle the problem. That strategy, as developed by the Inter-State Commission, will be published very shortly. It will then be a matter, of course, for the relevant interested parties-business, trade unions and the Government itself-to consider in detail the strategy there outlined and to respond to it. I am not going to jump the gun on that, except to say that I think the elements of a solution are quite possibly at hand with this long awaited strategy. Certainly we will be making every endeavour to put in place reform of the waterfront which will make it impossible in the future to draw attention to the sorts of issues that Senator Panizza has been able to draw attention to today.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. In view of the announcement by the Vietnamese Government that it will withdraw all its troops from Kampuchea by September 1989, will the Government restore bilateral aid to Vietnam from September 1989, will the Australian Government establish some form of representation in Kampuchea from September 1989 and will the Australian Government respond favourably to any request to provide observers and/or a peacekeeping force to assist in the establishment of a united and peaceful Kampuchea?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government certainly welcomes the announcement yesterday that Vietnamese troops would be withdrawn from Cambodia by September 1989. We have consistently called for the withdrawal of all Vietnamese troops from that country as a necessary precondition for any settlement of the Cambodian problem, and we certainly hope that that withdrawal will be completed within the stated time frame. Of course, the announcement adds urgency to other aspects of the Cambodian problem, including the cessation of military assistance to the various Khmer factions. During my visit to east Asia earlier this year, I was assured that once all Vietnamese forces had been withdrawn from Cambodia military assistance to the factions would cease. I hope and expect that that will occur, not least because the statement makes clear that a Vietnamese return to Cambodia cannot be ruled out if that cessation of external support to the other factions does not occur.

ANSWER.PARA: The announcement also underlines the importance of agreement among the factions for a peaceful and durable internal settlement. In this respect, the Australian Government welcomes the apparent agreement between Prince Sihanouk and the People's Republic of Kampuchea's Prime Minister Hun Sen to meet again. I also understand that the four factions are expected to meet in Paris later this month. We all hope that significant progress can be achieved at these meetings.

The proposal to reactivate the 1954 International Control Commission, augmented by Indonesia as chairman of the Jakarta Informal Meeting or JIM process and a personal representative of the United Nations, is new. Australia welcomes this as a possible step towards finding a suitable international control mechanism to oversee the withdrawal of Vietnamese troops and prevent outside interference in Cambodian affairs. Whether the 1954 ICC model will prove to be the most satisfactory one for such a mechanism remains to be seen. One is entitled to be somewhat sceptical. The 1954 mechanism is not the most successful international exercise in averting violence that the world has seen. Nonetheless, it does provide a foundation on which further institutional arrangements could perhaps be developed. In that respect, Australia stands ready, as the Prime Minister and I have made clear on a number of occasions, to consider any requests that might be made for us to participate in some appropriate control mechanism.

As to the question of aid, once the terms of an overall settlement were agreed, I could certainly foresee a need for a coordinated international effort to provide reconstruction assistance to Cambodia. Australia would play its part in any such effort. We already provide aid for humanitarian purposes to the Cambodian people through multilateral agencies and through Australian non-government organisations, both inside Cambodia and in civilian camps on the Thai-Cambodian border.

The question of aid to Vietnam was specifically adverted to in Senator Schacht's question. The situation there is that, because of Vietnam's military occupation of Cambodia, bilateral assistance to Vietnam has been suspended since 1979, although some Australian aid is still delivered to Vietnam through multilateral agencies. We would certainly sympathetically consider the resumption of a program of bilateral aid when Vietnamese troops were withdrawn. A number of questions would need to be considered in that context, not only the question of the availability of money in our aid budget but also considerations, for example, as to whether Australian resumption of a full bilateral program might or might not compromise the achievement of an overall settlement if by that stage an overall settlement has not been accomplished. So those are matters that would have to be considered, but the withdrawal of Vietnamese troops would certainly trigger a reconsideration by Australia of its position on that subject.

The final question I was asked was about the diplomatic representation in Phnom Penh. That is a further issue which obviously arises in the context of the moves towards a settlement. Equally obviously, it is too soon today to define with any precision what would be the appropriate timing and level at which we should restore such representation. That very much depends on the character of the internal settlement that is reached, when it is reached, how and in what circumstances. All of those matters will be kept under close review.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. I note that in Senator Gareth Evans's answer he referred to Cambodia rather than Kampuchea. I am interested to know whether it is the official position of the Australian Government to refer in future to what has been called Kampuchea for some 15 years as Cambodia.

—I suppose this is essentially a matter of taste. Just about every publication one reads jumps backwards and forwards between the two terms. I take as my text Prince Sihanouk's recent pronouncement on the subject, which was to the effect that `Cambodge' was the appropriate expression when one was speaking in French, `Kampuchea' was the appropriate expression when one was speaking in Khmer and `Cambodia' was the appropriate expression when one was speaking in English.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. I have in my hand a large plastic imitation pharmaceutical capsule. Can the Minister please inform the Senate how much this absurd capsule, its contents and the postage cost in order to advise medical practitioners of what they already knew, namely, the withdrawal of certain drugs from the pharmaceutical benefits scheme?
—No, they did not.

—If the doctors that Senator Crowley knows did not know, then I am sorry if they have been out of touch and off this planet. In addition, how many of these capsules were sent? How many more are proposed to be sent? If it was necessary to forward such mundane advice, how much would it have cost for that advice to be sent in an envelope with a 39c postage stamp?

—The first part of the question was whether I can advise the Senate. Yes, I can advise the Senate-when I have consulted with the Minister for Community Services and Health. As for advising doctors on what they already know, I have a problem with that in that Senator Knowles may know and may have special psychological insight into what doctors, individually and collectively, already know.
—That was not part of my question.

—It was part of the question, and I will answer it. It may be inconvenient for the honourable senator to have an answer. I do not know what doctors already know, but I do know that the information that we forwarded to doctors was necessarily forwarded and was essential to the issue.

—Has the Minister for Finance seen press reports on demands by the Opposition parties to underwrite the value of wheat? Has any analysis of these demands been made? If so, will the Minister report to the Senate the cost to the Government if such underwriting demands were met?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last month the Leader of the Opposition guaranteed that the coalition would vote as one on wheat marketing legislation, in a display of leadership. The Liberals then of course let the National Party decide how to vote. The surrender to the National Party has of course been camouflaged by a series of demands but the Opposition Leader guarantees the coalition will vote together. The Liberals asked the National Party how to vote. That is leadership Howard style. It shows that nothing in the coalition's relationship has changed since the 1960s.

ANSWER.PARA: When are the Liberals going to wake up? The National Party has nowhere else to go. The Liberals do not have to keep surrendering to it and compromising what few principles they have of their own. They do not have to do it. Why are they so thick that they cannot see this?

TALK.START.PARA: —Imagine Thatcher putting up with the National Party.

—One could not imagine that. The sequence of demands made were either irrelevant, undeliverable or very expensive. The first demand is that the Opposition will support the legislation subject to progress being made in the deregulation in the transport handling, storage and waterfront areas. Most of those matters are under the control of a State government. The Commonwealth can deliver absolutely nothing on most of those matters. If Senator Boswell and Senator Stone are so keen on deregulation, why do they not get to work on the National Party Government in Queensland with its rail monopoly?

ANSWER.PARA: I was asked directly what was the likely cost of the Government caving in to the National Party's blackmail, to which the Liberal Party has already caved in. This cannot be assessed with any precision. But I can tell the Senate what the second demand for a 95 per cent underwriting would have cost in the 1986-87 wheat season, when the estimated returns on wheat were some $20 per tonne greater than the price which was ultimately likely to be realised. If those conditions were to be repeated the cost would be about $190m. That is the cost to the taxpayers if the Government were to cave in to the National Party's blackmail, to which the Liberal Party has already caved in.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FUNCTION FOR FRETILIN MOVEMENT: ATTENDANCE BY PRIME MINISTER

During my answer I said that Mr Snowdon and Senator Collins placed an advertisement in the Northern Territory News inviting anyone who was interested to attend the function. The mishap did not of course affect the list of more than 300 written invitees to which I referred yesterday but I would not wish to be accused of leaving any misleading impression whatsoever in the statement I gave yesterday.
—I was asked a question at Question Time today by Senator Reid about an alteration to Hansard. I can inform the Senate that I expect to be in a position tomorrow to answer that question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I was asked a question by Senator Patterson in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. I now have further details that I can give on that question asked by Senator Patterson. The answer to part one is yes. The answer to part two is yes.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to part three is: the comprehensive fee to cover pre-natal and post-natal care and the delivery of the baby was introduced on medical advice that it was in the best interests of both mother and child. It was unanimously recommended by the Medicare Benefits Advisory Committee, two of whose five members were senior nominees of the Australian Medical Association (AMA), after extensive consultation with the Royal Australian College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists and the Federal AMA Coordinating Committee of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists.

The answer to part four is: this Government never interferes with the clinical judgments made by any medical practitioner. The `all-inclusive' fee recommended by the Committee is designed to remove the financial incentives for `inappropriate use of discretionary obstetric procedures'; in other words, for unnecessary birth intervention such as surgical induction or caesarean section. Thus it certainly is the intention of the Federal Government to promote good medical practice.

The answer to part five is: the new fee level was achieved by adding the average of all the additional fees to the new fee and did not result in any savings to the Government. The new fee is considered fair and reasonable, with more complicated deliveries being compensated for by the higher average fee for less complicated cases. The Government makes no apologies for acting on the best medical advice available to reduce unnecessary intervention in what, as far as possible, should be the natural process of childbirth. For obstetricians to charge patients above the schedule fee is totally unreasonable, given that obstetricians' gross Medicare only earnings have increased by 30 per cent, to an average of $220,000, since 1984-85. This is in a period when average wage earners have been expected to show economic restraint. Consumers are placed in a difficult position by the often outrageous charging practices of many obstetricians. To avoid being faced with substantial out of pocket expenses, consumers should discuss the cost of treatment with their doctor and shop around for a different doctor if they are not satisfied.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL SAFETY COUNCIL OF AUSTRALIA: VICTORIAN DIVISION

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Chaney proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The need for the Government to appoint a Royal Commission, preferably in conjunction with the government of Victoria, to inquire into all aspects of the collapse of the Victorian Division of the National Safety Council of Australia with particular reference to that organisation's links and dealings with all government departments and authorities, including security and intelligence authorities.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —There would be little doubt around Australia that the collapse of the National Safety Council of Australia (NSCA) is a matter of considerable public importance. It is likely that many Australians would not have been aware of the significance of that organisation prior to its collapse over the recent dramatic weeks. But the collapse has been so dramatic and the ramifications of it so wide that I think it is fair to say that for the first time for a very long time there has been a substantial distraction from the economic woes of Australia and that, temporarily at least, people's attention was focused, not on our extraordinary and difficult international debt, not on the enormous economic risks facing us as a nation, but on what appears to be a massive series of failures on the part of governments and government agencies to find out what is going on and to understand what is happening in an organisation which is performing major functions in the Australian community.

SPEECH.PARA: I suspect that many observers were as surprised as I was to find out just how broad has been the work of the National Safety Council of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Victorian Division.
—The Victorian Division.
—It is worth emphasising.

—It is a point that I intend to make later. The Minister intervenes that it is the Victorian Division. That is an important intervention because, of course, the National Safety Council of Australia in other State divisions is principally concerned with the sort of work that the name implies-namely, the promotion of industrial and other safety. That work is continuing and it is work for which I have had high regard. Indeed, a few months ago at Harbour Lights Mining Ltd at Leonora, I presented a safety award to that mine, which had completed yet another year in absolute safety. That award was promoted by the National Safety Council. It is interesting that that positive side of its work, of course, received little or no publicity.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a collapse which has extraordinary wide ramifications. For a start, it is a major commercial collapse. In Victoria, a major State institution, the State Bank of Victoria, is involved. It is described in early reports as the largest single creditor, with the Victorian Division of the Safety Council owing it $103m in loans. But the liabilities extend interstate. The State Bank of South Australia is reported to have a $30m debt at risk and was responsible for appointing receivers to the Council. The Elders Finance Group Ltd is believed to have an exposure of $15m to $20m. So very substantial public bodies have committed very large amounts of funds to this organisation. Substantial commercial questions arise as to how those loans came to be made to an organisation which, clearly now, did not have the commercial capacity to deal with them-not in some minor way; not in the course of some gradual reduction in its earning capacity; it would appear that at no stage did the National Safety Council Victorian Division have the capacity to service the sorts of loans which were provided.

We have seen the involvement of State instrumentalities. Questions have been raised about the operations of the corporate affairs authorities in Victoria. Allegations have been made about the adequacy or otherwise of the audits which were carried out. I heard a very spirited defence of the audit by the accountants involved, who made the point that they had issued successive warnings about the accounts of the organisation and that no action had been taken by the Board. That leads us to say that questions arise about the liabilities of the Board. These are issues which may well have legal ramifications and which I suspect would not be a proper subject for debate in the Senate or, indeed, in the House of Representatives. I make the point, because it is relevant to this debate, that a series of areas is involved in this collapse-areas which in our view require very careful examination.

There is wide public interest in the fact that this organisation is concerned with essential humanitarian services. Again, it perhaps comes as a surprise to many observers to find that in a very substantial part of Australia essential search and rescue operations have been dependent upon the contracted services of this organisation, the Victorian Division of the National Safety Council, and that widespread rescue operations have been dependent upon its successful operation. We find that there is a defence component. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made one of his public relations trips to the north to visit Tindal. We are told that the operations at Tindal are in part dependent upon search and rescue facilities which are being provided by this same organisation. We find the involvement of security authorities at some point because complaints have been received. We find that the members of the organisation are able to move in and out of Australia under a special permit because of the humanitarian work that they do. Possible criminal charges are now involved, with the arrest of the missing principal.

I do not think one could quarrel that there has been the widest possible government involvement in this extraordinary organisation. When one looks at the spread of locations and functions, one finds that that is not surprising. We find that the organisation is engaged at Townsville in search and rescue, emergency medical evacuations, including in the South Pacific area, and in repatriation flights from Papua New Guinea. It is involved at Coolangatta in pilot training, a search and rescue base and medical evacuation operations. It is involved at Williamtown, Newcastle, in work with the Royal Australian Air Force and in search and rescue for post-assembly testing of the Black Hawk helicopter. It is involved in search and rescue training at Richmond, which is another Air Force base. It is involved in para-rescue; in Sydney, in the treatment of civilian and military personnel suffering from decompression problems. It is involved in the Illawarra and at West Sale with much the same list of functions, although it is also involved in those places with fire bombing, and it is involved in the servicing and manufacture of safety equipment. In the Latrobe Valley it is involved in search and rescue and aircraft maintenance; and so it goes on. It is involved in activities at Morwell, Welshpool, Melbourne, Benalla, Fiskville, Adelaide, Perth and Pearce in Western Australia, Darwin, Tindal, and so on. It is a most extraordinary national network of operations which is very much a matter of public interest.

In terms of Federal Government involvement, we really do not have any sort of exhaustive list of the extent to which the Commonwealth is involved, but we get some hint of the breadth of involvement from the Prime Minister's words yesterday when he said:

But I wrote on Monday to about seven or eight Ministers who could, in some way or another, through their departments or agencies for which they are responsible, have some connection with the NSC, and asked them to meet together and their Departments so that we can have a full understanding of what involvement there is at the national level with any of the operations of the NSC.

In other words, the Prime Minister has found it necessary to bring together seven or eight Ministers just to deal with Federal Government, and potential Federal Government, implications and involvement with this organisation. Again, if one wants an illustration of the depth as well as the breadth of Commonwealth concern and involvement, one need go no further than to look at what Ministers have said in the Senate when the matter was raised during Question Time on the first sitting day this week, Tuesday. Questions were asked by Senator Hill and Senator Short. Senator Hill raised with the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) the involvement of the National Crime Authority and the Australian Federal Police (AFP). It is worth reading the answer from the Minister. I say to the Minister that on this occasion I quote him, not to chastise him for his answer, but merely to show that his answer discloses the substantial involvement of Commonwealth authorities for which he is responsible. In response to Senator Hill, a Liberal senator from South Australia, Senator Tate replied that a series of allegations and complaints had been made to Commonwealth authorities. He referred to the involvement of the Australian Federal Police. I quote:

Those sorts of allegations were taken extremely seriously by the intelligence division of the AFP over the period October 1987 to March 1988 but nothing was found to substantiate those particular allegations.
He talked about possible fraud being alleged by Mr Alex MacArthur, a former Queensland director of the NSCA.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, of the Victorian Division. He was the Queensland manager of the Victorian Division.

—In Queensland. I thank the Minister. I am sure that that interjection will be recorded in Hansard. Senator Tate continued that the Australian Federal Police felt that the matter should be referred to the Victorian police if evidence of fraud were uncovered. We heard Senator Tate tell the Senate about the briefing of the Victorian police by Mr Max Ieise and the inquiries that were taking place. We heard of complaints to the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and of a meeting in February 1989, with documents being handed to ASIO and so on. When Senator Robert Ray was questioned by Senator Short, Senator Ray admitted:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . no evidence that Mr Friedrich was an Australian citizen. As I understand it, he was not on the electoral roll and did not have a driver's licence or a passport.

The implications of that are clear. We have a man who was involved in all sorts of activities, who we certainly know was driving and who was not involved, apparently, in any of the government processes.

TALK.START.PARA: —And he did not have his Australia Card.

—The Minister says that he did not have his Australia Card. So we can see from the Minister's confusion that we need an inquiry. He is not quite sure what citizens are required to have. My main concern, and the point I wish to make, is that there are a great range of Commonwealth agencies which have already been involved. We can see that the seven or eight Ministers who were written to by the Prime Minister would presumably have included the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), the Minister for Justice, the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West), the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis), probably the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), and who knows which others. At the State level there is the clear involvement of the State Attorney-General, the Treasury, the police, the health authorities and, again, probably others. The minimum facts that we face at the moment are that there have been very large commercial losses, essential services have been put at risk and there has been a failure to respond to alarms by both State and Federal governments when multiple agencies have had difficulties drawn to their attention. It is in those circumstances that the Opposition raises the need for the Government to appoint a royal commission, preferably in conjunction with the Government of Victoria, to inquire into these matters. We raise and assert this because we believe that it is the only effective means of unravelling the enormous problems which this collapse discloses. It is the only way that we are going to learn all the lessons that need to be learnt from it.
