SPEECH.PARA: We have already seen that the attempted activation of the Commonwealth Government's own agencies has been tried and has failed. The very people that the Prime Minister is now writing to have had these matters drawn to their attention and they have found nothing and, as a result, they have done nothing. We find that even Labor members of parliament are concerned at the capacity of any single agency, without an Australia-wide reach, getting to the bottom of this matter. We find, for example, that the Labor backbencher, Mr Peter Cleeland, who is Chairman of the parliamentary committee which oversees the National Crime Authority, tells the world that he is writing to Mr Lionel Bowen seeking an urgent meeting of the intergovernmental committee which refers operational cases to the NCA. What Mr Cleeland had to say is that the collapse had implications beyond Victoria, that the Victoria Police would have jurisdictional problems investigating its funding activities across State borders and that the NCA already had coercive powers and well-established experts capable of investigating the scam. They were Mr Cleeland's words, not mine. The key thing is that we are at present facing the prospect that there will be a series of individual, ad hoc inquiries into the involvement of individual agencies and departments in this matter when in truth what that almost guarantees is that each agency and department will seek to justify its position.

TALK.START.PARA: —They will pass the buck.

—Yes, they will pass the buck. It is of the nature of an inquiry of the sort which is being put in train by the Commonwealth Government that each agency will, as best it can, justify its previous behaviour and, in the absence of some overall examination of what has happened, there is a real risk that we will never unravel this matter properly and, even more importantly, we will not learn the necessary lessons to ensure that this sort of thing cannot happen again.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition's approach to these matters is quite clear. We do not believe that the best means of dealing with a serious and complex issue of this sort, which crosses Commonwealth and State jurisdictions and which deals with a whole lot of different areas and arms of government, is by some form of parliamentary inquiry. It may well be that in the end that will be the only option that we have left to us. But we would ask the Government to consider the proposition that the important thing is to have some objective inquiry-not a political inquiry-that can get through the complexity of this matter. It should not be fragmented where people have a vested interest in trying to ensure that the blame does not rest with them. The Opposition is perfectly prepared to support an inquiry by a parliamentary committee but, consistent with the view that we adopted with respect to the Murphy matter, we believe that there are more accurate and appropriate ways of going about this and that the Executive Government is peculiarly well placed to do it. We believe that the appropriate agency would be by way of a royal commission which could have the necessary overview to ensure that this matter is satisfactorily dealt with.

The alternative that the Government has to consider is that we send this matter to a parliamentary committee. As in other cases, if the Government will not act responsibly, we will act through the Parliament to do what we can. It is my understanding-and no doubt this will be made clear by the Australian Democrat speaker, Senator Macklin-that the Australian Democrats would be sympathetic to that approach. Our first priority, the first suggestion we make to the Government, is that it should appoint a royal commission. We believe that such a commission with its powers and with its non-political character, provided it has satisfactory terms of reference, is the best option for dealing with this matter in an orderly and satisfactory way. We will not tolerate a situation where the Government simply tries to disperse this matter by sending it off into eight, nine, 10 or a dozen ad hoc inquiries so that the matter is never properly dealt with. If the Government does not respond in a sensible and responsible way to our call for a royal commission, we stand ready to take the final step.

It really is a matter for the Government to consider what its real options are. It is not a realistic option for the Government to seek to bury this matter in the way that I think it is currently trying to do with letters from the Prime Minister to Ministers and a series of self-justifying reports from departments and agencies, many of which will presumably not be disclosed by this Government which shows far less enthusiasm for disclosure than it did when it was in Opposition. That is not a satisfactory outcome in this extraordinary and scandalous collapse of an organisation which was carrying out such important functions in Australia. The choices the Government have are these: it may have a royal commission with an appointment made by it and, we would hope, by the Victorian Government so that there is a full coverage of both Commonwealth and State issues; it can have a set of terms of reference which are set down by it but which will be regarded as satisfactory by the Opposition only if it enables the royal commissioner to inquire into all aspects of this matter; or it can have a parliamentary inquiry. The Opposition is making it quite clear that it is very happy to see the former course followed by the Government. We think that would be appropriate, but we will not tolerate the approach which the Government has presently adopted. I ask the Government to consider the point which has been raised by the Opposition and to respond to it before the end of this current period of sittings. If the Government fails to respond in a positive manner we will bring forward a motion for a reference of this matter to a parliamentary committee. The people of Australia are entitled to have the full story told. It is a story which is set out so clearly by Paul Malone's article in the Canberra Times last Saturday. It is a record which demonstrates that internal inquiry by the Government is simply never going to get to the bottom of this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is discussing a matter of public importance which amounts to the claimed need for the Government to appoint a royal commission to inquire into all aspects of the collapse of the Victorian Division of the National Safety Council of Australia. It is a matter of great concern in the community-and it is shared in this chamber which, of course, is representative of the community-that such an organisation, which did undertake very important tasks on behalf not only of the Victorian community but also of various jurisdictions around Australia, has been brought to the point of collapse. It has collapsed apparently due to the activities of its then director.

SPEECH.PARA: That being said and the public concern being well understood, the question is, nevertheless, whether a royal commission into that collapse is justified at this point. There has been nothing revealed in Senator Chaney's remarks, apart from his misgivings and supposed cynicism about the good faith of the Government, to indicate that there has been anything but what is the case, namely, a determination on behalf of all elements of the Federal Government to make proper inquiries within the various portfolios to determine the course of activity between those various elements of all the portfolios and the Victorian Division of the National Safety Council of Australia with a view, not of trying to cover up or somehow displace proper gaze from the activities of various elements of the agencies in a sort of protective attempt to ensure that one's own turf is not embarrassed by some revelation of not dealing with the matter properly, but of aiding the Victorian Government and the relevant Victorian authorities, mainly the Victorian police, in the conduct of their inquiries into this particular collapse. This is the main purpose of the inquiry being undertaken at the request of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke).

It is worth emphasising at the outset that we are dealing with a Victorian company incorporated under Victorian law and subject to Victorian regulation. The Commonwealth had no part to play in the creation of this company, the National Safety Council of Australia, Victorian Division, nor did it have a real role in the oversight of its operations. The fact is, as is well known, that perhaps one of the causes for the sorry state to which this division of the National Safety Council of Australia has been brought is the fact that it had an exemption from lodging its accounts. That exemption was granted because it had been incorporated and licensed under section 66 of the Victorian companies code, which enabled it not to have to comply with the normal requirement that accounts and certain other documents be lodged. That particular provision under the Victorian company law shows squarely that perhaps the major reason for the failure of relevant authorities to know of the parlous state of this organisation rests in responsibilities which are those of the Victorian Commissioner of Corporate Affairs as the delegate of the National Companies and Securities Commission in relation to that type of entity in the Victorian jurisdiction. Basically we are dealing with a Victorian entity which has come to this sorry state with its collapse. The question of the liability of the board was properly touched upon by Senator Chaney and will need to be explored and, as he said, no doubt probably will be explored in the courts. I shall return in a moment to a comment he made about that.

We know that a receiver has been appointed as mortgagee in possession, a provisional liquidator has been appointed by the creditors in accordance with the Victorian companies code. One already has a series of properly constituted responses to this collapse in the appointment of a receiver as mortgagee in possession and the appointment of a provisional liquidator by the creditors. Therefore, a Victorian procedure is quite properly already in operation, designed to expose what has led to this collapse. In so far as the entity is Victorian one can see good reason for a royal commission being unnecessary while those procedures are being undertaken and are moving to the resolution of the responsibilities of the receiver and the provisional liquidator.

I made a note of what Senator Chaney said when talking about the board and its responsibilities in this matter. He cautioned us and said, `It is not proper to canvass the liabilities of the board'-I think he said in this chamber or in the House of Representatives-`because of the possibility of legal proceedings'. I think that is a very salient and correct point, but it should be applied even more vigorously and with greater force to the question of the establishment of a royal commission. Only late yesterday, as we understand it, Mr Friedrich was arrested in Western Australia. I am not in a position to say whether he has been charged under the relevant Victorian legislation. I understand that he has been charged under Western Australian legislation with being suspected of having committed an indictable offence in another jurisdiction, which I take it to be some sort of charge that is put in place while officers of the Victorian fraud squad get over there and commence the application for extradition back to Victoria.

The point I am trying to make is that the man known as John Friedrich is about to face, I can say with almost absolute certainty, very serious charges. One could imagine that he will then be subject to committal proceedings before a magistrate, and if the magistrate commits him to trial he will be up before a jury of 12 men and women drawn from Victoria in order to determine whether he is guilty of the various charges that are preferred against him. They will be making their assessment on his appearance in the court and will have to determine whether he is guilty on the usual criterion, beyond reasonable doubt. I say `his appearance in the court' because when one is talking about a trial as opposed to a royal commission it is worth remembering that Mr Friedrich need say nothing. He need say nothing to the police who arrest him and charge him and ask him certain questions. He need say nothing in the Magistrates Court when committal proceedings are being undertaken. He need say nothing at his criminal trial. In our system of justice it is up to the prosecution to prove all the elements of the offence beyond reasonable doubt. The accused person cannot be required to say anything, whether during the police inquiries, during the committal proceedings undertaken by the magistrate or during the trial.

Senator Chaney seems to be proposing that we have a royal commission where inevitably John Friedrich would be the star witness. He would be called before that royal commission. I have the provisions of the Royal Commissions Act 1902 before me. Section 6 provides as follows:

If any person appearing as a witness before the Commission refuses to be sworn or to make an affirmation or to answer any question relevant to the inquiry put to him by any of the Commissioners he shall be guilty of an offence.
The penalty is:
. . . a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment for a period not exceeding 6 months.
Under the subheading `Self-incrimination' section 6a of the Act provides:

It is not a reasonable excuse for the purposes of sub-section 3 (2) for a person to refuse or fail to produce a document or other thing that he was required to produce at a hearing before a Commission that the production of the document or other thing might tend to incriminate him.
Subsection (2) reads:
A person is not entitled to refuse or fail to answer a question that he is required to answer by a member of a Commission on the ground that the answer to the question might tend to incriminate him.
There one has a completely different public procedure whereby John Friedrich could be called before a royal commission and required to give answers even though they may incriminate him.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is wrong with that?

—At the same time as he is facing charges. Does Senator Teague propose that the royal commission be held before the committal proceedings or during them? Does he propose that the royal commission be held between the committal proceedings and the trial, or during the trial proceedings?
—It does not matter.

—Senator Chaney says that it does not matter. A person may be arrested, charged and enabled at common law to remain silent at the time of police questioning, before the magistrate and before the jury and judge at a trial. Senator Chaney is saying that it does not matter if a royal commission requiring that person to give answers, even though they could be self-incriminating, is conducted at the same time, or before, or contemporaneously, or currently or whatever. I do not believe that we are at the stage where a royal commission, which would have that inevitable impact on a person who has been, as I understand it, arrested and charged in Western Australia in relation to a Western Australian offence, should be given those powers. Such a proposal seems extraordinary to me. It is even more extraordinary in the light of Senator Chaney's statement that we should be very careful in this chamber not to say anything about the liability of boards of directors for fear of prejudicing a fair trial if any legal proceedings are brought in relation to that liability.

SPEECH.PARA: I have had many discussions in this respect with senators, and possibly discussions even in the chamber-and certainly relating to war crimes legislation and to the Rothwells matter. I believe I had an interchange with Senator Chaney about the publicity that attended the arrest of Mr Laurie Connell. I am not absolutely sure of that, but certainly we had private conversations. The fact is that all that sort of pre-trial publicity, which would inevitably poison the wells and fountains of justice, would be exacerbated. Perhaps to some extent it has already occurred, but it would be exacerbated beyond measure by the holding of a royal commission of the kind Senator Chaney has in mind.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the public interest?

—I think that the public interest lies in preserving our common law principle that a person is not prejudiced when he or she goes to trial. We have made that point time and time again. It is not as though the Government has been unresponsive. The fact is that I have answered questions in this place, as have other Ministers-indeed, as Senator Chaney pointed out, so did the Prime Minister-not in a defensive way to try to encourage Ministers or the bureaucrats to protect their turf but in a way which is designed to enable the transfer of whatever information comes to our possession or is in our possession, to the Victorian authorities. All that sort of inquiry is being undertaken.
—Not much.

—Senator Chaney says, `Not much'. I am pleased to say that Peter White, the shadow spokesman for defence matters, does not share Senator Chaney's cynicism. He telephoned me this morning on two matters relating to this particular inquiry, seeking my assistance in relation to the activities of the Australian Federal Police (AFP). After this debate I will be able to reply to Mr White in relation to one matter that he required me to inquire into. In fact, I think I can make it known now. He asked me:

SPEECH.PARA: Was information relating to the NSCA Victorian Division rescue ship Blue Nobilia and its possible involvement in military training and mercenary operations brought to the attention of the AFP's Sydney office in March 1988? If yes, what action was taken on that information?

I am now able to tell honourable senators that information of the nature described was provided by an informant. It was part of the investigation based on material originally provided by the National Crime Authority. It was commenced in October 1987 and concluded in March 1988. In my answer to Senator Hill earlier this week I made the Senate aware of this. As the Parliament has been previously advised, the AFP found nothing to substantiate any of the allegations, including the specific matters referred to in the question.

So Mr White had enough confidence to telephone me and ask me to provide an answer to that question, which I have now placed on the record but which I will also give to him personally. He also asked me to arrange with Commissioner McAulay for somebody from the Commissioner's office to act so as to receive certain documents which Mr White said may be of interest. Indeed, I rang Commissioner McAulay and have arranged that. I would say that Mr White believes that the AFP, as at least one of the Commonwealth agencies involved, is acting in good faith in its disclosure both to the relevant authorities, including the Victoria Police, and to this Parliament, of the matters that have occurred up to this point and is well placed to assist those Victorian authorities in the further considerations of any material that is brought to our attention.

I believe that this proposal, if it were a motion, ought to be rejected. The fact is it would perhaps jeopardise the fair trial of a person if we proceeded with a royal commission at this stage. I do not believe that there is any ground for thinking that the wider issues beyond the possible criminal liability of Mr Friedrich will not be addressed by governments. As I say, the fact is that the Prime Minister has required that all relevant Ministers undertake a review of what has occurred to this point. In so far as any material arising from that review leads either to a change in particular practices or to the need to inform Victorian authorities particularly, whether it be Corporate Affairs or the Victorian Police, of particular matters, that will be done. There is no attempt by this Government in any sense to cover up its activities in relation to this very sorry saga.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, have a royal commission then.

—I believe that would be most inopportune and even most improper at this stage and would put in jeopardy a very important principle of the common law. I therefore believe that the matter of public importance ought not to be supported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating a matter of public importance brought forward by the Opposition urging:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to appoint a royal commission, preferably in conjunction with the Government of Victoria, to inquire into all aspects of the collapse of the Victorian Division of the National Safety Council of Australia with particular reference to that organisation's links and dealings with all government departments and authorities, including security and intelligence authorities.

The Australian Democrats' view is that it would be inappropriate for a royal commission to be appointed at this time. I wish to suggest what we believe is the correct course to take now. First of all, we believe that the Federal Government should seek, through the Parliament, to refer the operational aspects of the activities of the Victorian Division of the National Safety Council of Australia to the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. Following the collapse, I, along with the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support, Mr Robert Brown, and most Australians, was astounded to find out some of the functions which were undertaken by the National Safety Council. Indeed, I must admit that I thought the Victorian Division of the National Safety Council was the same as the one in Queensland, which issues posters to people to ask them not to fall over ladders and so forth. Obviously in Victoria it is an entirely different kettle of fish. That is something of which I, for one, was completely unaware.

I therefore believe that it is appropriate that the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade be involved in this. I refer to a speech made by my colleague Senator Paul McLean on 28 November last year. Speaking on a matter of public importance he said, on behalf of the Democrats:

We must move towards new integrated models of defence based upon both civil and military defence thinking, models which would provide for increased and substantially improved morale within the Services by making their tasks more relevant and visible. Many Western European countries employ their defence forces in non-military tasks. One example is Austria, which employs her defence forces in mountain and air-sea rescue, as frontier police, for disaster relief, as police reinforcements and for fire control reinforcement. Similar undertakings are typical of the Belgian civil military defence forces. In Denmark they undertake mountain and air-sea rescue, coastguard work, and disaster relief. In Finland they undertake mountain and air-sea rescue, coastguard work, frontier police work, disaster relief, and reinforce police and fire control authorities.

From our point of view we should look at whether the type of activities undertaken by the National Safety Council indeed ought to have been undertaken by it or whether they ought to have been undertaken by other organisations. We believe they ought to have been undertaken by the defence forces of this country.

Also, we believe the Federal Government should seek from the Parliament a reference of the security aspects of the National Safety Council's activities to a committee. We believe that that reference would be most properly made to the Joint Committee on the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. Section 92c of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Act set up a parliamentary committee. Under subsection 92c (2) of that Act, it is permissible for the Minister to refer a particular aspect of the activities of the organisation to the Committee for review. We believe that sufficient material is now on the public record to warrant such a reference and to look at a review of security information. That committee has already been set up by the Parliament to deal with such matters. This joint committee, on which all parties are represented is, we believe, under its statutory authority, the appropriate body to deal with that particular matter. Another reason I think it is the relevant body is that many other items in the Act refer to the way that committee is to be conducted, the type of security arrangements it is to meet under, and the type of security arrangements which are available to members of that committee that are not available to other senators and members. In other words, that Committee already has in place the security that is necessary to undertake such an inquiry. No other committee would have those security arrangements in place. For example, when that Committee meets, it meets only in a place to which the Director of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation has agreed and which has already been made secure by a number of procedures. There is a whole host of protections already in place to make sure of the security of information that the Committee receives. There are aspects of this matter, which have been brought forward by the Opposition in the House of Representatives debate, that could very well be referred to that Committee.

There is a third matter that I believe ought to be referred to a committee, specifically to the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation. That is the matter of section 66 organisations, of which the National Safety Council of Victoria was one. Under the legislation currently in this place, which is being reviewed by the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation, they would become section 383 organisations. The matter may very well have been fixed up, but I believe it would be as well for that Committee to be given a specific reference to make sure that was the case. The simplest way to explain this matter is probably for me to read from the explanatory memorandum. Paragraph 1365 of the explanatory memorandum of the corporations legislation package states:
This clause-
that is, clause 383-

differs from . . . s. 66 in that it will no longer be possible for companies licensed under Bill cl. 383 to be exempted from lodging annual returns and returns of directors, principal executive officers and secretaries.

When one thinks of the current available material with regard to the National Safety Council, it is fairly obvious that the methods by which it was able to operate as a charity were quite different from those which it would have had to operate under if it had been an incorporated company. I believe this move, to seek annual returns from charities, would go at least part of the way to correcting the problem. Possibly there are more items involved in this, but I believe the relevant body to refer it to would be the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation.

Apart from that item, I do not think it would be correct for the Parliament to deal with any other items at this time. Incorporated in this whole exercise there are, of course, other matters. I draw attention in particular to the adequacy of the freedom of information legislation at Commonwealth and State levels to be able to deal with the activities and the collapse of the National Safety Council. For example, if the Freedom of Information Act in Victoria or federally operated in a way which allowed people to have access to a range of documents, I am quite sure that those people who have already displayed an interest over a number of years in this matter would have been in a far better position to make noises long before now. But, as we saw recently, with the Opposition's support of the Government to make the expense of gaining access under freedom of information legislation almost prohibitive to ordinary citizens, those particular pieces of legislation are not much use in these areas.

The only other comment I make is to echo points which have already been made. I believe that, as one of the principals involved has been arrested, it is important that no other statements are made at this time, in the public or parliamentary arena, which would impede the possibility of a fair trial for any persons who may be charged with offences, be they the person already arrested or other people who might be connected with the collapse of that organisation. I do not believe that the current situation would lead one to be very sanguine about the possibilities of fair trials, even at the moment. It seems that people in this country have been quite happy to try in the media various people without going to the point of putting in front of what they have been saying `alleged to have' or `allegations that'. It seems now that we are happy to say that people have committed crimes, without those people having a chance to answer in their own names. I believe this chamber should not involve itself in that aspect and neither do I believe that any inquiry of this place should involve itself in that aspect.

In other words, I believe that we need to put aside any of those legal aspects of the collapse of that branch of the National Safety Council which are more properly the concerns of the courts. I think that is the correct course to follow, so that those aspects which are not involved with it, but the operational, security or corporate aspects, over which a legislature has control and quite a specific interest in terms of making sure about the organisation of those safety or security elements or the way our corporate legislation is drafted, are legitimate aspects for inquiry. We should be involved and it should be our first concern. But, beyond that, I believe that this matter should be left to the courts. It may very well be that, after the courts have completed their inquiry, residual elements could be looked at by a further inquiry. However, I do not agree that we should do so prior to the operations of the courts. I doubt whether any senator here would like that type of operation to occur to them. I think it then behoves us to look at, for whatever reason whether political or otherwise, moving in between that person and that person's right, in our society at least, to a fair trial.

The other matters that I mentioned as references would not in any way impinge on these legal matters. They would deal with policy items on which policy recommendations could be made. For example, on the security or defence elements, we could look at whether a private organisation should have been dealing with rescues. That may be a matter for our Air Force. They are matters of policy and they are quite outside whether the National Safety Council had or had not collapsed, and therefore are legitimate aspects for immediate inquiry. Since the call was for a royal commission into all aspects, it seems to me that those aspects would also be those ones which are properly the concern of the court. I for one could not support such an exercise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support this matter of public importance on the need for the Government to appoint a royal commission into what has become known as the Friedrich affair or the National Safety Council of Australia (NSCA), Victorian Division scam. I support Senator Chaney, who gave the reasons why a royal commission would be the best way to inquire into the ramifications of this matter rather than little ad hoc inquiries which Senator Macklin obviously supports. I am saddened that he does not support a complete inquiry into something that the Australian people do not know anything about. I do not think the depths of this debacle are yet known to any of us. What the following weeks and months of investigation bring out will largely depend on how willing this Government is to seek the truth. The saga has many facets and many grey areas. There are many questions and, I think, too few answers. The Parliament is not in possession of the answers; the police are not in possession of all of them either. I am quite sure probably even John Friedrich does not know everything. Only a royal commission will have any chance to unravel this mystery.

SPEECH.PARA: We could argue-and I am sure the Government would like us to-that this is simply a white collar crime, another company fraud, admittedly on a somewhat larger scale than the average but still just another case of the boss running off with the bickie jar. That is what the Government wants us to believe. It says, `Leave it to the fraud squad; let the courts sort this mess out'. But it is a lot more than that. In the most simple terms we have a private, non-profit organisation that is based in Victoria but has offices throughout Australia and overseas with various subsidiary and associated companies throughout Australia. It employs hundreds of people and its budget runs into millions of dollars. It is not the local run of the mill charitable organisation or group; it is, in every sense of the word, a big business-but with some additional privileges. It enjoys the privileges of paying no tax and of being able to receive donations.

Just let us look behind the facade. We see a company that has remarkable access to various government departments, close links with public servants, politicians, bankers, defence personnel and businessmen. It has special freedoms not afforded the average business and contacts with foreign governments. If we dig a little deeper, little bells of warning start to ring out around the place. We see a little irregularity here, some suspect accounting there. Questions of safety standards being breached start appearing. Government departments are shown to be less than efficient in their dealings with the NSCA. What started as an apparently straightforward case of company fraud has developed into a scam involving various government departments. Questions of incompetence start to arise; questions of national security appear. Still the Government is telling us that it is none of our concern.

We then start to look at the man himself, and more questions go unanswered. As I see it, there are three levels to this whole incident. There is the company fraud angle-and, indeed, that is for the courts, quite rightly, to deal with. Whether the final figure is $100m, $200m or even more, it is a major financial scam. There are two other aspects of this case which the Government has not yet addressed in any meaningful level and which cannot be allowed to go unanswered. They are not for the courts to sort out; only a royal commission will have the ability and the flexibility to produce the answers.

The first is that of bureaucratic incompetence. How can one man for so long con so many senior government officials and industry leaders? It was seemingly easy-frighteningly so. I will come back to that in a short while. The third level of inquiry must surely be the man himself, John Friedrich. Just who is he? Why does the Government not know? The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) told the Senate quite unashamedly on Tuesday:

We have found no evidence that Mr Friedrich was an Australian citizen. As I understand it he was not on the electoral roll and did not have a driver's licence or a passport . . . we will not know, until Mr Friedrich is apprehended, how he arrived in the country.

This is not some miscellaneous factory hand we are talking about here; we are talking about the head of a multi-million dollar business, a council with access to government agencies and leading industry bankers, a company which, by any description, enjoyed privileges not given to other companies in Australia. The head of this company is known to governments throughout Australia and overseas. He is on first-name terms with half of the business community. Yet the Minister for Immigration tells us that the Government does not know who he is, where he came from or how he got here.

I find it somewhat extraordinary that in this age of computer files, tax file numbers and Customs records this man can even apply for a job, much less get one, without some sort of check being made as to who he was. How did he get married if he did not supply a birth certificate? How did he drive a car-and get all the way to Western Australia-without a licence? How was he able to operate bank accounts and pay loans without someone somewhere asking a few basic questions? It is so extraordinary that it is quite bizarre. When the Department of Immigration can run down with a passion the proverbial little old lady overstaying her visitor's visa, I find it quite stunning that its officers have no information on such a high profile person and even more amazing that the Minister can say, with no apparent difficulty, that no-one has a clue. This is the first question that must be answered.

On the question of bureaucratic incompetence, one is at a loss to know where to start. We have heard evidence in this chamber of attempts by various people, including the media, to force the State Government in Victoria and the Federal Government to investigate allegations of incompetence, of cover-ups, of possible breaches of national security and financial mismanagement. All have fallen on deaf ears. The Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) said basically, `Well, we had a look at it but really couldn't come up with anything; so we ignored the complaint'. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said similar things in the House the other day. I know, however, that he has now asked eight Ministers to prepare briefs on the issue, as Senator Chaney has mentioned already, so at last the Prime Minister is beginning to smell some trouble. It is not before time even though he claimed yesterday that it is a State matter.

Let us go through some of the allegations of bureaucratic bungling and the Public Service blind eye, deaf ear syndrome. First, there are allegations of arms deals with Third World connections by the National Safety Council of Australia in Victoria and associated companies. There are allegations that people associated with the NSCA were involved in trying to buy bomber parts from Canberra for sale to an overseas government. There are allegations of purchases of weapons and other defence equipment. We learn that the NSCA had an enviable supply of special halo parachutes, the sort used by Army experts. There are allegations that the Special Air Service Regiment (SAS) in fact wanted to use the NSCA equipment because it was absolutely state of the art stuff and better than its own. There are allegations of purchases of Boeing 727 aircraft for overseas sale. There are allegations of involvement in arms deals with Third World countries and other unlawful conduct. These allegations were made to the National Crime Authority as early as October 1987. Nothing came of them.
Let us turn to the Department of Aviation. It had an involvement at a number of levels with the NSCA. Indeed, one of its senior officers had close ties with the NSCA. He has said:
I know things don't add up at the NSCA but I'm just along for the ride.
Here was a public servant who knew things were wrong but, for whatever reason, chose to do nothing about it.

It is important to remember the extent of the role of the NSCA. It had an enormous fleet of fixed and rotary wing aircraft at its disposal. These craft were equipped with the latest navigational aids, long distance fuel tanks, various searchlight and radar equipment, winches and fully trained 24-hour crews. These aircraft were a significant part of aviation activity in Australia. The NSCA ran its own pilot training facility and had air bases and operations in several States. The Council sent its aircraft and crews to fight fires in France, Spain and Canada. This was all done during our winter here. There are allegations that one of the NSCA planes was damaged in an air traffic incident but, despite suffering tail wing damage, the incident was never reported for airworthiness testing. In fact, many such regulations were waived or ignored when it came to NSCA aircraft. There have been allegations of death threats against people who criticised the NSCA and threats against pilots who asked questions. Unfortunately, one of those critics is now dead, killed in an air ambulance plane crash that, according to at least one man, was not an accident.

There are also allegations that NSCA planes had blanket clearance for Customs. This is understandable when you consider the nature of their work. They could hardly be expected to queue for Customs clearance when they had critically ill persons from, say, Fiji or New Guinea awaiting urgent medical attention. But do we know how many times Customs clearance was sought and how often it was given? Was each case an emergency? We know flights were made to areas such as the Persian Gulf, but was every circumstance a fully documented emergency? What about the allegations made in the other place yesterday of the illegal entry of a German citizen aboard an NSCA plane? Let us face it: it would be no great effort to smuggle in or out of Australia via NSCA planes contraband, people-whatever you like.

Obviously many of the operations and relations between government departments and the NSCA were based on trust. Clearly that trust has been breached, but to what extent and does anyone know? Only a royal commission would find out. The old boy mateship network flourished very willingly. The NSCA annual report, which ironically boasts of 60 years of service to the community, is crammed full of activities and people. Just about every government department with any vague connection with NSCA activities had a seat on the Council's board. Yet it is that same board that claims it knew nothing of the financial mismanagement of the Council or its head. How much then did these people know or suspect but chose to ignore about mismanagement of their own department's dealings with the NSCA? How much do various State and Federal Ministers know but are not telling?

We know of at least one Minister who believed silence was the best course of action. I refer to the Deal Island fire. Deal Island is a 1,600-hectare Commonwealth lighthouse reserve in Bass Strait. It was used in 1986 by NSCA personnel to carry out survival exercises. However, while they were on the island a major fire broke out which required a massive firefighting exercise to contain. Subsequent reports indicate that the fire was started by NSCA personnel to cook some fish they had caught, despite the fact that fires were not allowed on the island. That one was lit in winds of around 40 knots is extraordinary. In fact, the winds were so strong it made air firefighting quite difficult and hazardous. It was suggested by local media at the time that the SAS was responsible for starting the fire because parachutists landing on the island were presumed to be SAS officers. The then Minister for Transport, Mr Peter Morris, knew the NSCA was responsible and chose to remain silent on the matter. I have a package of documents which show his Department was fully briefed as to who was responsible but Minister Morris said nothing. Neither has it been confirmed whether the NSCA, who not only started the fire but also put it out, actually charged the Commonwealth for its services.

An even more alarming allegation made against the NSCA is that of the sale of unsafe parachutes by a company associated with the NSCA to the Wilton Parachute School in New South Wales. This school is fairly well known, not only for the number of people who pass through its doors but also because there have been deaths of students there. The Department of Transport and Communications is in possession of signed statements from people who knew that faulty parachutes were being sold. Unserviceable parachutes were being used at the Wilton Parachute School. This has also been documented. What was behind the entire NSCA parachute rigging staff resigning because of poor safety standards? That is another question that could be asked. What about the allegations of jumps made from overcrowded aircraft or of parachutists dropped at Sale in Victoria with civil jets in the vicinity? Even the coroner inquiring into the deaths of the two parachutists killed at Wilton suggested that the Department of Transport and Communications hold an inquiry. Nothing was done. Again, the Department saw nothing and did nothing.

What is this Government trying to hide? Why does it not agree to a royal commission into the Victorian branch of the NSCA and clear the matter up for all the people who have been kept in the dark and make sure that every little facet of the organisation is made known by the Australian people, as is their right? A lot of us would like to know the facts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is perfectly true that the collapse of the Victorian company, the National Safety Council of Australia (NSCA), is a serious matter. It has been a spectacular collapse. The only organisation in Australia that I am currently aware of that is in a more bankrupt state than the National Safety Council of Australia is the Federal coalition-Opportunists Pty Ltd in receivership. That is precisely the way the Opposition has behaved in this debate. I actually took the trouble to go over to the House of Representatives last night to sit in on the debate on this matter. I saw such a transparent attempt by a fairly desperate Opposition to clutch at straws and draw whatever long bow was in sight to try to sheet the collapse of a private Victorian company home to the feet of the Commonwealth. I am surprised it has bothered to run the same sham in the Senate today.
—Your lot filibustered last night.

—I am not sure how I can filibuster with a 15-minute speech but I will try now. The National Safety Council of Australia is something of a misnomer because it is not a national safety council of Australia. A lot of people are under the impression that it is and it is the impression that it is some sort of arm of the Government the Opposition is trying to cash in on. It is a private Victorian company limited by guarantee. It has collapsed with the unfortunate effect of some 400-odd people being thrown on the street out of work. I dare say that the reasons for that will be canvassed in a judicial fashion in the weeks and months ahead.

SPEECH.PARA: A reasonable comparison to make with the collapse of this company that the Opposition is now calling for a royal commission would be the collapse of Patrick Partners some years ago because of fraudulent behaviour on its board of directors. It may have escaped my attention-I went through the Hansards of that time-but I do not think the Opposition was screaming its head off for a royal commission into that. Perhaps Senator Michael Baume may have done so and I am doing him a disservice. I do not think anyone on the other side was screaming about having a royal commission on the collapse of Patrick Partners.

There have been so many canards run in this debate about the involvement of the Commonwealth in the National Safety Council in Victoria that it is necessary once again to lay them to rest. What was the involvement of this private company which tendered, along with other private companies, for search and rescue operations with the Commonwealth? It, along with thousands of other companies in Australia, has contracts with the Commonwealth Government and the State governments. What was its involvement? I thought the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, put it fairly succinctly in the House of Representatives last night when he said that the valid comparison to make was that the total involvement of the National Safety Council of Australia with the Department of Defence was for a total amount of money equivalent to one-seventeenth of one of the 75 FA18s that are operated by the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF).

I will give a little more precise detail about that. The facts are that the RAAF had three contracts for search and rescue services with this organisation totalling $4.7m and a number of smaller ancillary services. I might also add that it is appropriate to note that these contracts were due to expire this year. They were negotiated on the basis that no up-front payments whatsoever were required by the Commonwealth for these services to be provided; so there was no exposure of Commonwealth funds in relation to this organisation whatsoever. I am sure the 20-20 hindsight experts on the other side of the House would be prepared to concede that up until this point in time the company not only had a good reputation but had a spectacular reputation.

Let me address some of the points made by Senator Brownhill as the grounds on which the Government should establish a royal commission. What are the dreadful sins of this organisation? It had spectacularly good and sophisticated equipment. It had extremely efficient personnel. I think this highlights one of the holes in this whole debate: the Opposition is deliberately trying to confuse the activities of the organisation itself with the activities of Mr Friedrich. That is the big hole in the Opposition's argument.

The organisation was acknowledged to be efficient. The Department of Defence had no complaint about the service that was provided. It paid only for services that were provided. The Opposition has attempted to make something of the fact that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) wrote to eight government departments as a very sensible precaution. Of course, the Prime Minister would do that. There is a little bit of public cont- roversy surrounding this organisation.

I wish to put into context the relationship of this private Victorian company which has failed. Of course the Commonwealth Government has thousands of contracts with private companies all over Australia. I will give just one quick example as time does not allow me to give any more. This organisation is not the only company that has contracts with the Department of Defence. Access by private contractors to defence bases in Australia can range from 65 visits a year in my home city of Darwin to 1,800 a month at Williamtown. It is seriously suggested by the Opposition-I heard it seriously suggested by Peter White last night-that the Department of Defence should set up an audit division of its own to investigate the financial affairs of every one of these hundreds of companies with whom it has contracts. What a nonsensical proposition that would be in terms of getting value for money for the Australian taxpayer.

The Opposition is seriously suggesting that we should have some sort of sophisticated security clearance for all of these contractors. It is freely acknowledged that sophisticated security clearances do have to be organised for contractors who are directly involved in highly sophisticated and secret matters such as providing the armaments on warships or the construction of submarines. But what is involved in getting a clearance of that magnitude? I can tell you that a great deal is involved. It involves investigations into a person's bank accounts and background and questions being asked of friends and neighbours. It is a very involved and highly intrusive process. The Opposition is seriously suggesting that organisations that have got a total involvement of $4.7m in contractual relationships with the Commonwealth Government should be put through such a process. To suggest that is an absolute nonsense. The entire government and business relationships of the Department of Defence would grind to a halt overnight and the cost of it would never be able to be justified.

What does it base this nonsense on? It is based on the alleged possession of a document by Mr Friedrich. What was the document? It has been described quite falsely as being top secret. It was nothing of the sort. The document was not a classified operational plan, nor a classified operational manual, but the findings of a Government review into counter-terrorist activities and search and rescue for aircraft downed in operations. Hundreds of copies were prepared and delivered, as they had to be, to State governments and various other departmental organisations across Australia. It was not a top secret document. It was a document that was classified, of course, to the point where it was not confetti on the streets, but it is a nonsense to suggest that a high security clearance is required for access to documents like that. The entire call of the Opposition for a royal commission into this affair is based on this nonsense.

Where should the onus for a security clearance of this level rest? Should it be with anyone that comes into contact with a senior officer or a senior bureaucrat in the Department of Defence? That would be nonsense. Is anyone seriously suggesting that because someone is the next door neighbour of an Army general or a senior officer in the Royal Australian Air Force or a senior bureaucrat and they have some contact with these people on a daily basis, they have to have a high level security clearance, that they have to have officers from Intelligence going round asking intrusive questions of their friends and neighbours? Of course they are not. The onus properly rests, in terms of security clearance, with the officers and the bureaucrats who have the information in the first place, and not with people they might give it to or come into contact with. Security clearances at that level are required to be given to the people who have the information in order to ensure that they will not pass the information on to anyone else they might come into contact with. That is where the proper onus should lie. The ridiculous proposition put by Peter White, on behalf of the Opposition, last night would render the Department of Defence unworkable overnight.

I add, just in passing, that in addressing myself to this debate and looking at what was said last night I tried to get all the relevant papers. It is just a minor complaint, but the honourable member for Richmond, Mr Blunt, said in the final few moments of his contribution in the House of Representatives last night that he had tabled copies of photocopies of cheques, invoices and termination papers that he had in his possession in the Parliament. I have contacted the extremely efficient Table Office in the House of Representatives. I cannot find them. In fact, the Table Office has informed me that, despite Mr Blunt's statement, they have not in fact been tabled. So perhaps I could just ask Mr Blunt, in order to complete the Opposition's case, which clearly has not been fully made yet, if he would care to table them today in the House of Representatives. It is just a minor irritation, but it is there.

Where should the responsibility lie for what has happened with this organisation? Before an investigation is even conducted, I have no hesitation in saying where I think it should properly lie. The ultimate responsibility for what happened in this private Victorian company rests with its board of directors. There is no question about that. It does not rest with Mr Friedrich.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that all you think it boils down to?
—Senator Newman will get her turn next. It does not even rest with the auditors. They may be partially responsible for what happened, but the ultimate reponsibility-
—Talk about simplicity!

—Perhaps the bastions of private enterprise on the other side of the chamber can tell me what new system they suggest for running private companies other than the ultimate financial responsibility for the dreadful collapse, throwing 400 people onto the scrapheap, resting with the board of directors of that company; and that is where it should rest. I am going to be very interested to find out whether this significant company had an audit committee on its board. I have no hesitation in saying that the public comments I have so far heard made by two members of that board are a nonsense. They sat at a board meeting and got a ring binder or a stack of papers from Mr Friedrich, from which he had removed the qualifying statements that had been put there by the auditors. They never thought to question him beyond that or go beyond that. That warrants serious investigation, and no doubt the relevant corporate bodies in Victoria that are responsible for investigating companies will investigate it.
—At last.
—I have no doubt they will, in the same way that they investigated Patrick Partners, and the Opposition was not calling for a royal commission into the collapse of that company.
—And do you think that is all that needs investigation?

—Of course it is not all that needs investigating, but I would suggest a more sensible course of action. I would hope that there is not one single person in this chamber that would want to prevent, impede or make more difficult the successful prosecution of the people who were responsible for the collapse of this company. I would also hope that there would not be anyone in this chamber that would want to try to interfere with or prevent, in so far as it is still possible, the right that anyone who is going to be charged in this affair has to try to mount a defence in a court of law. The proposition to now establish a royal commission into the affairs of this company, when the full extent of charges that are going to be laid is not even evident yet and when the person who has been deliberately avoiding the police has only just been captured, is an absolute nonsense and is, in my view, completely irresponsible. I had some involvement with a similar example recently-the Amann Aviation inquiry. Honourable senators on the other side of the chamber and their colleagues in the House of Representatives know the great difficulties of the very proper sub judice conventions of this Parliament with matters that are before the court. Our hands are tied on those matters. People deserve their day in court. Mr Friedrich deserves his day in court-in so far as it is still possible to give it to him. On the other side of the coin, as I said before, this Parliament should be doing nothing to impede or cloud the opportunity to successfully prosecute the people responsible for the collapse of this company.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no question whatsoever, therefore, that the call by the Opposition for the establishment at this point in time of a royal commission is irresponsible. The proper course of action is to allow the authorities which are now in charge of this to complete their work, to allow charges to be made, to allow the court cases to ensue, to wait for the dust to settle, and then to see whether any further action is necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —One at least has to give Senator Collins credit for being frank. He promised that he was going to filibuster and he did, practically in the same terms as did the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), for 15 minutes last night. I wonder whether he spent his bed time last night learning the Minister's speech. It would have made it simpler for him. It sounded very similar. He told us what the involvement of the National Safety Council with the Commonwealth was, and he gave us to understand that it was simply a question of a few piddling little contracts. Let us look at just what the involvement was with the Commonwealth. First of all, there were those contracts and queries about those contracts. Secondly, there were inquiries and complaints made to the Australian Federal Police (AFP) and to the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO). Next, there was suggested involvement with the Special Air Service. There was also involvement with counter-terrorism units and complaints on air safety and other matters to the Department of Transport and Communications. We know about those areas for certain. I believe there to be more. So it cannot be said that the Opposition has no genuine cause for concern about the various areas in which Commonwealth bodies and agencies had some connection with the organisation and Mr Friedrich.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, tried exactly the same tack last night. He tried to minimise the contact of the organisation and Mr Friedrich with the Commonwealth. He also tried the same stunt of trying to pour ridicule on the need for checks on defence contractors. We have been getting this Government line again today. We believe that there are many shady issues and unanswered questions that have to be dealt with. My colleagues Senator Chaney and Senator Brownhill have already alluded to many of them. The nation needs to know whether its security was jeopardised. If ever there was a good reason for the Commonwealth being involved in an inquiry at the level of a royal commission, it is that. The taxpayers also have a right to know what has happened to the money paid out for contracts that now will not be fulfilled. We believe that a royal commission is the best way of dealing with the questions that have been raised and the suspicions that are abounding.

There were so many Government and private agencies involved. It seems to be a bit like shutting the stable door after a $2m horse has bolted but we have to ensure that this does not happen again. In order to do that we have to know the full extent of the mess. Mr Friedrich was not superhuman; he was not a magician. Clearly, this has happened because various government bodies were negligent in some way, especially in the security area. They showed inertia in inquiring into allegations made to different Commonwealth bodies over several years. Alarm bells were ringing in some corridors of the Commonwealth Government at least two years ago.

I draw the attention of honourable senators to the Commonwealth Government's fraud report. The Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) has just come in. He will remember it quite well. We heard a lot about it from the AFP union during the last election. The Minister for Justice managed to keep the lid on that until the election was over. A couple of months later he was prepared to tell us about it. I recall that we had a great deal of discussion in a Senate Estimates Committee meeting in September and October 1987. I asked the AFP about the fraud report. I asked the Department of Administrative Services and I asked the Department of Defence. It is quite interesting. I would like to draw attention to the fact that on 22 October 1987 I referred to the Australian Federal Police estimate that fraud involving Department of Defence contracts and other defence matters amounts to about $800m a year. I asked whether the Department had taken steps to ascertain the accuracy of those estimates. I was told that there had been a detailed Defence internal audit report, only just completed, on the issue of fraud. I was told that the results of that report were being evaluated. That was in October 1987. I was also told by Mr McLeod, the officer concerned, that from time to time they receive specific allegations of fraud in respect of defence programs or contracts. My questioning went on for some time. They were investigated internally. In certain cases civil authorities were also involved.

At that time a body called the Fraud Control Committee was set up. It comprised the secretaries of some of the senior departments. The Committee was to look at ways of ensuring that the Commonwealth did not get caught up with shady deals or shady dealers and that fraud against the Commonwealth was prevented. It seems that that Committee has disappeared without trace. Once again we find the Commonwealth dealing with a contractor that it knows nothing about.

In this case the Commonwealth may not have been defrauded but there is no certainty of that. It is a matter of concern that, despite a long investigation into fraud against the Commonwealth, despite the AFP assessment of $800m fraud against the Department of Defence in its contracts, this contractor that came along was not thoroughly investigated. Perhaps we would not be debating this matter today if the Department, at that time, had taken steps to investigate its contractor. After all, as my colleagues have already said, it was pretty important. These defence contractors have access to senior defence officials. They also have access to restricted defence bases. Although the Minister and Senator Collins poured ridicule on the need to investigate the contractors, a year and a half ago the Commonwealth and the AFP were concerned to see that people were being properly checked out.

On 24 October 1986 Mr Beazley put out a press release in which he announced that he had called tenders for the provision of a civilian contract helicopter rescue service at RAAF Williamtown on a trial basis for two years. He intended to make more effective use of the defence resources. He thought that that could be done by providing a civilian contractor and tenders were going to be assessed. One wonders just how they were assessed. Was it purely for operational reasons? Was any thought given to the access they would have to defence establishments? Was any thought given to seeing whether they would be financially long enough to survive the length of the contract? The National Safety Council was given the initial trial run at Williamtown. That was fair enough. Clearly it must have been satisfactorily evaluated; either that or not evaluated at all. Its contract was extended to cover first Darwin and then Tindal. In both cases that was only some time early this year. The Department, or whoever was responsible for assessing this defence contractor, had a couple of opportunities for evaluating and clearly did not do so.

It may not seem so important to the Government but we have a problem with manpower and resources in the defence forces. They are strapped to the floor because of lack of money and lack of manpower. An arrangement was organised so that search and rescue was no longer one of its tasks. Search and rescue now suddenly has to be dealt with by a force that does not have the manpower and equipment to do all the tasks expected of it by the Federal Government. These defence funds are precious and there is no excuse for squandering them. If I had time I could go into the allegations about Mr Friedrich's international intelligence connections.

I am concerned that there has been a report that Mr Friedrich was looking at purchasing five Spanish CASA CN235s at a cost of more than $US8.5m each. This is a very strange proposal. Perhaps the report could be explained if we looked at the direction of the Defence Department under this Minister. He is planning to privatise more and more of the Defence Department. It may have been that he was going to have not only search and rescue provided by civilians but also medevac and troop transport. These planes would have provided quite good troop transports. The military sources quoted in the Herald newspaper said that they were puzzled about these prospective purchases. I wonder whether they really are or whether there are some people in the Department of Defence who know very well that Mr Friedrich was given a tip-off that this was a direction in which the Minister was moving.
I am concerned that Senator Tate has not been able to answer the question I asked today in time for this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a fishing question.
—It was not a fishing question, Minister. Obviously you do not know what is happening in your Department. I intend to tell you exactly which document I am talking about.
—Why didn't you then? You have a public duty.
—I now have an opportunity to tell you. I am not yet the Minister in charge of the Department of--
—If you knew at Question Time you had a public duty to inform me.
—Minister, I am now telling you what I have been able to ascertain. I would have expected you to ascertain this much faster than I. If you recall, I am in the Opposition.
—Order! Senator Newman, you should direct your remarks through the Chair.

—I now tell the Minister that the document concerned is called the national security plan. It was handed over, as was the other document which has also been referred to in the last few days, by an official involved in counter-terrorism and protective services. The Minister might now be able to find more details for me.
—Typical of you. When did you know this?
—I am just telling you now.
—When did you know?
—I have only heard about it; I did not know what it was. I asked you. I also asked whether--
—Order! Senator Newman, I would like your remarks to be directed through the Chair.
—The Minister clearly knows more than he was prepared to tell. I knew no more than I am telling him.
—And if he did not know he should have known.
—He should have known.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I completely refute the allegation that I knew more than I was prepared to tell during Question Time. That is completely and utterly untrue. Senator Newman has no foundation for that statement and she should withdraw it.
—The Minister wishes Senator Newman to withdraw that statement.

—I withdraw it. Clearly, he should have known. If he did not know during Question Time, he should have known by the time that I found out. I do not have much time left. I make the point that this was a sensitive document. It was a restricted document. I must be a bit worrying if anything called a national security plan is in the hands of a person who we did not even know existed in this country.
—You knew before.
—I did not know before. I knew what I was looking for, but I did not know what it was called.
—I do not believe you.

—No, I did not. I want to know whether this man has been getting briefings, whether he has had access to other material. I expect the Minister to try to find out more for me, now that I have been able to give him more details. The cuts in the last few years to the AFP, the cuts to the counter-terrorism units, are clearly responsible for some of the lack of investigation that has taken place on this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: It is obvious that we need a royal commission to see what jeopardy has been caused to our defence forces, our police forces, our counter-terrorism forces. The country is clearly in danger when this Government runs down the things that are absolutely basic to the responsibilities of a Federal government. These are some of the reasons that I believe are the most vital reasons why we need a royal commission. This joins the Amann Aviation scandal, but I believe it takes it a great deal further. This Government has shown irresponsibility; it has shown a curious lack of urgency or concern. The Australian public has a right to know why and where so much money has gone, how lax have been our security measures, our safety measures, our protection of defence secrets, our protection against fraud. Why were so many bureaucrats deluded by one man for so long? Who is he? How was he able to get here and to stay here for so long? Why was the Government unaware of his non-status?

The problems concerning Mr Friedrich and his rights can be quarantined if there is to be a trial. An awful lot of matters do not directly concern him but concern the operations of government departments and other bodies. The Government must be held to account. Too many government agencies are involved. Duckshoving will be the result of these seven or eight inquiries. All that will happen is that the people involved will rush to cover their hides with separate in-house investigations. We need a royal commission. If the Government chooses to run away from a royal commission, we will have to have a parliamentary inquiry. Too many serious and urgent matters have been raised by this scandal. We cannot afford to allow them to be dealt with internally by bureaucrats who may have something to hide.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin by telling a story which will become relevant as I proceed. Very recently my son was admitted to practise as a barrister and solicitor of the Supreme Court of Victoria. I had the pleasure, with my wife, of moving for his admission. Of course, it is always of concern, when one's children launch themselves into the world, as to where he or she might get a job. In that context, I am somewhat tempted to support the proposition put forward by the Opposition because if we had a royal commission along the lines suggested by honourable senators opposite, my son would be provided with work from now until the end of his days-and I hope his days extend well into his eighties.

SPEECH.PARA: If the suggestion made by honourable senators opposite is adopted, we will have the greatest legal battle since the time of Charles Dickens. I think the case of which he wrote in Bleak House was Jarndyce v. Jarndyce. Honourable senators opposite say that this inquiry, this royal commission, should look, among other things, into fires that have been lit and then put out, I understand, by the same people. There would be inquiries into foreign affairs and the conduct of foreign affairs, into parachute jumps that have been made, parachutes that have been bought and sold, the inefficiency of public servants, the identity of immigrants, the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, the Office of National Assessments, the Australian Secret Intelligence Service, and into the way in which directors have conducted themselves. Indeed, there have been some inquiries in this Parliament into directors and their companies, and those have taken us some considerable time.

Having looked at directors, we would then inquire into the financial dealings of private companies, the affairs of the Special Air Service regiment, the relationship between the Victorian Division of the National Safety Council of Australia and politicians, businessmen, big business and public servants. We would then inquire into the loss of safety services, large commercial losses, the screening of government contracts, and connections between the Victorian Division of the National Safety Council and transport and aviation. We would inquire into counterterrorism, fraud in defence contracts, the lack of manpower in the defence services, international intelligence gathering activities that may be going on in Australia and overseas, flights to the Middle East, police forces, and security threats.

That simple recitation shows that this proposal has been very sloppily drafted in order to get publicity in light of the publicity given to the man who headed the Victorian Division of the National Safety Council, as he has now been arrested. I note that it was not until Mr Friedrich had been arrested that this proposition was brought before the Senate, and the matter was not debated in the other place until after he had been captured. How sincere can we believe the Opposition is when it does not put forward this sort of proposition until the man has been arrested and publicity has surrounded him?

In that context, I say this: a humane and liberal society is one which extends the protection of the law to all people. It is easy enough to protect the people who we find beautiful, who we find intelligent, who we can sympathise with. It is easy enough to extend the protection of the law to them. It is a bit more difficult at times to extend it to those who we may not like or who we feel have committed a crime or crimes which are grander than normal ones. If that is the approach we take, I think we lose the ability to call ourselves a humane and liberal society.

Why is it-and this is not the first time-that the Opposition has waited until the man has been arrested to bring the proposition before the chamber? No matter how much argument there is that Mr Friedrich can be quarantined from any royal commission, the reality is-and the facts stare everybody in the face; they must stare the Opposition in the face-that even if this proposition goes no further, it has prejudiced the trial of Mr Friedrich, if he comes to trial. It has prejudiced any civil proceedings that may be brought by many people who may be candidates to do so. It may prejudice civil proceedings when, and if, any actions are brought against the directors of this company.

It is easy enough to put forward a proposition which, as I say, is a very sloppy proposition, to score points against the Government and to berate the Government for its alleged failures. On the other hand, if it is going to prejudice the rights of people in the community-Mr Friedrich, the directors of this company or public servants-it is proper for this side of the Senate to point out that that situation lacks propriety.

I have no doubt that the Opposition is intent on obtaining the truth on many subjects and many issues. Opposition members discussed many subjects and many issues in the debate today. However, they seem to lack a sense of propriety about when to introduce matters such as this. For example, I remember that when a civil hearing was about to take place in the Federal Court last year in a case between a union and employers the Opposition introduced a matter which cut right across the issues that that tribunal was going to deal with. Here we have again today, as we had last night in the other place, a proposition which is aimed, the Opposition says, at obtaining the truth but which has the effect of prejudicing people in exercising the rights which any citizen ought to be able to enjoy in this community. It has almost become a pattern of the Opposition to blunder in at times when issues of delicacy, issues that go to the very humane character of this community, are at stake. It is time that Opposition members started looking at themselves.

What does this motion mean? Why was it brought in now? Why could it not have been brought in-if it was going to be brought in-after the Opposition obtained some facts? What it has done today is typical of what happens in this place and in many other places. It has made a whole series of allegations that go to the integrity of all sorts of people, in this case to the Public Service, to the police and to people in private enterprise. No facts have been brought forward. Those allegations having been made, they are then made the basis of demands for a royal commission. One explanation might be that the Opposition has been so long out of government that it wants to try to exercise some executive power. It might feel that if it can get a royal commission up and running it will have somehow exercised the power of executive government. Royal commissions, of course, are the instruments of executive government. They are specifically aimed at giving information to government so that it can take particular actions in particular places. If an inquiry into a specific incident is called for, that is an appropriate thing for a royal commission to enter into, but it is extraordinary, in my view, that the Opposition should throw together-and this proposition has been thrown together-a matter of public importance and make all sorts of allegations without giving us any adequate proof.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is pretty normal.

—It does seem to be fairly normal and it is a bit worrying. Opposition members talk about the need for the Government to appoint a royal commission, preferably in conjunction with the Government of Victoria. They want to exercise executive power, not only federally but also in Victoria, to inquire into all aspects of the collapse.
