Originally I thought that `all' meant a fairly wide range of subjects but I did not conceive, until the speakers opposite spoke, that such wide-ranging inquiries would be sought as have been sought here today. The Opposition proposed a whole litany of issues that it wants a judge-and no doubt the judge's son, his grandson and his great-grandson-to inquire into. Just how long this inquiry will take, with all the issues that the Opposition has raised taken into account, is beyond imagination. There is no attempt to confine what the inquiry will cover. There is no attempt to give any direction to this Parliament as to the specific issues it wants investigated, except some vague suggestion at the end of the Opposition's proposition. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . with particular reference to that organisation's links and dealings with all government departments and authorities, including security and intelligence authorities.

I suppose the Opposition wants the judge to haul before him the officers of our security and intelligence authorities such as ASIO, ASIS and ONA. No doubt the Opposition wants them cross-examined in public on the dealings of our security services. The Opposition has been very keen on the security services and has been very keen to see that what the security and intelligence authorities do is kept safe and secure. Yet as soon as it smells some sort of opportunity in the political field it is willing to cast aside all the jealousy that it had for preserving the confidentiality of these security organisations and wants to bring them out in the open.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you were protecting the public interest we would be less concerned to open up the files of ASIO.

—What Senator Hill is saying, as I understand him, is that it is now in the public interest to open up the files of ASIO, that it is now in the public interest to open up the files of ASIS, that it is now in the public interest to open up the files of ONA. Where is the evidence to suggest that it is time we blew apart the security and intelligence authorities that we have built up over the years? It would seem to me to be quite--
—What about the national plan that apparently they have got? Should this fellow have had a national security plan?

—Senator Hill's answer to my proposition that we ought to preserve the sanctity of the security and intelligence authorities is that this fellow had a national security plan. What has that got to do with the proposition that we should open up the files of ASIO and ASIS? It is a non sequitur and it is typical of an Opposition that is willing, on the flimsiest of excuses, to tear apart the law that has protected us so well up until now.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

DEBATE.TITLE: TORRES STRAIT PROTECTED ZONE JOINT AUTHORITY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

In view of the arrest this morning of five Indonesian fishing boats in the area north of Australia, the issue of the proper protection of the zone to our north with respect to fishing and a large number of other matters, such as drug running and security surveillance, becomes a very important issue indeed. The annual report of the Torres Strait Protected Zone Joint Authority refers to a small part of the protected northern zone which comes under the joint authority, which pays particular regard to fishing matters. Interestingly, the report deals with a number of matters such as the number of licences which have been granted and the size of the various catches. I notice that in the Torres Strait region there are already a large number of fishermen operating. As at 30 June 1988 there were 851 fishermen's licences for that region and they covered a number of species including prawns, rock lobster and several species of fish. For prawns there was a total allowable catch of 1,500 tonnes-a not inconsiderable catch from that region.

If this Protected Zone Authority is to manage the fishery properly, it is important that it is able to keep proper surveillance over the area and avoid the illegal fishing which is going on around our northern shores by a number of overseas fishing boats. Some of these illegal fishermen are arrested, but I have no doubt that the large majority of them are not. Interestingly, this morning's news item mentioned that the arresting vessel went out to arrest one vessel; it then discovered a second vessel and finally discovered five fishing vessels out there. On page 7 of the report under `Surveillance and Enforcement', we find that the ability to carry out surveillance properly in this region is indeed very limited. We have one boating and fishing patrol vessel, the Wauri, which commenced operations in mid-1988. We also have the occasional visit of naval vessels and Royal Australian Air Force P3 Orion long-range aircraft. Also, the report says that increasingly the coastwatch littoral surveillance flights are providing useful assistance for fisheries surveillance in the Torres Strait.

The point I would like to stress is that we need very much to improve the quality of our northern surveillance. This is a good example of an important area in this regard, not only with respect to fishing but also with respect to quarantine, because there are significant diseases which can move down through that chain of islands from Papua New Guinea to Australia. For those purposes, the Australian Democrats have long believed we should purchase the Canadian amphibious aircraft, the CL215, which could be used, among other things, for this surveillance purpose. Not only could it carry out surveillance but also, because it can carry an armed boarding party and land in large seas, it could actually land and arrest these illegal fishermen. At the same time, this aircraft would be eminently suitable for fighting fires in southern Australia during the summer time. For that reason, the Democrats believe that the purchase of a fleet of these aircraft would be extremely useful to Australia in a combination of these activities. It would be extremely useful for this task of northern surveillance, particularly because of its ability to land in remote areas to arrest the illegal incursions by fishermen from Indonesia, Taiwan and various other countries to the north of Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

In speaking on the annual report of the Wheat Research Council, I wish to point out that the total amount allocated to continuing research in the last 12 months was $3.84m. It is no coincidence that Australia has the best quality wheat in the world at present. I know that wheat is the subject of the moment because of the expiration of the five-year agreement. A new agreement will start on 1 July. The reason that we have the best and cleanest wheat in the world flows from the use of research money provided by growers under successive agreements since 1947. It has generally been accepted that the average rate of research for each tonne of wheat has been around the $1.80 per year mark. This expenditure has created a pool of research into quality, fertilisers, handling and shipping, and this research activity lies behind our great wheat export trade.

I am worried about the new plan. If deregulation is accepted in respect of the domestic market, what will happen to research funds? Under the present scheme it is easy to collect the $1.80, or whatever the sum happens to be, at the source of delivery or payment. That has also been the case with the buyer permit and feed wheat systems which have existed for the past five years. Those who apply for permits ultimately are responsible for putting up research money. However, under a totally deregulated domestic market I am concerned about the future of the industry. I know that it will still be able to be collected from exporters, but if it is not collected on internal sales I am afraid that exporters will have to be charged more.

Each State makes its own collections of revenue by way of wheat volume in the way of research fees, and levies from the Australian Wheat Board are funnelled to each State to distribute and use as they think fit. Different States concentrate on different research areas and that research is then pooled. The fact that the main research ideas and recommendations are pooled reflects on the whole Australian wheat crop. I am happy to say that the accent in Australia has been on quality, cleanliness control and weevil control. This has shown up in the sales of Australian wheat throughout the world. In world markets corrupted by United States and European Common Market subsidies, we have been able to compete because of the quality and cleanliness of our product. I commend the report of the Wheat Research Council to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some remarks on the annual report of the Wheat Research Council 1987-88. I am particularly interested in the reports from the State research committees where the main items of interest to the Australian Democrats are a number of points relating to the fragility of our soils, the use of chemicals, and emphasis on problems with weeds resistant to herbicides, whole farm management strategies and sustainable agriculture. It is good to see such an emphasis in the annual report on those issues, which the Democrats have been putting forward as major issues for Australia's long term agricultural prospects. We welcome these proposals in such annual reports. On page 12 the following statement is made:

SPEECH.PARA: The agro-chemical industry has responded professionally to the development of resistance by the establishment of a `herbicide resistance action committee' but without providing a significant funding commitment to the research being undertaken.

This calls in question the credentials of the agro-chemical industry in attempts such as this, which must be seen as rather cosmetic attempts, to indicate its concern in the area of chemical resistance, especially where that industry sets up committees and then does not put its money where its mouth is. That is in contrast to the wheat industry itself which, as Senator Panizza said, has a fine record in funding its own research. On behalf of the Australian Democrats, I call on the agro-chemical industry, if it is really concerned about these issues, not just to set up committees as fronts to give everybody comfort but also to fund those committees adequately and get on with genuine research if the industry is itself genuine in that effort.

I congratulate in particular the States of Victoria and New South Wales. In this annual report those States go into some detail on those important aspects of the wheat industry such as fragility of the soils, use of chemicals, whole farm management strategies and sustainable agriculture. These issues are important to all agricultural industries. I wish to quote from the report of the Wheat Research Committee for Victoria, which says on page 44 of this annual report:

Soil degradation is becoming a real concern to farmers and to the Government. We believe it is important to continue research in this area to support farmers who are doing some valuable work at the practical level. We believe that one of our great thrusts in the coming year should be working towards what is called sustainable agriculture. This will ensure that the farmer can produce very valuable crops and still maintain or even increase the fertility of the soil.
The committee states in its next paragraph:

The whole farm management strategy would ensure wheat is grown on the most appropriate soil type, using optimal tillage methods, planting times, weed control measures, rotations and machinery systems. Computer modelling of whole farm systems is showing promise . . .

The Democrats can only say `Hear, hear' to that. The Australian Democrats commend the thrust of the Victorian report and the Victorian Government's growing interest in and stated commitment to the promotion of agricultural methods and management practices which emphasise sustainability. I should also like to quote from the report of the New South Wales Wheat Research Committee which, on page 24 of this annual report, says:

One of the major thrusts of the Department's research has been to develop cropping systems which are sustainable in the long term and do not leave the soil as vulnerable to erosion as traditional systems.

I take issue with the word `traditional'. The Democrats prefer the word `conventional' in regard to chemical-dependent agriculture. In fact, many traditional farming practices are chemical free and sustainable practices. Although we always want to move ahead with research and with industry in general, particularly agriculture, we believe that in many ways it behoves us to look back to our fathers and our fathers' fathers to see how they worked in a sustainable way on their land. The Democrats commend the wheat industry for its commitment to its own funding, and in particular the New South Wales and Victorian departments of agriculture, for their stated and emphasised thrust towards sustainable agriculture, which is in the best interests of the wheat industry and of our nation as a whole.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

When the original annual report was presented last year I was critical of elements of it. I now notice that at least one of the points I raised in criticism has been corrected by this corrigenda that has been tabled today. I might say that the list of several items that have been corrected indicates a touch of sloppiness in the preparation of this annual report. It seems to me unfortunate that there has been no effective response to the matters of serious substance that I raised last year about this annual report when it was brought down. I acknowledge the point made subsequently, I think by Senator Beahan, that the loss of $1.5m revealed in the accounts is more an accounting arrangement than an effective loss. But I think it would be useful if the report element of annual reports, as distinct from the accounts, effectively related to the figures shown in the accounts. The Trade Union Training Authority (TUTA) is one of many authorities under this Government whose written reports bear very little relationship to the accounts printed at the back of the document. That was my concern.

I am now interested to see that in this corrigenda tabled today there is a `slight' correction: on page 12 of the report the amount shown under the heading `Salaries and Related Items' for a prior year should be $2.7m and not $700,000. That kind of sloppiness in reporting brings its own consequences; and, of course, the consequence was that the report was strongly criticised by me. I regret that TUTA has not taken this opportunity to state more clearly just what were the consequences of the relocation of its office.
National Library of Australia
National Library of Australia

As I noted when I complained about this report, total expenses of $330,000 were involved in the relocation of the office and the retrenchment of staff when TUTA joined the whole horde of governmental authorities which are changing the location of their head office simply because the head of the organisation, appointed by the Government, is in a different location from that of the previous head or head office of that body. This is monumental waste. It is a disgrace. It seems to be the normal manner in which this Government conducts its business, and I think it should be strongly criticised. DEBATE.TITLE: FILM CENSORSHIP BOARD AND FILMS BOARD OF REVIEW

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.

In these times when we are conducting so much debate on matters with regard to film and video classification, this report is indeed welcomed as being informative and concise. The classification guidelines are clearly stated in this report. I remind the Senate of the classifications that we have in Australia. We have classification G, PG, M, R, X and videos and films which are refused classification. The films and videos which are refused classification are those which include `depictions of child sexual abuse, bestiality, sexual acts accompanied by offensive fetishes, or exploitative incest fantasies'; those which contain `unduly detailed, and/or relished acts of extreme violence or cruelty; explicit or unjustifiable depictions of sexual violence against non-consenting persons'; and those which contain detailed instruction or encouragement in . . . the use of terrorist-type weapons and terrorist acts' and `the abuse of proscribed drugs'.

The classifications for films and videos are the same with regard to R-rated videos; that is, there are virtually no restrictions on language in our films; sexual intercourse or other sexual activity maybe realistically implied or simulated; depictions of sexual violence are acceptable only to the extent that they are necessary to the narrative and not exploitative; violence may be highly realistic and explicit depictions of violence may be shown, but not if unduly detailed, relished or cruel; and drug abuse may be depicted but not in an advocatory manner. Extreme horror special effects usually warrant an R-rated certificate.

The report states that videos have an extra restricted classification if they contain material which includes explicit depictions of sexual acts involving adults, but do not include any depictions suggesting coercion or non-consent of any kind. There is an anomaly in the report because X-rated as a classification is also included for films, so I draw that to the Senate's attention.

There are some interesting statistics in the report with regard to the classifications made by the board during the 1987 year, and I would like to refer briefly to those. As far as videos are concerned, 30.67 per cent came into the G category; 17.67 per cent came into the PG category; 28.71 per cent came into the M category; 14.82 per cent came into the R category; and 6.68 per cent came into the X category. A total of 1.45 per cent was refused classification. It is also of interest to note the origin of the films and videos. The report states that 66.68 per cent of videos came from the United States of America (USA), 10.36 per cent came from the United Kingdom and 7.88 per cent came from Australia. It stated also that 38.13 per cent of films came from the USA, 16.45 per cent came from Hong Kong, which surprises me, 9.53 per cent originated in Australia, while 6.92 per cent came from the United Kingdom. I suggest there is scope for a labour intensive industry to be increased in Australia in the film and video business. I do not have time to refer to the activities of the Board of Review, except to express surprise at the number of videos and films which originally had an R classification but which were, on review, granted an M classification. I suggest that matter needs to be looked into.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I want to raise this matter because I am a little concerned that the Government may seek to take some disciplinary action against the Australian Federal Police arising out of the industrial action that the AFP has taken over recent days. In the circumstances, the industrial action that was taken seems to me to be wholly responsible. The Australian Federal Police has been frustrated by this Government in that in its view, and it is a professional view, it has been unable to meet the statutory requirements of its office to provide the sort of security for the Australian people that it sees as its responsibility. It has been frustrated through a lack of adequate funding and a diversion of funding that has been necessary to a number of major investigations, including the investigation into the murder of Assistant Commissioner Winchester.

Regrettably these matters do occur from time to time, and we on this side of the chamber say that in such circumstances governments should meet their responsibility not only to fund adequately those investigations but also not at a cost to the balance of police work. That was what was occurring in Australia. This Government required the Australian Federal Police to conduct these new and major investigations at a cost to its existing work.

A number of examples have been put to this chamber. They have so frustrated the Australian Federal Police that it has been led to take that course of action, action that as I understand it is unprecedented for this police force. For example, I understand that basically throughout Australia the fraud units and other specialist units of the Australian Federal Police are now required to work office hours only, office hours being from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m. I would have thought that even this Government would have appreciated that a police force cannot operate on office hours.

A matter that was mentioned in this chamber by one of my colleagues a couple of days ago was ignored by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate). Nevertheless, I will repeat it. We have good information that a recent drug surveillance operation in Sydney ceased at 11 p.m. because the police force conducting the operation ran out of overtime. We on this side of the chamber regard it as deplorable that major drug investigations-and they are one of the chief functions of the Australian Federal Police-have to be curtailed in such a way because the force is not adequately funded by this Government.

I refer to another matter-a significant fraud investigation in Sydney, which was to involve a number of search warrants which were to be executed out of office hours because that was the most effective time to gain the material that was being sought. At the last moment that operation had to be cancelled because the police force was unable to provide overtime for the officers concerned. I know that the intelligence and drug operations of the Australian Federal Police in South Australia are being restricted. I regard that as deplorable.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you were Minister, what would you do about the second tier decision?

—If I were the Minister I would meet my responsibility to fund adequately the Australian Federal Police, which has major responsibilities in relation to drug enforcement, anti-terrorist operations and major organised crime in this country. The Minister's failure has led to a situation where the police have taken unprecedented industrial action, not to serve their own purposes but because they are frustrated that they are unable properly to do their job. The Minister has failed in that regard and his Government has failed. The police had to take industrial action to get even $500,000 partly to meet that shortfall. The Minister should have stood up for what he knew was necessary. He said he had sympathy for the position of the AFP, but Hawke and Keating had to make the decisions. What the Minister needs to do is show a bit more strength and leadership in this portfolio and then he might do something about lifting morale in the Australian Federal Police, which is at an all time low.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 296th report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts entitled The Auditor-General: Ally of the People and Parliament-Reform of the Australian Audit Office. I seek leave to move a motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The inquiry which led to this report was the first comprehensive government or parliamentary inquiry into the Australian Audit Office since the Office of the Auditor-General was established at Federation in 1901. In the 88 years since then the Government and the Parliament have changed dramatically and the purpose and conduct of audits have also been transformed. The Committee examined the role of the Australian Audit Office and the Auditor-General in the light of those changes.

I stress that the report stands as an objective assessment of the need for reform of the Australian Audit Office and is above party political considerations. The Committee believes the report will be an enduring contribution to the reform of parliamentary democracy in Australia. It is a document relevant to the reform of the Audit Office not just at the Federal level but in the States and Territories and probably in other jurisdictions as well. It is a document of the Parliament for the Parliament and the people.

The terms of reference for the inquiry were, first, to investigate whether the Australian Audit Office had kept pace with developments in regard to the public audit function in the States and Territories and in comparable countries. The question was answered with a conditional no. The second term of reference concerned whether current arrangements guaranteed the independence and resources necessary for the Australian Audit Office to fulfil its role as determined by the Audit Act 1901. The answer to this question was no.

It must be pointed out that the reasons for these negative answers were largely outside the control of the Auditor-General and the Audit Office. The Auditor-General and the Australian Audit Office are responsible for reassuring Parliament that government's financial management and financial statements are sound. Considering the billions of dollars that the Commonwealth Government collects, manages and spends on behalf of all Australians, such reassurance is a foundation of citizens' belief in government. Without the Auditor-General's examination and reports on Commonwealth accounts, Parliament and ultimately the Australian people have less reason to feel confident in any statement by any department or statutory authority about its income and expenditure.

Therefore a strong and independent Auditor-General and Australian Audit Office are fundamental to the credibility of Audit opinions and the effectiveness of the Auditor-General and his staff. Independence has diminished practical value unless the Auditor-General has the human and material resources to exercise his responsibility. The report addresses the resources question by comparing three approaches to determining how many resources the Auditor-General requires. In theory the Auditor-General, Parliament or Government can determine how many resources are necessary for audit. The inquiry report compares and contrasts how these approaches work in different countries. It concluded that the least desirable basis for maintaining the independence and resources of the Auditor-General and the Audit Office was where the executive government determined audit resources.

Australia is one of the few comparable countries where the Government has such influence over decisions on audit resources. The ideal situation is either where the Auditor-General makes a professional decision on how many resources are necessary for him or her to be able to give an opinion on a government's accounts or where Parliament itself makes that decision. The Canadian Auditor-General has very great discretion over how many resources he needs. The Committee rejected the Canadian model as unsuitable for Australia. The Committee's recommendation was for Parliament to decide on how many resources it wanted to allocate for audit. This approach has been adopted by the British Parliament in recent years with the support of both Government and Opposition.

The Auditor-General audits the Government accounts on behalf of the Parliament and, through the Parliament, on behalf of the Australian people. The Committee believes that fundamental to reform of the Australian Audit Office is a more open and clearer acknowledgment of this Parliament. Consistent with this emphasis, the Committee recommended the establishment of an audit committee of Parliament comprising Government and Opposition members and senators and chaired by the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives alternately. The audit committee of Parliament would advise the Auditor-General on Parliament's audit priorities and make recommendations to Parliament on the Audit Office resources.

I turn to the question of human resources. The Audit Office has very many talented staff. However, in recent years it has lost many able personnel because the salaries of senior and specialist staff have lagged behind incomes available in the private sector. For example, the Australian Audit Office staff member responsible for audit of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation earns from one-third to one-quarter of the income of private sector auditors in charge of the audit of Australia's other large banks. Yet there is no evidence that the standard of the Commonwealth Bank audit is any different from that of private sector audits of very large banks.

Salary differentials between experienced auditors in the private and public sectors are now so substantial that the Audit Office is also having difficulty in recruiting junior staff. Thus there are two problems: how to attract young, new staff and how to maintain senior staff. It is so difficult for the Audit Office to recruit and maintain staff that Parliament must be made aware of the dangers that the current circumstances create for the strength and capacity of the Audit Office. The Committee recommends that the best way to overcome this problem is to establish the Australian Audit Office as a statutory authority and to give the Auditor-General the authority to determine the terms and conditions of employment of staff.

I now turn to the relationship between auditing and a more efficient public sector. The practice of auditing has evolved so that auditors now have techniques to analyse how efficiently Government programs are managed. The authority to conduct efficiency audits was introduced into the Audit Act in 1979 following recommendations of the Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration. Internationally, efficiency audits-or value for money audits, as they are sometimes called-utilise a very large part of the General Accounting Office's resources in the USA, while in Canada and the UK approximately half of the resources of the national audit offices are dedicated to efficiency audits. In comparison, the Australian Audit Office devoted 6 per cent of its resources to efficiency audits in 1987-88. No witness in the inquiry argued that this should continue.

To demonstrate the importance of efficiency audits, I recall that one prominent participant in our inquiry made a point to the effect that when an auditor enters an institution to conduct a regulatory audit the person behind the cash register feels the pressure but when an auditor arrives to conduct an efficiency audit the permanent secretary or head of the organisation gets nervous. A situation wherein only 6 per cent of the Australian Audit Office resources are set aside for efficiency audits is not compatible with a commitment to increase public sector efficiency.

Accordingly, the Committee recommended a major change in the Audit Office's orientation. There can be no reduction in resources for financial and compliance auditing. Therefore the only way in which more resources can be allocated to efficiency audits to improve public sector efficiency is if more resources are allocated to the Australian Audit Office. The Committee has recommended that an additional $3.1m be allocated to the Audit Office in 1989-90. This will increase to an additional $15.7m within five years. Consequently, by 1994-95 approximately 50 per cent of the Australian Audit Office's resources and effort will be for efficiency audits. The effect of this will be to place increased emphasis on maximising the efficiency of the public sector. Despite differing views held by Committee members on the role and size of the public sector, we are on common ground in believing that the public sector, whatever its size, must be both efficient and accountable.

In conclusion, I turn to an issue which lies at the heart of the inquiry, namely, the relationship between executive government and the Parliament. The year 1988-89 was the 300th anniversary of the drafting in London of the Bill of Rights. This Bill of Rights was one of the foundations of parliamentary democracy not just in the United Kingdom but in many other countries around the world, including Canada, New Zealand and Australia. One achievement of the Bill of Rights was to assert executive government's accountability to the entire Parliament. The United Kingdom Exchequer and Audit Department Act 1866 on which the Australian Audit Act 1901 was based was another milestone in the evolution of accountability of government to Parliament. Indicative of the importance of the Audit Act 1901 was the fact that it was the fourth Act to be passed by the first Australian Parliament.

The report of the inquiry into the Audit Office points the next step forward to strengthen public sector accountability to the Australian Parliament. Political activity in the twentieth century in Australia has been characterised by the increasing domination of Parliament by the executive government. This increasing domination has occurred whichever political party or coalition has been in power. The results of the inquiry into the Australian Audit Office now provide the Parliament with an opportunity to strengthen the accountability of Executive Government to Parliament. For this purpose the Committee has recommended the repeal of the Audit Act 1901 and its replacement by two laws-a new Audit Act and a new financial administration Act for the Commonwealth. New audit legislation will be a cornerstone for relationships between Parliament and the Government for the remainder of this century and into the next. It is my deepest hope that the report will be the catalyst for further reform in this particular area.

I have a few further comments to make on this report. It is a recommendation of the Committee that an advisory committee be established by the Auditor-General with representatives from the private sector, universities and auditees to advise him on developments in private sector audit. This should be a milestone in the evolution of auditing procedures and practices. A further recommendation is that an additional committee be established to advise the Auditor-General on audit practices and ensure that the principal government audit authority is fully aware of practices in private enterprise in the field audit.

A further matter that must be drawn to the attention of the Senate is that there be established an interchange scheme to provide officers of the Australian Audit Office with the opportunity to be seconded to the private sector firms. Right at the end of the report there is a recommendation which I believe to be quite important. The Committee recommends that the Australian Audit Office plan for a new building within or close to the Parliamentary Triangle and that the new building be called Audit House. We are already aware of problems concerning the stability of its present office. I believe that this would provide a physical recognition of the close relationship between the Australian Audit Office and the separation of the Audit Office from other government departments which do not have the same important linkage.

I am also concerned about a number of issues that may come to light unless the Government provides adequate resources to the Australian Audit Office. In the report we have drawn attention to an increase in responsibility for the Australian Audit Office. I draw attention to recommendation 38, which says that it should devote significant resources to follow up performance audits. That has certainly been a criticism in the past. It recommends that it adopt a systematic approach to follow-up performance audit findings. Recommendation 39 says that follow-up procedures for performance audits should be linked to follow-up procedures for regularity audits. In addition, in section 76 we recommend that the Australian Audit Office undertake an efficiency audit of the internal audit of the Commonwealth sector.

One of the problems nowadays under this new philosophy of risk management is that many departmental secretaries are sacrificing the internal audit function under this concept of risk management. I believe that this attitude is just not good enough. It is certainly putting additional responsibilities on the Australian Audit Office.

I am deeply concerned that while we are talking about giving additional responsibilities to the Audit Office to undertake to audit statutory marketing authorities, and so on, some of the audits they are currently doing are quite unsatisfactory. For example, at the Public Accounts Committee inquiry into the Antarctic today the Auditor-General said that on only three occasions within 10 years had it audited aspects of the Antarctic Division in Hobart. Given the history of that particular institution, that is clearly not good enough. When we further questioned how comprehensive those audits were, we found out that they covered only certain aspects of the operation. In other words, a cyclical approach was used. Under such circumstances, this leads to severe questioning of the stewardship of certain assets owned by the Commonwealth.

I call upon the Government not only to provide additional resources but also to ensure that the Australian Audit Office more comprehensively audits on a more regular basis those responsibilities which come within its present domain.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to take note of the report of the Public Accounts Committee, I want to support the remarks of my colleague Senator Watson in directing the Senate's attention, and hopefully its careful study, to the report of the Committee entitled The Auditor-General: Ally of the People and Parliament. As Senator Watson said, it is a bipartisan report in the sense that there is a commitment by all members of the Committee to truly strengthen the role of the Auditor-General and use him as the method of accounting to the Parliament and therefore to the people for the expenditure of Government moneys.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Watson has already outlined many of the important findings of the report but there are one or two points I would like to mention specially. We are all concerned about the increase-the creeping increase, in a way-in the ways in which executive government is taking over the function of the Parliament and in which the function of accounting to the Parliament is becoming less and less. Of particular concern to me is the practice that this Government has entered into of pushing more and more government functions off the budget sheet so that the appropriations are not made and are therefore not subject to scrutiny through the Estimates committees. Once a function of government is corporatised, or whatever other mechanism the Government chooses to use, and it is pushed off Budget, the Minister tends to say, `It is at arm's length and therefore I am not accountable'. From my point of view, I find the answer to the dilemma to be privatisation. Those activities, if privatised, would then be answerable to shareholders. Bearing in mind that that is presently not the case, there is a concern that where Government moneys are spent the scrutiny and accountability are of a different standard from that used by private auditors when auditing either public or private companies.

I think it is most important to realise that the only link this Parliament has with many government business enterprises-with so-called corporatised activities-is the Auditor-General. There has also been evidence to suggest that some of these organisations be given permission to use private auditors and to bypass the Auditor-General. When I say that my very strong feeling is that it should be the Auditor-General who continues this auditing process, I am in no way disparaging the work, the ethics or the ability of private audit firms. I am merely saying it because I believe that where public moneys are expended, the responsibility of reporting to the Parliament is different from that of a board of directors reporting to its shareholders. Therefore, the role of the Auditor-General is a different role from the role of auditors in the private sector. I find that with the practice we presently have in place, whereby the executive arm of Government, via the Department of Finance, determines what the resources of the Auditor-General are, executive government can effectively curtail the activities of the Auditor-General. I find that is very strongly against the public interest. The report recommends one way in which there can be an interaction between the Auditor-General and using the skills of the private sector: that is for the Auditor-General to be able to use the private sector as a contractor in some approved instances. I think this could be a very useful development. But the responsibility must finally be for the Auditor-General to be the continuing link between this Parliament and the expenditure of Government moneys.

There is another strong recommendation made to which I would like to draw particular attention because I have had cause to look at this question in another committee. Recommendation 35 recommends amendment of section 48C of the existing Audit Act but, hopefully, if our recommendation to repeal the old Act and introduce fresh legislation is accepted, then, accordingly, a fresh section would be drafted that would carry out the recommendation. That recommendation is that the Auditor-General would be permitted to conduct an efficiency audit on an eligible incorporated company without a Minister's permission; further, that the definition of `eligible incorporated company' be amended to give effect to the Committee's concerns that the current definition excludes a company which is incorporated as an initiative of the Commonwealth and which receives the majority of its funding from the Commonwealth but which for policy reasons has a board of directors on which Commonwealth representatives are in a minority. This is exactly the sort of situation I was talking about before. Immediately prior to that recommendation there is a paragraph which I think is important to read. It is paragraph 12.18 on page 170 of the report which states:

The Committee is rather concerned that the definition of `eligible incorporated company' is excessively narrow in that it is limited to circumstances where the incorporated company is one over which the Commonwealth is in a position to exercise control. Such a definition excludes a company which is incorporated at the intention of the Commonwealth and which receives the majority of its funding from the Commonwealth but which for some public policy reason has a representative board of directors in which the Commonwealth representatives are in a minority-
as per the recommendation-

An example is the Australian Bicentennial Authority, ABA, which was incorporated at the behest of the Commonwealth, performed important national functions and which received the majority of its funds from the Commonwealth. The Auditor-General did not have the power under the 1979 Amendments to conduct an efficiency audit of the ABA without the permission of the ABA or the Minister.

That permission was asked for but was not forthcoming and, accordingly, the efficiency audit was not carried out. We found that to be an unacceptable practice. It is simply not acceptable for an efficiency audit to depend upon an auditee granting permission.

Overall, this report is profound. It deals with the importance of the office of Auditor-General. It deals in great detail with the options for reform that are available. It comes down with a set of finely tuned recommendations covering the interaction between the expenditure of public moneys by executive government as authorised by the Parliament-by way of the appropriations, and scrutinised under Estimates and Government moneys which are spent without such scrutiny. If people think of the Auditor-General, as we have entitled the report, as `an ally of the people and Parliament', and the report is considered in that way, then it ought to have bipartisan support. Its recommendations ought to be introduced as soon as possible and dealt with by the Government.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report deals with the somewhat limited role that the Museum has as a consequence of the Government putting it somewhat on ice. The report refers to the functions of the Museum as being to develop and maintain a national collection of historical material and to exhibit, or make available for exhibition by others, historical material from the national historical collection or historical material that is otherwise in the possession of the Museum. It goes on to list the other activities and functions that the Museum is able to undertake. It is a pity that this Government seems to lack commitment to the Museum. The Museum of Australia would be totally different from any other museum that exists in any other part of Australia, and is holding and collecting material which has a quite different purpose and function from the museums which already exist. It seems to me that within the Government there are people who do not understand the reason why it was established and the function and purpose that it is to carry out. It is a great pity that, in the year of the bicentenary, the Government chose to downgrade the advancement of the Museum and did not get on with the construction of it. I would have thought that the bicentenary year was the year to give it a boost. I am well aware that the Government has got the economy into serious difficulties and that money is short, but even at such a time there are certain things which ought to be done for the longer term benefit of Australians who will want to see much of the material that, I believe, is being lost because the Museum is not able to get on with the work that it was established to do. It is doing something quite different from the States, and that needs to be recognised.

SPEECH.PARA: The other thing that perhaps it ought to be doing is getting on with looking after and developing the old Parliament House. This is a matter that I have been speaking about now for some four years or more. The old Parliament House is being left to be taken over by the cockroaches. At the same time, the Government is busily planning to put a child-care centre in its grounds without determining what should happen to the building first. There is a good case for suggesting that it should be restored to its 1927 configuration and be made available to the Australian people as a political and constitutional museum. I believe that we are losing material of that era that ought to be in that building and ought to be made available. The Museum of Australia is the organisation which ought to have the responsibility for that and, of course, the funding that would enable it to proceed. I trust that I will not need to speak in a similar vein this time next year when the National Museum of Australia annual report comes before the Senate and that reasonable funding will be made available to enable us to protect the heritage of this country and know that our children and grandchildren will have the benefit and understanding of what has gone before. It is all very well to shout that we have not got the money, but there are some things that need to be done in balance and in harmony, and this is one of them. I urge the Government to see that the report next year does not start of by saying, `For the third year in succession the National Museum of Australia was very much on hold'. Hopefully, that will not be the case.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I could take the rest of the afternoon talking about health in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT), but I shall refrain from doing so. I have frequently spoken on this before. Most people in Canberra and nationally realise by now that, as a consequence of Medicare, the health services in the Australian Capital Territory have, in some instances, almost ground to a halt. There are a couple of aspects of this matter that I wish to refer to-in particular, the rehabilitation and aged care services. I remind the Senate that we do not have enough beds for those who need to be in nursing homes. A number of people who need 24-hour care and nursing home care are in hospital beds but we have not yet managed to find sufficient resources to look after adequately the people who, perhaps, having stayed in their own homes for as long as they possibly could, finally get to the stage where they need the care that can be provided only in a nursing home. We have not done well enough in this community to provide for those people.

SPEECH.PARA: The other group we have not taken adequate care of are those who suffer from mental illness. The report under the heading of `Mental Health Services and Intellectual Disability Services' deals with the services available. To the extent that the Health Authority is dealing in these areas with the resources that it has, it is doing its best. But the clear fact is that we are not adequately providing services for those who are suffering from, in particular, schizophrenia and certainly not for the families who are attempting to deal with it. All too often one hears of suicides and other tragedies affecting people that are not able to get the services required. Frequently they will not be admitted to Woden Valley Hospital when they are taken there. They drift around from one place to another.

Somehow, we just do not seem to have got on to the right wavelength to deal with the tragedy of this problem in our community. There are a number of rehabilitation facilities and services but we are not doing well enough, particularly for the group that I have mentioned. While recognising what is referred to here, it is an area where we have a great deal more to do in the Australian Capital Territory before we can feel that we have dealt with the problem.

I commend the health service on the program that is provided to promote the immunisation of children against measles. It is referred to on page 24 of this report. I recently attended on a somewhat wet afternoon the Teddy Bears' health service, on the lawns outside the old Parliament House. It was held on the last day of the festivities in conjunction with the Canberra Festival and the Family Day. Many members of the Australian Capital Territory Health and Community Services Department gave of their time that day to encourage parents to realise the necessity for immunisation against measles and to encourage children to participate in a way which was meaningful for them. An excellent facility was set up. Cath Bourke, who is the ACT Citizen of the year, opened the day. It gladdened one's heart to see the number of little people there with their bears at the bears' immunisation clinic. It is certainly the right way to go about making every endeavour to eliminate this disease. It is being dealt with most effectively in the Australian Capital Territory.

Others could perhaps take a leaf out of this book and proceed with the same sort of programs. Similarly, I mention the scoliosis screening in Australian Capital Territory high schools. There can be no doubt that prevention in these areas is the much better course.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: HEALTH, POLITICS, TRADE: CONTROLLING CHEMICAL RESIDUES IN AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Science and Technology Council Report

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This is the report from the Australian Science and Technology Council entitled Health, Politics, Trade: Controlling Chemical Residues in Agricultural Products. I comment first on the membership of the Australian Science and Technology Council. It masquerades-I think that is the appropriate term-under the title ASTEC: This report considers the controlling of chemical residues in agricultural products. When one looks at the membership of ASTEC one finds that there is probably only one person on that Council who could claim expertise in any sense in this area. That fact is worth noting. This Council often has these sorts of matters referred to it. It has a certain aura of authority about it which perhaps, when one looks at it, is belied by the membership.

The two matters I particularly want to comment on today are the failure of the Government adequately to fund research in the area of alternatives to chemicals and the fact that the executive summary makes some rather interesting comments when, in one place, it states that there is a surplus of agricultural products, but in another, further on, it seems to accept the valuations that, I am almost certain, have been given to it by the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Association of Australia (AVCAA). As to the benefit of agricultural chemicals, one could argue that we would be better off if we even suffered some diminution in productivity because the price of food would substantially increase. That might be to the benefit of the producers. Having said that, and having pointed out that health authorities generally do not regard the European Community's action with respect to chemical residues in food as warranted, the report continues:
Consumers who can afford to choose have made it clear that chemical quality is a factor in what they buy, regardless of assurances from health authorities.

Therein lies a very significant indicator for Australia, in that our overseas trade in food produced in this country will be increasingly dependent upon our ability to assure overseas consumers that our food is free of contact with agricultural chemicals and, should we further entertain food irradiation, that it has not been irradiated. The report states, in effect, that for this reason there is a need for research into alternatives to chemicals. It continues:
Research and development expenditure on alternatives in 1988 was only 2 per cent of that spent by farmers on chemicals. This expenditure is inadequate to meet long-term market requirements.

One finds a very serious criticism of the Government, which has very substantially cut funding for the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation in precisely those areas in which CSIRO was carrying out research into integrated pest management and methods of biological control which would avoid the use of heavy applications of chemicals or, in some cases, avoid the applications of chemicals altogether. As I have pointed out previously-but it needs stressing-the Government is being quite naive if it believes that private industry will take up the funding of that research work. The industry that may take up such funding, of course, is the chemical industry. The chemical industry would find it inimical to its short term interests to fund that sort of research. Therefore, that research is simply not being funded. ASTEC recommends as follows:
We consider that increased expenditure on alternatives to chemicals would be economically sensible-
I stress, `would be economically sensible'. The organisation is making a judgment, not about the health value, but that it would be economically sensible to do this. It continues:
and will be essential to meet the new demands of the market place.

Again, there is an emphasis on the economic aspects; yet we find this Government cutting the amount of money that it is spending in this area and naively expecting private industry to pick up an area of research which private industry, by the very nature of things, will simply not pick up. The report specifically stresses that in this research it is important that CSIRO maintain its research emphasis on alternatives to agricultural chemicals. It states that the Australian Research Council should establish a key centre of research and teaching in integrated pest management, which I find a rather peculiar recommendation. When CSIRO is carrying out that work, why should a new body be established to do that work? The report continues:
. . . the establishment of integrated pest management as a priority by State Departments of Agriculture . . .

Surely, this is the sort of work which should be integrated with the body which has traditionally carried out this work, and carried out this work extremely well, as Senator Powell indicated earlier. Finally, the report stresses that there should be a greatly increased commitment by the Rural Industry Research Fund to fund this research.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, wish to make some remarks on the report by the Australian Science and Technology Council (ASTEC) entitled Health, Politics, Trade, which is a report on controlling chemical residues in agricultural products. It is a study which was set in train in the aftermath of the chemical residue problem, highlighted by the problem with our beef exports to the United States which resulted in a $20m screening program for organochlorine residues being mounted. A clearance program for over 100,000 farms Australia-wide was mounted. The report notes that, as of January this year, 1,000 farms still remain quarantined. Clearly, it is a major problem, at least in that industry. The section entitled `Executive Summary' reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The major conclusion of the report is that chemical residues are not an undue health hazard to consumers of Australian agricultural produce, but chemical residues are an important factor in the marketing of this produce.
In chapter one of the report we find this comment:

. . . there are about 400 active ingredients used in agricultural chemicals sold in Australia. Furthermore, knowledge of the effects of particular chemicals is changing all the time, and regulatory systems must take this into account. Despite these difficulties, we feel confident in stating that chemical residues in agricultural products are not an undue health hazard to consumers of Australian agricultural produce . . .

My colleague Senator Coulter has drawn attention to another comment in the report in which ASTEC notes that those consumers who can afford to are choosing chemical free produce and that this is therefore opening up a market, which leads ASTEC to make recommendations of an economic nature. Clearly, the community does not accept that major conclusion, and therein lie both an opportunity and a challenge for the Australian agricultural sector and for the Australian community as a whole.

I draw attention to a warning in the report that we need more analytical chemists to meet this challenge. I believe that we need appropriate forms and methods of analysis, especially with regard to the chemical cocktail. We must go beyond looking at one chemical component in perhaps one food product. We need to be able to look at the context of everybody's personal workplace and social environment with regard to chemicals.

I focus for the few minutes remaining to me on the recommendation on funding for research on effective and economic alternatives. I stress, as Senator Coulter has, that ASTEC puts forward proposals for increased funding on the basis that they make good economic sense-a point which the Australian Democrats, since they came to this place and even before then, have been making for many years. It is good to see it repeated in this report. We hope that as a nation we are able to take up this challenge. I draw attention to comments on the method of funding. Senator Coulter has already mentioned some of those. The report makes the following point:
It is important to recognise that, unlike chemicals, biological control and biotechnology methods generally do not provide patentable products that can be sold to recoup development costs.
Therefore, it will not be done by the private sector, which is profit oriented or, at the very least cost recovery oriented. The report continues:

Such research will not be funded through the individual rational decisions of producers expressed in a conventional economic market, but must either be funded by producers through a levy system or by Government.

I do not want us to exclude the possibility that it be funded through a levy on chemicals. Only 2 per cent of the value of chemicals used by farmers in this country goes into research at present. If, for instance, we added a 2 per cent levy, we would double the amount of funding available by that one means alone. We must meet the needs of the market. We must meet this challenge as a nation. We must see it as a fully national challenge, not just something which is confined to the agricultural sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.

These papers deal with International Labour Conference conventions or recommendations concerning the welfare, health and repatriation of seafarers. These International Labour Organisation (ILO) conventions are designed to protect all seafarers in all ports. Nobody would have any quarrel about that. However, there has been too little time to examine these conventions and recommendations in close detail and to consider their implications in the light of the past history of this Government's handling of these matters.

Honourable senators may recall that the ILO sets the guidelines for the standard of ships. In 1986 our Navigation Act was amended to give the Government power to prescribe health conditions which could be imposed on foreign registered ships visiting Australian ports. This was purported to be in accordance with article 4 of the ILO convention No. 147, which says in effect that we may take measures necessary to rectify any conditions on board a foreign registered ship which are clearly hazardous to safety or health.

It is clearly reasonable that Australia should have the power to enforce suitable health and safety standards on foreign registered ships, but only in cases which affect our own interests or the safety or health of our own people. In 1987 we introduced a set of marine orders which allowed this Government to enforce standards on foreign ships-not only ILO standards but standards far in excess of those recommended by the ILO. For instance, we insisted in these marine orders that flyscreens be fitted to all portholes, ventilators and doors. These are not required by the ILO conventions. In other words, we could detain ships on such a trivial matter in this country. We can also detain ships if light fittings are not fitted with globes or tubes to the full value of the fitting. One can make an argument that these things should be done, but it is a question of whether it is our job to enforce them in foreign ships when they in no way affect the safety or health of our community. But we have done it. I will give the Senate just one example.

On 11 November 1987 we delayed a foreign ship for four days because it had light covers missing in toilets and showers and had light fittings and bulbs missing from the crew's recreation rooms. None of this was our business, nor was it required by the ILO convention.

Honourable senators might like to look at paper No. 7 on the list, which deals with the welfare facilities and amenities which should be provided on board ship for the benefit of the crew. These include television viewing and the reception of radio broadcasts, projection of films or videos, stock of which should be adequate for the voyage, sports equipment, exercise equipment, table games and deck games, a library, facilities for recreational handicrafts, and the provision of bars on board ships. I am not saying that these things might not be desirable on board ships, but the question is: should we have the right to enforce these on foreign flag ships? We all know that militant unions have harassed and disrupted foreign owned ships in the past to the detriment of our exports and imports and our whole community. I am worried lest these conventions might provide more ammunition for future disruptions.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The slender annual report of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Pricing Authority, which is six pages in length, reports on a six-month period, yet it has taken nine months to reach Parliament, and the covering letter inside it is not dated, so we do not know where the hold-up was. The report claims that the Pharmaceutical Benefits Pricing Authority is `more independent' than the bureau which it replaced. But one wonders what is meant by this when the Authority is merely implementing this Labor Government's haphazard policy in this area under tight ministerial control. And what is the policy? It is an application of bandaids, without proper review, to a scheme badly in need of major remedial surgery.

I find it interesting to note that the consumer nominee on the Authority is not identified as a member of any of the bodies which make up the Consumers Health Forum, but is listed as a consultant to the Health Forum and his background, we understand, is another Government department. The reason I mention this is that the pharmacists and consumers of pharmaceuticals should be aware of the membership of the Authority and assess whether such are in a position `to represent accurately the views of the majority of the community who do not belong to organised groups'. That quote is from the Government's own review of community participation when the Consumers Health Forum was established by the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett).

Page 4 of this six-page report reveals that the major beneficiaries-if we can really currently call them that-of this scheme are pensioners. Eighty-two per cent of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme budget is spent on pensioners, most of whom would be age pensioners. Basically, we are talking about a scheme for the elderly. This Government has set in train vast policy changes, many of which have had an impact on the older Australian. There have been changes to the income and assets tests on pensions, capital gains taxes, nursing home and hostel funding, Medicare and health insurance, and now, to cap it off, the aged have to come to terms with their pills being in different packets with different names. If those on the other side of the Senate do not think this has been an added burden, let them go into pharmacies across this nation to hear how it is. Pharmacist after pharmacist will tell them that the new policy is a shemozzle. In fact, I would have to resort to unparliamentary language to quote what pharmacists have said. The latest confusion strengthens the Opposition's earlier call for a total review of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme.

The report before us justifies the latest round of changes, which came into effect last Saturday-April Fools' Day-as being needed to offset, in part, the costs of the Government's industry development policy. It has been the cruellest kind of April Fools joke on the sick and elderly of this nation. Twenty-one branded drugs have been delisted. The generic drugs supposed to replace them have simply not been available for much of this week from the wholesalers. Pharmacists around the country are reporting that there are no supplies of generics, and that the supplies of the delisted substitutes have dried up as well because of the change. The drug users are confused-and no wonder.

The Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) issued a question and answer kit for members and senators which pharmacists have described to me as being full of misrepresentations, inaccuracies and untruths. The Australian Pensioners Federation has been enlisted as part of this propaganda exercise-like the Price Watch business. It in turn cited as its authority such organisations as the Consumers Health Forum, a body which was set up by the Government and whose representative nature is very doubtful where the majority of consumers are concerned.

It is high time that this Government came to terms with the fact that this is an ageing society and that ageing inevitably produces health problems. We need a comprehensive review of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme that takes this fundamental into account. We do not need more April Fools tricks played on our elderly citizens. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
