INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received, through His Excellency the Governor-General, from the Governor of the State of New South Wales a certificate of the choice by the Parliament of New South Wales of John Philip Faulkner as a senator to fill the vacancy in the representation of that State caused by the resignation of Senator Arthur Thomas Gietzelt.

INTERJECT.PARA: The certificate was laid on the table and read by the Clerk.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Senator John Philip Faulkner made and subscribed the affirmation of allegiance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Pharmaceutical Benefits Pricing Authority was established as a non-statutory body on 1 January 1988. Its role is to review the prices of products listed under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. Its report for the year ended 30 June 1988 provides an opportunity for us to review the principles and objectives of the Authority. Of particular interest is the section dealing with the factors considered in the setting of prices. These prices have an impact on manufacturers, wholesalers, pharmacists, and ultimately on consumers who pay the cost of the drug. The report also spells out the means by which prices are calculated. It is interesting to note that one of the factors, and one which I would certainly support, is the level of activity being undertaken by the Authority in Australia, including new investment, production and research and development where the activity is oriented towards international competitiveness. This factor obviously serves to develop in our country an internationally competitive pharmaceutical products industry.

SPEECH.PARA: It would be remiss of me not to take this opportunity to bring to the Senate's attention action which Tasmanian pharmacists were forced to take recently as a result of the treatment they have been receiving from this Government. I understand that Senator Watson spoke on this subject during today's lunchtime proceedings. On Tuesday 22 March 1989, 171 out of 176 chemists in Tasmania created history by closing their doors for three hours. The stop-work meeting was organised by the Tasmanian branch of the Pharmacy Guild of Australia to protest in the strongest terms the changes to the health system in the last 16 months, particularly the dropping of 12 brands of drugs from the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. That Tasmanian pharmacists were forced to take such drastic action does not surprise me in the least. I have had so many protests from chemists over the way in which they have been treated, and I know that this House has had thousands of signatures presented to it in the form of petitions and in other ways.

Much of the treatment which pharmacists have been receiving relates to the wish of the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) to trim $300m from the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. As a result bureaucrats have been experimenting with a number of means by which they can achieve these cutbacks. However, it is the chemists and patients who are suffering the most. The payment of claims has been inexcusably slow and this has caused severe financial hardship, particularly for chemists operating in rural areas. On more than one occasion I have presented petitions and concerns to the Minister on these matters. The Government does not seem to realise that chemists are forced to pay for supplies which they receive from wholesalers, and yet the Government does not provide the payments to allow this to happen. It has been brought to my attention that many pharmacists could be facing bankruptcy if the situation does not change.

A further concern is the decision by the Government to drop 12 brands of drugs from the pharmaceutical benefits scheme from 1 April and to replace them with alternative generic brands. This move has caused confusion and a great deal of discussion in the community. The elderly and the chronically ill are the least able to cope with this initiative. Further problems have been experienced in Tasmania because half the generic equivalent drugs are out of stock and unavailable in the State. Though doctors have been in a position where they have been obliged to prescribe the alternatives, chemists have been unable to fill the prescriptions. The Pharmacy Guild's Tasmanian Branch President, Mr John Cleary, informed me that Tasmanian wholesalers were out of stock of many of these drugs.

In defence of its situation the Government has claimed that pharmacists were deliberately misleading the public. It was also claimed by the Federal Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), along with Mr Duncan Kerr, the member for Denison, and Senator Devereux, that all the drug brands which were delisted had an alternative and that therefore no patients would be disadvantaged. The facts are that the drug ammonium chloride, which is used by paraplegics to control the acidity level in their urine and to prevent urinary tract infections, is no longer available under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. No alternative exists; so the drug must be purchased at the full rate. That is an absolute disgrace. It should be changed by this Government immediately.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

I have the honour to be one of the two representatives of the Parliament on the Council of the National Library of Australia, and I want to say a few words in that capacity. The first matter I want to mention is that the Chairman of the Council at the time covered by this report was Morris West. Morris West has since retired. I would like to commend him for his excellent service to the Council and to the nation in that capacity. I have found him a most impressive person-one who has, obviously, not only a great capacity but also a great humility. His contribution to the Library leaves a mark that will demonstrate his wider contribution to the Australian community. He will be replaced by Sir Ninian Stephen, somebody who also exhibits both of those qualities. I am sure that he also will carry on the fine tradition of chairmanship and leadership that Morris West has set.

Morris West took as his charter a responsibility to extend the public programs of the Library. He had a great belief that it was important that the Library, its staff and its collections were effectively taken to the people. This promotion or extension of the Library into the community was his goal. The list of the Library's exhibitions which appears in this annual report provides an ample demonstration of the success of his charter. The highlight of this year's exhibition was, of course, the Library's major bicentennial exhibition, People, Print & Paper, a celebration of the books of Australia. This exhibition celebrated 200 years of Australian life and culture through its books, writers, printers, booksellers and publishers. The standard of presentation and the quality of the exhibits, most of which came from the National Library's own collection, again demonstrated the depth and strength not only of the collection but also of the people who work for and who are involved in supporting the Library.

Since this annual report was written there has been a more controversial exhibition, which some of my colleagues have mentioned before-the constitutional exhibition. Certainly some of the matters in that exhibition gave cause for an interpretation of bias. I want to put on the public record tonight that I am absolutely satisfied that there was no deliberate attempt at bias on the part of the National Library staff. It would be the last thing that they would want to do.

In these few minutes I also want to make mention of the leadership role that the National Library plays in the library community in Australia. I would like to record a recognition of the work that is done by the Director-General, Warren Horton, and his staff, which rightly claims that distinction. Their leadership and professionalism is something that I admire, and something of which this Parliament should be proud. I am very pleased to be able to say that here tonight.

The last matter I want to raise is my one matter of regret, but I feel I have no choice but to mention it in these few comments. I refer to the attitude of this Government to the funding of the National Library, particularly to the book vote. I remind the Government that reducing the book vote creates a loss to the nation that can never be recovered. I think that was demonstrated by the estimates last year. I have time to say only that, in terms of monographs and printed books, the Library estimated that approximately 50 per cent of its purchasing power had been lost due to this Government's attitude to funding of the Library's book vote which led to reductions in real terms. That is a matter of great regret. It shows a distortion of priorities. Such priorities are not in the best interests of this nation. We had promises from Senator Richardson when he had a ministerial responsibility in this area. I would like to think that the Government would finally positively address this question and do something for the benefit of the nation in this regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although I want to support most of the remarks that Senator Hill made in speaking to his motion to take note of the annual report of the National Library of Australia, I do not wish to join that list of people who always say that they support a tighter fiscal policy but then advocate increasing spending in every area they discuss. I do not intend to pursue that line of double standard, but I do want to support Senator Hill in the positive remarks he made about the Library. As a senator representing the area in which the National Library is found, I get more opportunity than most-perhaps not more than Senator Hill, who is on the Council-to observe and take advantage of the activities at the Library. I particularly want to join with Senator Hill in his comments about the excellent work that is done by the Director-General, Warren Horton, and the staff there, not just for what they do within the National Library but also for giving impetus to the wider library community. I want to come back to that later.

SPEECH.PARA: I also want to comment upon the diversity of activity that takes place in the Library. In recent years it has certainly been opened up and become a much more active and contributing part of Australian society. I say that deliberately; it is not just an active and contributing part of Canberra society. I want to make particular reference to the National Poetry Awards which it sponsors, which of course are not local awards; they are contested by people all around Australia. I had the honour of presenting the awards this year in the Library. I think the contribution it makes to Australian literature is substantial and entirely appropriate.

I note with interest also some of the political manuscripts which the National Library has collected this year, including those from Clyde Cameron, Norman Makin, Sir John Cramer, Wal Fife and a number of other interesting citizens, including David Williamson. Those things will make a substantial contribution to our culture and heritage, although some people may not always enjoy everything they find in Clyde Cameron's papers.

I want particularly to refer to the role the National Library played in supporting and bringing into being the National Library Summit this year. I addressed the dinner at that summit and tried to give my views about the role of libraries and the way in which they should go about developing a strategy to improve libraries in Australia. Out of that summit came a number of important agreements about the preservation priorities for Australian libraries; about establishing a central database, operated through the National Library of Australia as the major component of a national database for the foreseeable future; and about a national plan, which I think is very important, for improving access to information for remote users. There was talk about the primary responsibility of the public library to serve as the first point of access to information for the general public and to the national system of library and information services. It called for a strong funding partnership by the three levels of government. That is one of the important things about libraries in Australia. They are in one of the few areas that are supported by all three levels of government.

I conclude by again endorsing the things Senator Hill said about the good work which the Library does and by congratulating my Labor colleague Manfred Cross, who was Acting Chairman of the Council for some time this year and has made an outstanding contribution to the Library over the years. I hope that when he retires from the Parliament the Government can find its way open to reappoint him to the Council as a member. I am sure Senator Hill would agree he has had a longstanding commitment--

TALK.START.PARA: —The new Government will.
—Yes. He will make a very good contribution and I hope he can continue to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, I want to quote from the final paragraph of Warren Horton's introductory remarks to the final report of the National Library Summit. He said:
We have now an agreed broad agenda for the better development of library services to the people of Australia.

I hope that over the years we can implement that broad agenda and make information available to the people of Australia in the way that librarians and people who work in the information industry would like to do. I hope that the National Library can continue to play a positive role in that area.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION INTO ABORIGINAL DEATHS IN CUSTODY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to speak about the first Muirhead Interim Report on the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. There are five reports noted and I wish to speak about the report of the inquiry into the death of Charles Sydney Michael. Charles Michael was an Aboriginal Australian who died at Barton's Mill Prison in Western Australia on 9 October 1984, aged 31 years. I quote from the report:

SPEECH.PARA: The primary cause of death was myocardial infarction. He was suffering a serious heart condition, atheroma and coronary thrombosis, and the findings at autopsy prove he was prone to a fatal attack. This was unkown to the prison . . . authorities.

The disturbing feature is that when he died he was face down on the floor of the Senior Officer's small office, handcuffed, ankles secured together by a belt, another belt securing the handcuffs to the ankle restraint. He died following or during a struggle with several prison officers during which he remained at all times on the floor. No attempt was made to resuscitate him. At the time he was pronounced dead by a local medical practitioner he was beyond all aid and his body, trussed as it was, was there to be seen by the doctor and the investigating police upon their arrival . . .

Photographs were taken of the body of Charles Michael in that state. In other words, he was hogtied, and during a scuffle while still hogtied he died on the floor. When it was realised that he was unconscious, no attempt was made either to untie him or to resuscitate him. Mr Olive, counsel for the Committee to Defend Black Rights, puts the position on a different plane. He stated:

This is a shameful affair in which the supervisor bears prime responsibility although all prison officers share the guilt for their failure to act in a prompt and humane way-to accept the fact that a fellow human being was dying, was seriously ill, and needed their attention.

I suggest that such restraints are an infringement of the international covenant on human rights, to which we are a signatory. This is a very serious matter indeed. Commissioner Muirhead said in his findings:
I must accept the findings of Dr Pocock upon autopsy, namely that the direct cause of death was acute myocardial infarction due to coronary thrombosis and atheroma.

Commissioner Muirhead goes on to say that that condition had not been diagnosed previously. In fact, just a month before Michael's death, he underwent surgery at the Fremantle Hospital and there was no indication of heart trouble then. On 7 September he was certified fit to return to Barton's Mill Prison where, as I said before, he died on 9 October. What is very interesting about that is that I have seen a videotape of a program put out by Granada Television in the United Kingdom from a program called The World in Action. That tape has not been shown on television or anywhere else publicly in Australia. There are two re-enactments of Michael's death on that tape, One according to the warders' account and the other according to the accounts of other prisoners and witnesses who did hear some of the sounds made. On that videotape the pathologist, Dr Pocock, who was the pathologist in charge at the time and who conducted the autopsy, actually states that to some extent he has changed his mind. He has conceded that as Michael was hogtied and warders were sitting on him while he was on the floor, this may have contributed to his death.

Articles have appeared in the West Australian, both today and yesterday, about another young person, Stephen Wardle, aged 18, who died in the Perth lockup while being kept overnight on a charge. Although that inquest has now finished, and the findings are that he died of natural causes, the police internal investigation squad is now looking into allegations of police misconduct made by his stepfather. I hope that Commissioner Muirhead's recommendations about a review of our coronial system are seriously looked into, because a lot of people are not satisfied with the way that our coronial inquiries are conducted. There is insufficient independence and the coroner is too closely associated with police evidence because of the whole set-up of the coronial inquiry system in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This is another of those instances where the report is presented unacceptably late. It is for the year ended 30 June, and it was tabled in the Senate in April, two and three-quarter months to go out of a year. This is unacceptable for a variety of reasons, but one of them is evident from the Auditor's Report, a copy of which is on page 67. I make no inferences at all about the management of the Australian Institute of Sport in making these points. In fact, I have a high personal regard for Mr Ron Harvey. But I do not find it acceptable that the Auditor's Report, dated 21 December 1988, which is in the annual report which has come into this chamber only now, reveals this:
The last full stocktake undertaken by the Institute was at 30 June 1985. Due to weaknesses in the asset recording system-
I emphasise that as I am not too cheered about seeing that-

and the impending amalgamation of the Institute with the Australian Sports Commission, the Institute commenced a complete stocktake of plant and equipment in February 1988 . . . at the time of signature of this report, the stocktake was not sufficiently advanced to enable verification of the $4,296,773 figure for plant and equipment in the financial statements. Accordingly, I am unable to determine if that figure is materially accurate.

Apart from the fact that we have had three full months since 21 December during which time some comment could have been made in the printed message at the front of these accounts about what had happened since then, it is simply unsatisfactory for this kind of note to appear in the accounts. I think the Senate has every right to ask: Is the stocktake sufficiently advanced now for the Senate to be told whether the auditor can certify that figure of $4.3 million?

It was interesting to listen to Senator Watson earlier. We should say how grateful we are for the sterling efforts of the Auditor-General, despite his lack of facilities and support from this Government, as he has been able to reveal many instances of inadequate reporting standards among so many governmental institutions. I am concerned to see the following remarks made on page 87 of the report, which states that under subsection 34 (3) of the Australian Institute of Sport Act:

. . . the money of the Institute shall not be expended otherwise than in accordance with estimates of expenditure approved by the Minister. During 1987-88 the Institute breached this sub-section as indicated below.

By 30 November 1987 it had exceeded estimates approved by the Minister on 30 June 1987 by $649,963 in various programs and $841,413 in administrative and operational expenses. It was also noted that expenditure at 30 June 1988 exceeded estimates approved by the Minister for administrative and operational expenses by $197,924 and by $118,360 for sport, $193,745 for a sports laboratory--

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BUREAU OF STATISTICS AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 6 December 1988, on motion by Senator Sheil:
That this Bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
Debate resumed from 2 March, on motion by Senator Walters:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating a private member's Bill relating to the censorship of `certain video materials'. In this case the `certain video materials' seem to be erotic video materials, apparently what is at present classified X. I wish to speak fairly briefly tonight in response to a small number of matters raised in the debate by the Opposition because they are myths which are also abroad in the community and should be exposed. One is about so-called evidence of public opinion from polling. Honourable senators opposite referred to a poll in the Age newspaper on 15 August last year under the heading `43% want X rated videos banned, opinion poll shows'. To the credit of the Age, a correction was later made. The question asked in the poll was:

SPEECH.PARA: There has been some discussion recently about X rated video cassettes. Some people say that videos depicting sex or violence should be banned.

The question then went on to ask specifically what should be banned and produced a very contradictory result. This was that 43 per cent wanted X-rated material banned but only three per cent thought that explicit sex, that is, the real contents of X-rated material, should be banned. In other words, three per cent thought that real X-rated videos should be banned and the other 40 per cent were confused by the incorrect information in the question. As I said, the Age later corrected its mistake. Such confusion is widespread in the community as evidenced in many of the letters I have received from individuals and organisations and in a number of debates that have occurred in this place.

Honourable senators opposite also repeated during this debate their claim that most women oppose the availability of X-rated videos. In the Australian Capital Territory, an Australian Institute of Criminology survey found that 30 per cent of total hirers are women and 70 per cent are couples. I suspect that the view that these videos degrade women is based partly on a belief that women should not be seen to enjoy sex or take the initiative in sexual activity, as is the case in many of the videos to which they object.
I quote from what the Office of the Status of Women said when it appeared before the Joint Select Committee on Video Materials.

The Office is satisfied that the guidelines, as they now stand, will operate in such a way as to prohibit such material as is likely to cause direct or indirect physical or psychological harm to women, while maintaining the rights of individuals to develop their own view of life, without direction from the state or the majority.
Another opinion quoted by some honourable senators opposite was the opinion of the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees Association, the shop assistants' union, which has claimed:
Habitual viewers of X rated videos were likely to hold a sexually callous view of women.

This is one of many similar arguments which fail to distinguish between cause and correlation. If the claim were true, the viewing of videos causes the callousness. As Laurence Splitter, chief research officer of the very prestigious Australian Council for Educational Research, wrote in a recent article in the Bulletin:

On the sexual side, I challenge anyone to establish a genuine correlation between viewing and real harm. There is little reason to think that if a person watches erotic videos they will be more inclined to do anything harmful. People watch what they want to . . . usually to satisfy rather than create a need.
I should add that much of the recent overseas evidence supports that view. In fact, there is some evidence that, far from being harmful, the material is helpful to many people.

One of the Opposition speakers supporting the Bill referred to the Association of Heads of Independent Schools in Australia as a body which opposed the availability of X-rated videos. I did a little bit of research on this matter myself before it was even mentioned in the Senate. Certainly that report did oppose the availability of X-rated videos, but I had difficulty in tracking down the process by which that decision was reached-apparently by a small working group of the Association. Its report said:
The working party had discussions with both Senator Harradine and Mr Charles MP.
In an addendum to the report the working party acknowledges:
. . . the assistance of Senator Harradine and David Charles MP in the selection of relevant extracts from the report.

This suggests to me that the working party did not take the time to read the whole report and the evidence it contains. It is probably significant that this working party, meeting in Victoria, did not seek to discuss the issues with a Victorian senator, namely, myself, who holds different views and also has qualifications and long experience in both teaching and pychology which they might have thought relevant. The first I knew about the report was when it landed on my desk.

Another matter raised by the Opposition was the recommendation of the State Attorneys-General last June that X-rated videos be banned. That recommendation was also based on lack of knowledge of what is shown in X-rated videos. The Attorneys-General are not alone in their ignorance; it is widespread in the community and has been fostered by some people who know better. I understand that the concern at the Attorneys-General meeting was about violence. X-rated videos are non-violent. The Film Censorship Board's guidelines define X, or extra restricted, material as follows:
Material which includes explicit depictions of sexual acts involving adults, but does not include any depiction suggesting coercion or non-consent of any kind.

That is why the Joint Select Committee on Video Material recommended that it be renamed `non-violent erotica'. That is a far more useful way of describing it in terms that people can understand. The most violent video material which is legally available in this country is that which is classified R, yet before and after the meeting of the Attorneys-General we read and heard interviews with State Ministers who clearly had been wrongly advised and/or had not done their own homework because they thought that, by recommending that X-rated material not be available, they had done something significant to prevent violence. It was irrelevant to violence.

I think it is notable that Senator Walters's private member's Bill does not address the question of the portrayal of violence, yet this is something that is of great concern in the community and is an area where the Film Censorship Board has already taken action to tighten up its own interpretation of the guidelines.

To save the time of the Senate, I have not addressed the details and wording of Senator Walters's Bill. If it reaches the committee stage, its lack of clarity will become obvious. At this stage I would just like to mention what I consider to be one very obvious flaw. Clause 4 of the Bill, on interpretation, states:
``explicit depictions of sexual acts'' means depictions of:
(a) sexual penetration;
(b) oral contact with genitals between consenting adults; or
(c) sexual manipulation alone or between consenting adults.

I imagine that Senator Walters intends the term `sexual manipulation' to mean masturbation but it could just as easily be interpreted to include such things as kissing, fondling and so on. I would like to quote from Senator Macklin's contribution to this debate. He said:

Sex is not a crime in Australia; it never has been and hopefully it never will be. It is a healthy human activity. The depiction of sexual activities occurs in an enormous range of movies . . . An example of this is kissing.

Does Senator Walters really want to ban the depiction of explicit kissing? Other parts of the Bill are similarly confused and seem in some cases to be self-contradictory. But that matter can wait until the committee stage. I would like to finish with another quotation from Laurence Splitters's clear-sighted article which appeared in the Bulletin last year. He writes:
In these times of safe sex promotion, legislation against a patently safe sexual practice i.e. watching erotic videos-seems to be a move in the wrong direction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a great deal of sympathy for the Opposition's opposition to these videos. I think it is a great pity that the advice of the Attorneys-General to ban these videos in the Australian Capital Territory was not taken because we would not then have had to debate this contentious but comparatively unimportant issue at such length now and on a previous occasion. There is clearly much misunderstanding about the nature of these videotapes. I must admit that I was one of those who misunderstood the nature of them.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to give honourable senators present who have not seen any of these videos a brief outline of two of the six videos which Senator Macklin kindly lent me and which I subjected myself to one rainy weekend. Neither of them contained any physical violence at all. The first one I saw really offended my feminist sensibilities. It is called Butterflies and is about a rather sleazy yuppie type who is clearly suffering from satyriasis and requires a constant stream of women to satisfy his exceptional appetite. He is a cad, a bounder and a sexist pig who treats women abysmally. The story ends with the departure of yet another initially willing victim too naive to perceive his true character. His final words are, `There are always more where she came from'. Of course as a feminist I found this mortifying.

The other video called Deep Throat is about the wife of an apparently straight-laced senator who, when she is suddenly possessed by the spirit of her notorious mother, Linda Lovelace, sets about to prove the hypocrisy of the members of a committee, including her husband, who are examining X-rated videos. Does this sound familiar? There follow some amusing scenes when a news broadcaster and some gospel singers are overcome by irresistible urges. The only objection I had to this video was its execrable aesthetic execution. Its content, however, bore a remarkable resemblance to reality.

I refer now to an article in the Australian Financial Review of 2 February which was taken from the New York Times. The article was about a Christian religious broadcasters conference in Washington. There was a collection of delegates at the forty-sixth annual convention of that religious organisation. The end of that article states:

One of the highlights of the conference was a vote by the directors of the NRB to oust evangelist Jimmy Swaggart from the organisation for his `moral failure' in allegedly consorting with a Louisiana prostitute.
The journalist goes on to say:
But one of the participants, radio broadcaster Paul Ramseyer, said that an analysis of hotel bills of the 1988 NRB-
that is, the National Religious Broadcasters-
conference participants had shown that 80 per cent of the delegates had watched an X-rated movie in their room.

I thought this quite amusing. I think these videos are misnamed as non-violent erotica. As Robbie Swan from the Adult Video Association suggested to me, they should be called not very erotic because, in their anatomically stark, repetitious, close-up shots, they contain little that healthy sexual adults might find appealing. I certainly acknowledge Senator Macklin's point which he made to me privately that `if a man is dying of acquired immune deficiency syndrome and wishes to view one of the gay X-rated videos I have no right to deny him that'. As far as my feminist instincts go I believe it would actually be unhealthier for this society in general, and for women in particular, to force this material underground. I am not just talking about the criminal domination of this particular business. A corollary to this would be the development of an unhealthy prurience about sexual matters that might have even more of a detrimental effect on the status of women in this society. In relation to this I have to think of the United States where some awful pornography and sex shows exist alongside some of what I regard as the most progressive feminist debate of sexism.

The last time I spoke on this Bill I referred in passing to an advertisement which cost me a job. It was an advertisement which portrayed women very much as dolly birds. It was an advertisement for a secretarial agency. I felt that the ad had denigrated women by showing them dressed in clothes which were not suitable for the dignity and seriousness of the work that they were to do. I did not even at the time-it was over 10 years ago-believe that that ad should have been banned. My advice to the organisation was that I would conduct a national education campaign against it to show how offensive its advertisement was to all female office workers. I wanted to expose its subliminal message and show women and men the sort of stereotypes that were being reinforced, to the detriment of women, and men, too, I believe. I believe that education and a re-examination of our attitudes is the path to follow in uncovering the sexist and demeaning nature of such advertisements in many of these X-rated videos. I urge the Government to maintain and expand its support for non-sexist education and training programs. I believe that this is the reasonable way to go. So I join the Women in Science Network in opposing Senator Walters's private member's Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the second reading motion in respect of Senator Walters's Video Material Bill 1988. I do so for a number of reasons. I moved the resolution in the Senate which resulted in the setting up of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material. I did so in June 1984 and have maintained a very close interest in the progress of the Committee's work and its report, which was tabled some time ago. The establishment of this Committee arose out of a very serious situation which had developed from 1 February 1984 when the then Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, in the Hawke Government, introduced some major amendments to legislation governing censorship of video material in Australia. As a result of those amendments which he made, with the very obvious purpose of removing virtually all controls on censorship of video material, the legislation is very complicated and has various parts to it. I do not propose to go into that detail.

SPEECH.PARA: The end result of the Hawke Government's legislative changes, taking effect from 1 February 1984, was to open the floodgates for importation into Australia of largely American X-rated video material, to enable that material to be given an X classification in Australia and to introduce a very liberal classification ordinance in the Australian Capital Territory for such material. This was done ostensibly to give effect to decisions which had been made by the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General relating to censorship. By the end of 1983 it had reached general agreement to introduce a scheme of this kind. It was part and parcel of that scheme that complementary State laws would be introduced. This was to be a national liberation of material of this kind.

Instead of waiting until that arrangement was finalised and that legislation was ready to come into effect in all the States, Senator Gareth Evans-as was his custom and probably still is in many respects-went ahead alone on behalf of the Commonwealth and allowed a great range of this American X-rated material to be imported into Australia before there was adequate legislation in place in the various States. The only place where there was any complementary legislation of that kind was in the ACT. The material, which was X-rated in the United States and which was imported into Australia under these new Commonwealth laws, created an enormous amount of alarm throughout Australia when it suddenly became available. There was immediate reaction, great concern and considerable opposition to the videos, and in the course of 1984 virtually all States decided that they were going to ban this material. The end result was, as is now the position, that not only the hire and sale but also the possession of this material was banned. However, the material is still allowed to enter Australia and be sold under the restrictions of the local ordinance in the ACT. Although State laws attempt to restrict interstate trade in this material, there is now a flourishing interstate trade in this material through mail order from the ACT.

The net result is that the ACT has become what is widely described as the porn capital of Australia. That is a very justifiable description. The national capital has become the porn capital because it is the only place in Australia where this material has any legal status. Because of the national laws and because there is a Commonwealth constitutional guarantee for freedom of interstate trade and so on, this material is still available throughout Australia by mail order. I am told that that has resulted in a $25m industry in the ACT. That is what the video industry tells us. It is in fact the fourth largest industry in the ACT.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those figures are not correct.
—It is worse than that?
—No, far less.

—That is what the industry claims. It is a horrifying claim, and I hope it is not true, as Senator Harradine suggests, but the fact is that there is a very substantial business in this material concentrated in the ACT. That is a direct result of the attitude of the Hawke Government under the then Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, and no doubt continued by his successor. The Prime Minister said recently that he could not care less about the situation; he is going to leave it to the new ACT administration, whenever that is brought into being under other recent laws of the Hawke Government. So there is a very clear attitude by the present Hawke Government, by the Caucus of the Australian Labor Party, that this deplorable situation should be allowed to continue indefinitely and that the Government does not intend to do anything about it.

SPEECH.PARA: It is in those circumstances that Senator Walters has brought forward this legislation, the purpose of which is twofold. Firstly, it is to correct the great anomaly that exists. The effect of the Bill will be to remove the X-rated classification altogether, thereby preventing this material from being available legally for sale, hire or possession in the ACT and to prevent it from being imported into Australia. Secondly, and very importantly, its purpose is to tighten up the violent content of the R or restricted classification, which is well known. Under the ordinary film and video classification laws of this country an R certificate means public viewing of material that is restricted to people over the age of 18. In recent years, unfortunately, that material has contained a good deal of violent material. Senator Walters's Bill is also designed to tighten up the classification of that material with a view to eliminating serious offensive violence contained within it. I hope that the Senate will support this Bill.

Some amendments could be made to this Bill. For instance, Senator Walters has said that she believes that X-rated and R-rated material should be given a suitable classification provided that it has educational, literary or artistic merit. The vast majority does not have that quality at all, so there would be only a few exceptions. She also believes that this material should be available for film festivals and that type of activity. The Bill purports to allow for that. There is some question about whether it does so correctly. There may be some amendments that are desirable to give effect to her intention. Subject to that relatively minor qualification, I hope that the Senate will agree in principle with the object of her Bill.

There is a good deal of confusion in the public mind about what is X-rated material. One of the excuses that the Labor Party Caucus has given is that this could be cleared up. Indeed, Senator Dunn seems to believe that this material is really quite harmless. On the other hand, there are people who believe that it is material which contains a great deal of violence, particularly sexual violence. The present classification system adopted by the Film Censorship Board does not admit into the X classification material depicting violence, particularly sexual violence. However, the confusion was clearly caused by the Hawke Government and the Attorney-General of the day. For the next 18 months, after the floodgates were opened on 1 February 1984, this material which was given X ratings under United States laws and which contained the most horrific violence flooded in. It is no wonder that the Australian community was outraged by the material that suddenly became legally available in Australia. It was not soft pornography, which is now said to be part of this X-rated material; it was pornography that contained a great deal of violence. In fact one of its major features was violence.

If there is still some confusion about what X-rated material is, it is clearly due to the way that the Hawke Government went about this exercise. As a result of the great concern that was immediately raised about this X-rated material, the Film Censorship Board-I think under a good deal of pressure from the ministerial councils involved-modified what was allowed in X-rated material.

We now come to the hub of this debate. Senator Dunn has said that she has seen two of these films. It surprises me that she can come into this Senate and give opinions and make judgments after having seen only two films of this kind. Nevertheless, it is claimed, and claimed with justifications, by those that have better knowledge of the matter than Senator Dunn, I or most of us that this X-rated material-I have taken the word of the Chief Film Censor for this; I think he knows what he is talking about-has now been sanitised so that at least it does not contain the sort of violence and the sexually violent material, some of which I have seen in the past, which is of an absolutely horrific nature and which all of us in this chamber would wish to ban.

The question is whether this existing modified X-rated material should also be banned. One of the major purposes of the Joint Committee was to evaluate evidence. A great deal of very valuable and highly expert evidence was given to that Committee about material which does not contain violence but which is made simply for the purpose of portraying various explicit sexual activities of a great variety; not just one-to-one heterosexual activity but various aberrations of sexual conduct of both a heterosexual and a homosexual kind. By no means is it the portrayal of sexual activity in a loving and caring relationship. This material is very far removed from that. The question is whether that material is or may be harmful. There is evidence to suggest that it is sufficiently harmful that we should prevent its being seen.

It concerns me when governments or parliaments are called upon to ban material, whether it be material that is viewed, read or heard. We take the general approach that censorship is permissible-there is a general right to that material-unless there is something harmful that may come from it. I have not the time to go through all the material that was canvassed in the report of the Committee. There are two volumes of that report. There is some very valuable material in it. It is clear from the evidence given to that Committee by experts and by many other people that there is a real risk that this sort of material can lead to changes of attitudes and conduct by people, particularly men in their attitudes to women. This is harmful and a denigration of women and attitudes to women. It could, in some circumstances, lead to aggressive conduct such as rape and other types of sexual assault.

One of the most persuasive pieces of evidence given to that Committee came from Professor Sheehan, Professor of Psychology at the University of Queensland. He has been a member of the Films Board of Review. He is an expert of high standing whose views one should take very seriously. Of non-violent material he says-I quote from page 1192 of the Hansard-in his evidence:

In and of itself, I do not think seeing sexually explicit material divorced from aggression leads to strong negative effects. Once you combine sexually explicit material with aggression you have a different kettle of fish. I think the evidence for harmful effects is much stronger in that. The critical thing is how much someone is aroused and how aggressive he is in the first place.

The thrust of that view is that one should not take the risk. It may be that, in the great majority of cases, this material will not have those effects. But we have to be concerned at the impact it may have on the exceptional individual. If the exceptional individual is aroused by this material to aggressive conduct-it may well be rape or aggressive, violent conduct particularly towards women; these days it may even be on a homosexual basis-then we, as legislators, should prevent the distribution of this material. It is of no real value to members of the community. If we do not let them see this material we are not depriving anybody of any great benefit. We should not trouble our tender consciences about rights of individuals and the freedom to see, hear and read what people want to. If there is evidence of that kind, and there was-one has only to read Professor Sheehan's evidence, which I have just quoted-it behoves us to be very cautious indeed.

I refer to a finding of the whole Committee, which included Senator Zakharov. I am not quoting from the minority report; there is great confusion as to who was in the minority and who was in the majority. I am now quoting from a summary of evidence on which all members, including Senator Zakharov, agreed. Page 230 of volume one of the report reads:

Theories of behavioural science, laboratory experiments and anecdotal evidence point strongly to the fact that the effects of pornography are not aberrations. Responses to pornographic stimuli fall within the range of human behaviour.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not agree with that volume of the report.
—Is Senator Zakharov denying that? The report continues:

SPEECH.PARA: It cannot logically be argued that the effects of pornography can safely be ignored because, supposedly, only deviants would respond to pornographic influences. While behavioural science studies in this area do not provide certainty they do establish theories which make reliable predictions about human behaviour. It would therefore be unenlightened for Parliament to ignore them.
As I say, there is a great deal of evidence to back up that finding, which is a finding of the whole Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not of the whole of the Committee.
—I am sorry, Senator, you keep interjecting, but so softly that I do not know whether you are saying that you do not agree with that.
—Order! The honourable senator will address his remarks through the Chair.

—Some studies have been undertaken that may be controversial. Professor Sheehan, in another article that was submitted to the Committee and published in the Committee's findings, refers to them. It sets out the results of experiments done in the United States by some researchers named Zillman and Bryant in which they summarised the effects that they observed on normal human beings as a result of exposure to this sort of material. What they found, most importantly, according to Professor Sheehan, was that massive exposure to this sort of pornography results in recommendations of significantly shorter terms of imprisonment for rape. They found that not only did this result in trivialisation of attitudes to rape, evident in women as well as in men, but also that this massive exposure resulted in significantly increased men's sexual callousness towards women.

SPEECH.PARA: It is no wonder that so many representatives of women in Australia are deeply concerned about this material and are supporting Senator Walters's Bill. Senator Hill, in speaking in this debate a few weeks ago, quoted extensively from replies that he had received from women's organisations around Australia. The Women in Science Enquiry Network, which Senator Dunn referred to, was about the only women's organisation that expressed any lack of concern about this matter.

One need only read the text of Senator Hill's speech to see the massive widespread concern amongst women in Australia about this sort of material, for the very good reasons that have been set out in the expert evidence before the Committee, and which is there for anybody to read. I have mentioned some of it by Professor Sheehan. I have mentioned the findings of the Committee in relation to that material. They are warnings that have been given to us as legislators about the possible deleterious effects on human behaviour by a continual viewing of material of this kind. We have been warned. The Joint Committee-albeit that it took a long time to do so-came forward with a valuable report. It has collected a great mass of evidence of which we as legislators should take note and on which we should be prepared to act, and to act firmly. Senator Walters's Bill provides for this to be done.

There have been some great advances in evidence of this kind in the last 10 years. When I first became Attorney-General and had responsibility for censorship in this country, in 1977, my attention was drawn to the then development of violence, particularly violence in films. Videos were not a big deal in 1977. The Chief Censor in those days-and Mrs Janet Strickland, who subsequently became Chief Censor-became very concerned by the development of violence, and sexual violence in particular. I made a lot of inquiries at that time as to whether there was any real evidence about the effect of this on individual behaviour. I was told, as best as I could ascertain from scientists in the field, that there was no evidence one way or the other. That was the situation in 1977-78. The sort of scientific evidence that the Committee has obtained comprises scientific work and experiments which have been made since that time. It is quite clear, of course, that our knowledge only 10 or so years ago was quite deficient. Scientific development in this area has been quite significant. I only wish that that material had been available many years ago because, at least in relation to the R certificate area, we might have avoided a good deal of the violence that has crept in.

One of the things that I am particularly pleased about in this Bill-it is why I support it so strongly-is the attempt by Senator Walters to tackle that development which has occurred in relation to violence. In relation even to non-violent pornography, there is clear evidence now that there is a danger of harm to people. As long as there is any real danger, it is our duty as legislators to try to do our best to prevent it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the last 15 years there has been a pattern of deliberate delay and deception to deny democracy a role on determining this issue. This chamber has the opportunity tonight of striking a blow for democracy. It has the opportunity of carrying out the expressed wishes of the hundreds of thousands of people throughout Australia who have petitioned this Parliament, who have written letters, who have had meetings, demanding that something be done about this matter. In this week, when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) launched the Government's campaign against domestic violence, we have the opportunity of doing something about the type of video pornography which is linked to domestic violence.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Zakharov made some grossly inaccurate statements in her contribution tonight. A quite obvious one was her accusation that Senator Walters was not doing anything about violent videos in her Bill, the Regulation of Video Material Bill 1988. It is quite clear that she has not read the Bill and she has not even read Senator Walters's speech, since that Bill and that speech refer specifically to the intention of this Bill to refuse classification to video material which depicts detailed, relished or gratuitous depictions of acts of considerable violence or cruelty.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is already there.

—That is not already there. I am sorry to say to Senator Zakharov that that shows her ignorance on this subject. In fact, she was a member of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material. The majority of the Committee, of which Senator Walters and I were a part, recommended that the Parliament introduce legislation to ban that type of relished violence. She did not ultimately sign that recommendation. Who is it amongst us who is soft on violence? Those of us who are against X-rated videos are frequently accused of being soft on violence. I ask the Senate: Who is soft on violence? Senator Zakharov will not sign the recommendation that we should abolish violence. Senator Zakharov says that Senator Shirley Walters is not doing anything about violence. The honourable senator should read the Bill; she might learn something.

SPEECH.PARA: I reiterate that there has been a deliberate pattern of delay and deception of the public about this issue. That started way back in the time of a former Attorney-General, Lionel Murphy. Honourable senators who have taken the trouble to read the first couple of chapters of the report of the Committee will see that there has been a deliberate attempt to hide from the public what has been going on. The advice given to the then Attorney-General was that `the Government's policy might best be achieved by a strategy of hastening slowly, gradually broadening the standards of imported material so that public opinion can be developed to embrace the principles embodied in the policy'.

What were those principles? That policy was that adults should be free to view what they wish. That is not an issue. Adults are free to take poison if they wish. It so happens that adults are not free under this Government to view many videos which it already bans, including unduly detailed acts of extreme violence and explicit or unjustifiable victims of sexual violence, not to mention bestiality. So the Federal Government does not see its policy as being a principle to be applied universally and uniformly, but rather as a slogan to be used selectively and arbitrarily in a manner which lacks credibility. And it does lack credibility because there is only one class of video that is not subject to the general censorship guidelines and that is the X-rated video. In the case of X-rated video pornography, this Government resorts to the use of that slogan rather than to admitting to giving priority to the exploiting pornographers' claimed right of freedom of expression over other individual and societal rights.

This is where the question of censorship comes in. I am quite happy to debate the issue of censorship. I am quite aware that censorship has a connotation of being associated with narrow-minded reactionary interference. If we are talking about censorship as a term, we should move away from some concepts of the word `censorship' as an abstraction to the term `censorship' as a principle which underlies human actions and conduct. It is a principle which will stand up to scrutiny and perhaps will provide a philosophical basis for the concept of censorship. I define censorship as the application of a carefully balanced and judiciously evaluated assessment of that which is conducive to the essential common good of an equal liberal-that is, free-and life-affirming society. It is important to consider the nature of society in any analysis of the justification or lack of justification of censorship since many of the arguments against censorship are based on the rights of the individual within society. Time does not permit me tonight to develop that point because I believe the Senate wants to vote on this matter, but I would like to develop it at some stage. I would like also to develop an argument against those who misquote John Stewart Mill on this issue.

Let me come back to the main theme. There has been a deliberate pattern of denial of democracy. This material has been allowed into the country without regulation until 1963-64. At that time, the Government for the first time legitimised the distribution for sale and hire in Australia of what it termed `hard core pornography' in the video field. That is not my term; that is the definition in the explanatory memorandum of the ACT Classification and Publications Ordinance, and it is a definition given to X-rated videos by this Government. This Government calls X-rated videos `hard core pornography'. We have had obfuscation of what is contained in X-rated videos. All we hear is that there is no violence in X-rated videos. All we hear is the bland statement that X-rated videos depict sexual acts involving adults but do not include any depictions suggesting coercion or non-consent of any kind.

Let me refer to the report. Those who wrote this report had seen far more than two X-rated videos, and I am not sure that one of the videos listed is an X-rated video. They indicated that the dominant theme of this non-violent, pornographic and degrading video material is that it objectifies and commodifies women. The report states:

Rather than treating women as free and responsible initiators of human activity, the material in this category, although non-violent, treats women as sexual commodities to arouse the sexual desires of its target audience. Thus sexual intercourse is typically depicted as a mechanical act devoid of love or human consequences . . . The bulk of all pornographic video material commercially available in Australia falls within this category.
As we know, in general there is little or no plot or character development. If there is a story line, it is an excuse for the sex exploits contained in this material.

The Committee, as did the Meese Commission in the United States, referred to the material as degrading in that it frequently depicts people, usually women, as existing solely for the sexual satisfaction of others, usually men; depicts people, usually women, in decidedly subordinate roles in their sexual relations with others; or depicts people engaged in sexual practices that would to most people be considered humiliating. The Committee report states:
Women are often depicted as sexually malleable for the purposes of satisfying male sexual desires.
I wonder how many Labor Party people support material that depicts women often as `sexually malleable for the purposes of satisfying male sexual desires'. The report goes on:
This is sometimes manifested by themes involving workplaces sexual favours.
In fact, that is called sexual harassment. It further states:

Women are frequently depicted as eager for sexual experience of any kind and ever ready for any opportunity for sexual activity. This is frequently manifested in the group sex scenes depicting diverse sexual activity, which are a feature of much of the material in this category.

Senator Zakharov says that we cannot prove that there is causal harm in that. Who said we could? The majority of the Committee did not say that one could say that the viewing of this particular video caused the commission of that particular crime or offence. That is impossible to prove because of all the other variables, upbringing and so forth. But what can be established is the perception that this type of material mediates in the mind of the habitual viewers. That is what one can demonstrate and what has been demonstrated and proven to the satisfaction of the majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material. That is something that this Parliament cannot run way from. We spent many years on this and thoroughly examined it.

It is quite clear that the majority of evidence which was cited by the Joint Select Committee showed that the material engenders a sexually callous and manipulative orientation towards women. It mediates in the minds of the habitual viewer a perception of women as being highly promiscuous and therefore available. It is interesting to note that at least four of the behavioural scientists whose work was subjected to the scrutiny of the Committee saw non-violent pornographic videos as being more harmful in that regard-that is as to the perception-than the violent explicit pornography which has already been banned.

Senator Zakharov referred to recent overseas research. She did not cite any of it, but I happen to have in my hand some very recent overseas research which clearly goes to this question. It is from a book-either a forthcoming book or one that is now in print-by Zillmann and Bryant Pornography: Recent research, interpretations, and policy considerations, Hillsdale, New Jersey. An article in that work entitled `Pornography and Men's Sexual Callousness Towards Women', by Professors Zillman and Weaver, deals with the nature of sexual callousness, the culture of sexual callousness, the nurture of sexual callousness and the theoretical proposals-namely, social cognition, social learning, guided imagery and target depersonalisation-and the pertinent research findings.

It is interesting to note that the article deals with this question of the effect of high fidelity audio visual pornography that is available in Western societies. It indicates that many of the pornographic scripts:

. . . dwell on sexual engagements of parties who have just met, who are in no way emotionally attached to one another, who enjoy sexual stimulation for what it is, and who will part shortly, never to meet again. The implicit conquests tend to be mutual and rarely show coercion. Men are invariably shown as go-getters. Women are portrayed as ever-ready to accommodate any sexual request from anybody in the vicinity, often taking initiatives in signalling their readiness. The women featured in pornography have been characterised as men's playthings, creatures who quiver at the sheer sight of a penis, who scream for sex, who squeal euphorically in response to any sexual or quasi-sexual stimulation to which they are subjected . . .

I will not go on. The effect of that clearly is to mediate in the minds of the male viewers a perception of women in general as being highly promiscuous and available. It is conducive to the formation of callous sexual dispositions towards women. The article states that pornography thus can be seen as the primary social institution that fosters sexual callousness by promoting self-serving male beliefs about female sexuality. It then goes on to deal with the effects on women.

Before I get to that, let me turn to domestic violence. This is a very serious question-so serious that this week the Government has seen fit to conduct a publicity campaign against domestic violence. Domestic violence is a disgrace-there is no excuse whatever for any domestic violence-but it is in the perceptions that are gained from outside and perpetrated by people against women-their victims. Incidentally I would say-and I do not know whether anybody is listening-I believe that in that campaign against domestic violence all the attention is being addressed to the victims. It is very important that victims are protected, that they know they have ability to rise above violence, but let us spare a thought for the perpetrators too, because they need help.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is part of the campaign.

—I am pleased to hear it. It is no good their going from one relationship into another and doing the same thing. I refer to what Professor James Check said in a study entitled Violence and Victims. Research was carried out by Check and E. Sommers into pornography and violence and dealt specifically with video pornography which is referred to as `sexually explicit or sexually arousing material'. The report says:

SPEECH.PARA: A total of 39% of battered women versus only 3% of the women in the comparison group-
who incidentally were not battered-

reported that they had been upset by their partners asking them to imitate pornography. In addition, the battered women reported much more frequent pornography consumption by their partners than did the women in the comparison group . . .
I shall be brief, as I know Senator Walters wishes to reply to the debate. In its conclusion the study says:

Although the results of the present study do not provide direct evidence of a causal link between the use of pornography and violence against women, certain observations can be made specifically about the data collected for this study. These observations are consistent with the link between pornography and violence against women and may ultimately add to the growing body of evidence showing that the use of pornography increases males' aggressiveness towards women. Since other studies have suggested that certain forms of pornography contribute to aggressiveness against women, it was assumed that a higher consumption of pornography among the partners of the battered women than among the partners of non-battered women would be reported. This assumption was in fact confirmed.

Surely we cannot take the risk. I believe that tonight we are at the crossroads. I believe that it is most important for this Bill to be supported in the second reading stage. If there are concerns by some about whether it is effective and would be effective at the control barrier, that is the time to discuss those concerns and to amend the Bill if it is thought it would not be effective. I consider that it would be effective. I have heard no arguments that it would not be effective seriously advanced.

There has been a suggestion that, if X-rated videos were banned in Australia, a criminal element would be established. That is the latest of the excuses of those who do not want to ban hard core pornography. That sort of argument can be used for almost anything. If the Government can get away with that as an excuse on this issue, it can do it on any other issue. Four years ago the Senate Select Committee on Video Material, knowing that the Federal Government was to send this matter off to yet another committee and that this delay would entrench video pornography in Australia, and the Senate as a whole requested the Government to place a moratorium on these videos pending the outcome of the new Committee's report. What did the Government do? It did not do that, and it is to blame for this material currently in the community.

I say `in the community' because it is in the home video entertainment system; that is where it is. It is not just in a few restricted theatres or anything like that; it is in the home entertainment system, available for children and anybody else who wants to see it. Indeed, the mail order system is the worst of all in that there is no requirement for proof of the age of persons who are hiring the material; they just sign.

I end by conveying an appeal that was made by the President of Apex Australia. He has appealed to the community and the Parliament to take action against this type of material, which is, in fact, engendering attitudes within our society which we will live to regret.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Regulation of Video Material Bill 1988 introduced by my colleague Senator Walters. I will be as speedy as I can because I recognise that Senator Walters would like us to get through the second reading stage this evening. This is the latest of a series of efforts by the Opposition-particularly Senator Durack and Senator Walters-and, of course, Senator Harradine, to stop the distribution of what I believe is quite disgusting material which can only pollute the minds of Australians, particularly the young. Every State in this country and the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) are in favour of this measure. All States have in fact banned the sale or hire of X-rated videos. Canberra has become the porn capital of Australia. It is from Canberra that this quite obscene material is distributed by mail around the country.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of Senator Walters's Bill is to prohibit the importation, sale or hire of X-rated videos and to reduce the violence in R-rated videos. I refer to the reminder given by Senator Harradine to Senator Zakharov. The reasons for the Bill have been well canvassed by Senator Walters and others, and I will not go over them again. For four years now this out of touch Government has delayed doing anything about the distribution around Australia of this quite pernicious material. The Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Macklin, implied in his speech that he would not support the Bill and stated quite vehemently that he would call points of order on anyone who said that those who supported the continued distribution of this material were guilty of improper motives. In fact, he used the opportunity to attack my coalition colleague Senator Bjelke-Petersen. He drew a comparison between this matter and the views of those who are genuinely opposed to drugs but who took the view that the only way to control them, and thus remove them from the criminal elements in society, was to make them freely available to addicts. Notwithstanding the fact that I do not agree with Senator Macklin-or, perhaps more correctly, the views expressed by these people-I believe that such people take that stand because they have come to the conclusion that our law enforcement agencies cannot control the peddling of illicit and harmful drugs.

Hard drugs destroy the bodies and minds of people. Video pornography desensitises young people and degrades the dignity of women, and with it comes an attitude to women which promotes violence to women of all ages. We do not need scientific studies and inquiries to tell us that.

Senator Macklin also said that he would prefer the videos-which he described as being amateurish and without any artistic merit, and I am sure he is right-to be out in the open rather than peddled by criminals in society. I wonder how Senator Macklin would describe those people who already, because of a loophole, peddle this material to all States, when it is illegal to do so within those States. To my way of thinking, people who make a living out of this would have to be among the lowest and most despicable people in our society. To give honourable senators some idea of their mentality, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a letter which was received by all Liberal members of Parliament from a Mr Robbie Swan of the Adult Video Industry Association.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
AN OPEN LETTER TO LIBERAL POLITICIANS
It is a strange thing within the Westminster system that `conservative' politicians are supposed to toe `liberal' philosophies.
That sort of doublespeak doesn't exist in the Israeli Knesset, the Hindu Parliaments or even in the Russian Politburo.
You know why?

Because they don't have a christian church carping at them all day, telling them that God is looking over their shoulder-except when they do it in the missionary position and then He turns away for five minutes.
The way of Bjelke-Petersen and Fred Nile is not the true Liberal party way. Banning condoms in Queensland is madness in the middle of the black plague.
Banning `The Last Temptation of Christ' is an acknowledgement of cracks in one's own faith.
Banning X-rated non-violent erotic movies, while retaining movies like `Rambo' and `Blood Sucking Freaks' is a fascist move.

How can any of you say you are acting in accord with your Liberal Party Federal Platform which states in the second paragraph, ``Liberalism's central task is to safeguard and advance the freedom of the individual and to subject all constraints on him to ever more stringent scrutiny.''
Surely it's a small freedom, the one to watch a non-violent erotic movie in the privacy of one's own living room.
And how can any of you justify your involvement and co-ordination in bans on X-rated videos in the ACT?

In the fifth paragraph of the Federal Platform, under the banner of the Spirit of Liberalism, you state ``Within Government, Liberals encourage decentralisation decision making by State and local governments, which are closest to those affected. They seek to reserve for Federal Government decision, only those issues of truly national significance.''
How can you justify video erotica as an issue of truly national significance?
Maybe by virtue of the fact that 99% of the population enjoys some sex, but after that, surely schools, defence, the disabled and a free money system are all far more important.

The Government has at least bothered to hear both sides of the issue. Not one member of the Opposition has bothered to talk to anyone in the Adult Video Industry Association and hear their point of view.
Shirley Walter's time on the Joint Parliamentary Committee hardly rates.

If the Adult Video Industry Association is closed down in Canberra, business at Australia Post Express Courier will halve overnight. Canberra's printing industry will lose 10% of its business. Three hundred staff will lose their jobs. Two million dollars in group taxes to the nation will be lost and the publishing industry will lose two million dollars in advertising revenue.
All to please the outdated morals of elderly (and mostly celibate) men of the cloth.
The people of Canberra have clearly shown (see enclosed poll) that they approve of, and enjoy, adult video erotica, while condemning violence (R and M rated movies).
Surely it's time the Liberal Party started to espouse a truly `liberal' line.
Yours sincerely,
ROBBIE SWAN
Lobbyist for AVIA
10th January 1989

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had that incorporated to save time, but it is worth quoting just a few words from that letter, which, incidentally, was sent, I understand, just to Liberal parliamentarians. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: It is a strange thing within the Westminster system that `conservative' politicians are supposed to toe `liberal' philosophies.
That sort of doublespeak doesn't exist in the Israeli Knesset, the Hindu Parliaments or even in the Russian Politburo.
You know why?

Because they don't have a christian church carping at them all day, telling them that God is looking over their shoulder-except when they do it in the missionary position and then He turns away for five minutes.

That is the most incredibly disgusting letter that has been sent to me in the whole time I have been in this Parliament. The vitriol of this vile individual and his or her organisation is there for everyone to see.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is his.

—I am not sure whether it is a him, a her, or an it. It shows what decent people, the vast majority of Australians, are up against. I think it is worth comparing that with other letters and comments that I have received. I received a letter from a Reverend J. Pasterkamp on behalf of the congregation of Christian Life Centre, Ipswich. Rather than go through it in detail, I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
24th November, 1988
Senator W. R. Parer,
Parliament House,
Canberra ACT 2600
Dear Sir,

By way of this letter we want to strongly appeal to you to use your influence in Parliament to see that all X-Rated videos in Australia are banned. I know that I speak for all the members in our congregation (some 450 including children) that we don't want a classification change. We simply don't want smut videos at all. I have little doubt in my heart that this is the desire of the majority of families in Australia.

As a pastor I am continually faced with the horrific consequences of these smut videos and pornographic magazines.
