of Christian Life Centre Ipswich.

TALK.START.PARA: —Basically the Reverend Mr Pasterkamp says that he has had experience with these sorts of videos in his own parish and that he is continually faced with the horrific consequences of these smut videos, as he calls them, and pornographic magazines. He says that since taking up his pastorate, as he calls it, he has had to deal with some 30-odd cases of rape and incest. He says that in his investigations none of them have been without the influence of X-rated videos and/or pornographic magazines.

SPEECH.PARA: In winding up-because I did say I would be as fast as I could-I draw attention to something that has stayed with me on this matter. Honourable senators who know something about the New Testament may be familiar with the comment made in the Gospel according to St Mark:
But whoever causes one of these little ones who believe in me to stumble, it would be better for him if a millstone were hung around his neck, and he were thrown into the sea.
That is the sort of thing that I throw back at this individual called Robbie Swan, who wrote a letter to me in the terms that I have outlined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —It certainly gives me great pleasure to take this opportunity to support my colleague Senator Walters and to support all the people who have spoken in support of her Regulation of Video Material Bill 1988. Senator Walters's Bill has been designed to counter the growing availability of pornographic material in Australian society. Its main purpose is twofold. Firstly, it aims to prohibit the importation, sale or hire of X-rated videos; and, secondly, it seeks to reduce violence in X-rated videos. In my role as a senator for the State of Tasmania, I have had an opportunity to move around that State and to gauge the public feelings on this matter. I am able to say quite categorically that it has been rare for me to find the huge-in fact almost unanimous-public support for this Bill now before the Parliament. The Bill is supported by all sections of the Australian community. I believe that we, as representatives of that community, have a responsibility to ensure its safe passage through the Parliament because, if we fail to uphold our responsibilities in that regard, we fail as legislators to fulfil our obligations to those who elect us.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been particularly disappointing for me that my fellow Tasmanian senators on the other side-and I do not include Senator Harradine-have failed to act to support the views of those in their own State. I have received many letters from Tasmanians on this subject-and many petitions too. I cannot remember the exact number. I know that I have presented thousands of signatures on petitions which are part of the 18,000 signatures generally on petitions which have already been presented on this matter to this Parliament. I am quite confident that the Tasmanian Federal members have also received similar letters and deputations. It appears to me that those on the other side of the House have simply chosen either to forget them or to ignore them.

In the brief time available to me, I take this opportunity to bring to the Parliament's attention a few brief examples of correspondence from people from different facets of life in Tasmania who have contacted me. Reverend Beeston, who is the Superintendent/Secretary of the Baptist Churches of Tasmania, states:
We strongly support the decisions taken by the Attorneys-General in Darwin last week in relation to video pornography . . . We . . . urge you-
that is, this Parliament, to:
Support the measures to be taken by the Federal and State Attorneys-General in line with their Darwin decisions. . .

Questions the right of parents and guardians to show their children sexually explicit material; and oppose the screening of banned films (under the new conditions) from being screened in hard-top cinemas.
That was just one example.

It would appear that my concerns over the lack of support by Tasmanian senators on the other side was brought to the attention of the Baptist Churches of Tasmania also because, on 2 March, 1989 I received another letter from Reverend Beeston, which states in part:

It was with very deep concern and disappointment we learned that a number of Tasmanian Senators voted in favour of continued dissemination of hard-core pornography out of Canberra. In so doing, they ignored the calls of concerned parents' groups, schools teachers, churches and many other community groups.
I believe that Reverend Beeston has been very forthright in his comments.

I quote from a letter from the Rokeby High School, which is a very short distance from my home and also very close to Senator Devereux's home. That school has an excellent reputation for a very high standard of educational programs and the parents of its students are very committed. Those parents wrote:
The existence of pornographic videos in our community was discussed at the . . . August meeting . . .
The meeting was in favour of censorship including classification and restrictions on the availability, if any, of pornographic material.

As time is restricted, I mention briefly another letter, this one from the Municipality of Circular Head-local government even-which passed motions at its meetings calling upon this Government for support. It said:
A recent meeting of the Council gave consideration to a request from the Australian Church Women (North West Branch)-
that was-
that the Federal and State Governments:
ensure that ``X'' rated video pornography (and their . . . equivalents) are refused classification;

I fully support what has been said by the previous speakers tonight in support of this Bill. We have heard comments from the Women's Electoral Lobby, the Country Women's Association and Australian Church Women. I hope that tonight commonsense will prevail in this Parliament and that we will support this Bill wholeheartedly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Regulation of Video Material Bill 1988 presents some difficulty not only for me but I think for many people in the community. From the letters I have had sent to me and letters I have seen sent to others, it seems that there still remains a great deal of confusion about the X and R classifications. I am utterly opposed to gratuitous violence on videos or in any other form. I am also opposed to videos which depict women as submissive, powerless and degraded, whether the material is of a sexual nature or not.

SPEECH.PARA: The real cause of concern for me, however, and I think for most Australians, is the level of violence in our community. I mean the real and acted out violence which is occurring. This is where our energies should be directed. It is interesting that this issue is being debated in the month declared national domestic violence awareness month. We certainly need community participation in reducing domestic violence, and I do not mean only in terms of supporting the victims and dealing with the problems of the perpetrators. What we need to address are the root causes of violence which have been, perhaps unconsciously, actually encouraged in our society.

Take the example of our children, who are subjected to hours and hours of mindless violence if they are allowed to watch programs which are actually designed for them. I have introduced a Bill on violence in children's cartoons which are used to promote violent toys. I believe there is continuing community concern over the level of violence shown on television. Much of this concern, of course, has been linked with the recent mass killings in Australia as well as those in the United States of America and the United Kingdom. What I am proposing is a ban on violent programs shown to our children on television, which amount to the promotion of toys which encourage violent play in our nation's children. Of course that has very severe psychological repercussions for the next generation. I believe that that is a much more practical measure to be taking, because violence which is shown on television for hours each day is available to all people in the community just at the flick of a switch. It is a very different matter from making a decision actually to go and hire a video, which people ought to be able to choose to do.

I note the Opposition's concern for a Christian opinion in support of this Bill, but I would point out that this same Opposition ignored church opinion on the subject of the Australian Capital Territory casino, and not all Christians support Senator Walters's Bill. Some of the carefully considered Christian opinion which I have had put to me is based on the fact that banning certain undesirable videos will drive this industry underground. Senator Macklin of course has put that position very eloquently indeed. We need to learn techniques of non-violence in problem solving. Educators are beginning to understand this and positive conflict resolution skills need to be taught in our schools and homes. That is where we should be directing our energies and not to trying to ban videos which people choose to watch in their own homes. Incidentally, these are videos which most Australian do not watch. For many who are one-time viewers, these videos are rejected as being very boring indeed.

I think it is about time that this debate was wound up, because we have heard about this subject in here for weeks. I conclude by saying that I support the decision for a committee to be set up to clarify further the classifications in relation to these videos.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I rise to wind up the debate, but it seems to me that that would be an impossible thing to do in the one minute only available to me. I am not sure whether the Government would like to suspend Standing Orders to allow the debate to be concluded tonight. If we go through the committee stage I doubt whether we would wind up even by 10.30 p.m. I have already indicated that I have two amendments, which I will be foreshadowing in the next few minutes. The Australian Democrats also have several amendments. I am not sure whether the Minister in the chamber at the moment is keen to get this Bill through or whether he would rather put it off for a week or perhaps even three weeks, because I think the Estimates are to be dealt with next Thursday.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1987

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —When the debate was interrupted earlier in the day I was addressing two Bills in this cognate debate concerning customs and excise, namely, the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 and the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1988. I had dealt with some of the Opposition's objections to the new system of issuing magistrates warrants by telephone, to penalties being made under the proposed new section 242t of the Customs Act 1901 and with out belief that the words `or otherwise' should be deleted from the proposed section. This morning I did not deal, however, with the proposed new sections 243u or 243v of the same legislation. Section 243u purports to provide relief from the harsh penalties under section 243t, which I dealt with this morning, by giving a discretion to the Comptroller to grant a remission of either the whole or part of that penalty at his discretion. It also purports to provide for a review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. This again is a conferring of a discretion upon the Comptroller, and again the law is rendered uncertain.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed section 243v provides that section 243t shall not apply if a declarant is genuinely uncertain of the truth of the information submitted and states that uncertainty and the reasons for that uncertainty at the time of declaration. Should the information supplied turn out to be false no penalty will be applied under the aforesaid section. But who decides what is genuine? Who decides whether the uncertainty was genuine uncertainty? It is yet again the conferring of another discretion and again the rendering of the law becomes uncertain.

At the actual point of interruption in the debate this morning I was dealing with a question of inland freight becoming part of the dutiable value of the imported good. I pointed out that the Government has made the false assertion that the reason for the introduction of this requirement is to comply with the provisions of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT). I pointed out this morning that article 8 of the code that is relevant to that part of the GATT specifically leaves the question of the inclusion in or exclusion from the customs value of freight insurance and other associated charges entirely at the discretion of the signatory country itself. I also pointed out that the Government had chosen to exercise this discretion with regard to exempting certain other associated charges from the value to be subject to duty.

I further pointed out that bona fide users of the exemption may be advantaged. Senator Lewis gave an example of this in his opening remarks this morning concerning Australian Consolidated Industries' importation of soda ash from Wyoming in the United States of America. The Government's move will simply result in higher importation costs and higher manufacturing costs which, of course, ultimately are passed on to the community as a whole. The Government's response that importers or others who consider that they may suffer a hardship under this provision would be invited to put their case to government or to the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) with a view to having the duty on their goods reduced is quite unsatisfactory. It is unsatisfactory for several reasons, the first being that there will be a time lag and that the company concerned will have to pay duty in the interim. There will, indeed, be no guarantee of any reduction. Indeed, the case of the importation of soda ash has already been before the IAC and I think it is unlikely that the IAC would welcome a further reference on the matter.

It is also pointed out by the Customs Agents Institute of Australia, which has made a strong plea, that small importers would be quite considerably disadvantaged by this provision. People who can load a full container packed at the factory can gain an advantage over small shippers where goods are packed in container depots where they only fill part of a container. The former does not have to pay duty on the inland freight but the latter does. Again it is unfair and not consistent, and the law, to be a good law, ought always to be consistent as well as certain.

These Bills were first placed before the House of Representatives some 18 months ago and were then introduced into this chamber. They have been the subject of much discussion because industry has been so dissatisfied with the approach that the Government has taken to them and, indeed, with the lack of consultation. I do not think that situation has been remedied. Indeed, the amendments to the initial Bill introduced 18 months ago are considerable. My understanding is that the consultation concerning those further amendments has been less than satisfactory.

It is always disappointing to find legislation introduced into this House that makes conducting business more difficult. There are in excess of 80 discretionary powers conferred on the Australian Customs Service by this legislation. The legislation has a complexity which renders the law, as I have said earlier, uncertain. Good law is simple law. Good law is easy to understand, interpret and comply with.

I have already said that the technique that was used in drafting these Bills is the technique which has been used in drafting taxation legislation. In the taxation area we have come to the ridiculous situation where pensioners cannot fill out their own taxation returns because of the complexity of the law. In this area we are applying strict liability in some instances to a complex law which is uncertain and subject to many discretions. That is bad law. It would be quite refreshing if the Government could perhaps take a leaf out of the books of other countries which have similar problems to us, such as Canada, where they seem to be able to have law drafted in a more straightforward way and in a way which is comprehensible and certain.

The Opposition, in moving an amendment to one of the two pieces of legislation I have referred to, is taking a stance on an important issue. The nature of the Bills is serious because they will affect the overall economy. The concern of the Government seems simply to collect more revenue without concern as to whether this is just or equitable. I find the Bills to be bad law in the sense that I have described and would draw the Senate's attention to the fact that there is a need to overhaul totally the attitude which this Government has to the introduction of laws which affect the business efficiency of our economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak about clause 8 of the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987, which allows for the Minister for Defence to suspend previously granted licences or permissions to export goods from Australia in circumstances where it is deemed in Australia's national interest to do so. This follows the recommendations of the 1986 Cooksey Review of Australia's Defence Exports and Defence Industry, which have never been debated in this chamber, and the announcement in June last year that the existing export controls on defence related goods would be revised so as to reduce constraints on exports where that could be done without prejudice to Australia's national interests and international obligations.

SPEECH.PARA: The Cooksey report recommended that Australia could and should double its defence exports over three to five years. This is a curious contrast to the statement made by Mr Hayden, the former Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, speaking at the United Nations (UN) Special Session on Disarmament in June last year in New York. I will quote what he said even though Senator McLean mentioned it in his speech. I will add a little bit to it because his statement is central to my argument in opposing this clause of the Bill. The former Foreign Minister, said:

It is also clear that arms exports should not be turned to as a way of solving domestic economic problems. Arms transfers must not become a new cash crop. It should also be recognised, especially by those whose development needs are great, that the purchase of arms is at the cost of the purchase of the investment goods essential to the creation of employment and economic growth.
In June last year the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) announced in a news release:
This Government's successful economic and defence policies mean Australian companies can now produce a growing range of internationally competitive defence products.
Twelve days later Mr Hayden was quoted in the Australian as saying:

I can't go to the UN Special Session on Disarmament, as I did a fortnight ago in New York and talk about our commitment in Australia . . . to work to try to cut back the arms trade . . . and then come back home and talk about a huge burst in the sale of conventional arms.

The UN Special Session on Disarmament was important because 26 countries, including Australia, raised the issue of arms transfers in the plenary debate. The Assembly voted for further discussion on arms transfers in the Disarmament Commission meeting this year and there will be a report to the Forty-fourth UN General Assembly. A study will then begin, to run over two years, of ways and means of promoting transparency in international transfers of conventional arms on a universal and non-discriminatory basis. One possible outcome of this study would be the establishment of an international registry of arms transfers under UN auspices.

I look forward to seeing what position the Australian Government will take on this issue and whether we vote in favour of a register. It is a point I make because even Robert Cooksey in his report to the Minister for Defence observed that it was extremely difficult to estimate the value of current and potential defence exports due to lack of available data in Australia. I see nothing in the new arrangements which will make it possible for us to know what defence equipment Australia is exporting in this way.

What are the reasons for the contradictions I have outlined and why have the merchants of death won out over the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade with its consideration of our more long term interests? The reasons for the Government's change of mind on defence exports are partly strategic and partly economic. It considers that greater overseas sales of defence products will make Australia's existing defence industries more efficient, that they will help develop the kind of industrial infrastructure that is required to support our new so-called strategy of self-reliance, that they will reduce the relatively large portion-23 per cent in 1986-87-of the defence budget that is spent overseas, and that they will help offset our balance of payments problems.

I would like to question some of these assumptions. Given the changes now taking place in the international arms market, it is highly doubtful whether Australia can simply double its defence exports, despite a greater effort on the part of industry and appropriate government support. Today there is a growing buyers' market in military arms and equipment, including the kind of materiel that we would hope to sell. A lot of other countries are seeking to use defence exports to alleviate domestic economic problems and even well established defence equipment exporters are having to diversify and offer attractive package deals in order to survive. The main reason for this situation is the global recession and the indebtedness of many of the major arms importing nations as well as the tendency for importing nations to update existing arsenals rather than buy new replacement weapons systems. Under these circumstances, and in view of our relatively small and unsophisticated defence industry, it will be very difficult, if not impossible, for Australia to capture major new markets or significantly to expand its defence exports, at least not without disproportionate government investment and still further relaxation of the export control regime that we are considering right now.

Besides this relaxation of export controls there has been a change in export policy guidelines. While the revised guidelines have not yet been publicly released, they are believed to be far more lenient than those that have operated in the past. Moreover, there has been a reversal of the onus of proof in relation to the approval of export contracts. The Government will now have to indicate why a particular export agreement should not proceed, rather than the exporter demonstrating why the goods should be sold. Export proposals will no longer be considered on a case by case basis, and most will now be approved by officials of the Department of Defence. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce will be consulted only in sensitive cases or when Defence proposes to deny an export application.

It appears that Australia will continue not to export defence goods to certain states against which there are arms embargoes imposed by the UN Security Council, or by any other international instrument to which Australia is a party. Also, we will not be exporting to those countries which threaten the strategic interests of Australia or its friends or allies. The Australian Government expressly reserves the right to prohibit the export of military goods to governments that seriously violate the human rights or constitutional rights of their citizens and also, in particular cases, where specified Australian foreign policy interests could outweigh the export benefits. Quite how these guidelines are to be interpreted remains unclear, particularly given the increasingly automatic nature of the export approval process.

There is also a conflict of interest associated with the encouragement and approval of exports. The Minister for Defence is the principal approval authority for the export of defence materiel. He is also responsible for the preparation of policies for the export of defence materiel. Given the present desire to increase exports, this dual function is likely to lead to the erosion or evasion of existing export controls. This conflict of interest is also a product of the generally closed nature of the approval processes within the Department of Defence. There is no oversight of defence exports by Parliament, nor are other government departments or agencies, other than the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, involved to any large extent.

Under the old guidelines there were 32 categories of weapons and equipment subject to export restrictions. These controls covered everything from ammunition to fire alarm systems. Under the new policy those broad controls have been reduced. The new controls will apply only to items specifically designed or adapted to military purposes and to products which are inherently lethal or destructive. In other words, far more products and services can be exported without adequate scrutiny. Obviously, I have not seen the new guidelines on export controls and therefore my reference is only to the press release put out by the Minister for Defence last June. Before then export controls on arms were tight by international standards, which themselves were depressingly slack. The revised controls of June 1988 have even more weaknesses than the old ones and I would like to outline what I see as the seven principal weaknesses.

There is no Australian arms embargo upon repressive governments. Instead, under the new policy exports will be favoured `where there is no reasonable risk of using the equipment against the citizens of a country with a dubious civil rights record'. This is splitting hairs. If a government has a track record of repression, like the Philippine Government, then the supply of Australian small arms target training ranges is support for repression, even though a target range cannot be used to kill. Secondly, subject to constraints, like the human rights ones I have just referred to, there will be a presumption that if our friends and allies export certain military equipment to country X Australia may export comparable equipment there too. This is more than disturbing given the deplorable record of the United States in supplying arms to repressive governments.

Thirdly, equipment which is neither lethal nor of major military significance will be exempted from controls. This implies that there will be no control whatever upon intangible exports like maintenance and overhaul services, or upon combat support equipment like small arms training aids and transport aircraft. Fourthly, the onus of proof has been shifted on to those opposing an export proposal. In such cases a specific case against an export approval will have to be made within 21 days.

Fifthly, the participation of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, which was the human rights watchdog within the old consultative status, is greatly reduced. Routine administration will be performed by the Department of Defence, whose prime concern is not human rights but keeping arms out of the hands of Australia's enemies, perceived or real. Sixthly, there are no controls upon the retransfer of Australian-made components incorporated into foreign built equipment. Finally, there are no controls upon the supply of First World countries with a record of repressive intervention in the Third World. Both the United States and France import arms from Australia. Both have a record of repressive intervention. Currently, the United States, the United Kingdom, New Zealand and Canada are exempt from export controls. Of course, these nations are free to re-export whatever they buy from Australia.

There is great doubt whether we can realistically compete with our defence exports, given the competition from countries such as China and exporters with lower costs. Obviously, we cannot compete in the high technology market. The danger is that we shall reduce our own restrictions in order to realistically compete in a buyers' market. Which countries are we hoping to sell to? Perhaps we could sell a little more to the United States as a concession from the Government there, given how much we buy from them-like 75 FA18s. We cannot offer much to Europe. We are already bullying New Zealand over the frigates. Most of the countries we might like to sell to in South East Asia come in the category of national security regimes where defence equipment is, more often than not, used on the people of those countries rather than any external enemy, or to boost the egos of the top military brass. Human rights groups in countries like Thailand and the Philippines have already asked Australia to stop encouraging their governments to spend more on military equipment or not to participate in defence exhibitions-for example, the ones in Bangkok and Singapore.

It is also not clear that an increase in arms exports will significantly benefit Australia's economy. Any increase in earnings from defence exports will need to be measured against some of the costs and potentially adverse economic effects of seeking to become a major arms exporter. These include the diversion of capital and key skills and resources away from other areas of the manufacturing sector; the need to import new technologies from overseas in order to establish new armaments and related industries; and the need to support these industries between contracts or in times of low demand.

No doubt we shall be hearing about the virtue of the patrol boats being handed over to the South Pacific nations under the defence cooperation program. I am not opposed to this program, but as far as I can gather we are not selling those patrol boats. They only benefit Australia because, in building them here, we create jobs in the yards concerned. I would rather we gave them as part of a civilian aid program. I fail to see why they should be considered as defence exports. I suspect that part of the motivation in providing these patrol boats is to develop our regional forward defence strategy in the South West Pacific, even if the patrol boats have to spend most of their time chasing trawlers engaged in poaching in the region, particularly those belonging to the United States.

Other contradictions are also evident. On the conservative side of this chamber there are those who believe that arms transfers are a part of building up a country's ability to defend itself against aggression. They seem to have a fixation with the past. They refuse to acknowledge that the nature of war and the weapons of war have changed. They are the kind of people to whom Albert Einstein referred when he observed that the atom has changed everything except the way we think and, thus, we drift towards unparalleled catastrophe. Yet at the same time they argue in favour of everyone's right to export arms, particularly to resolve problems with balance of payments. So we have a situation when they gravely warn us of the dangers of the naval build-up in the Indian Ocean by India and go as far as to suggest that perhaps Australia should acquire nuclear submarines and an aircraft carrier to replace HMAS Melbourne. Next, we hear that an Australian-Dutch consortium has won the contract to set up a huge new naval base in India and the Australia hopes to sell off 50 old Mirage fighters to Pakistan, thus further exacerbating the arms race in the region. I thought that there might perhaps be some protest about this; but no there is silence. It is very hypocritical.

The balance of payments is a mess, in great part because of the vast amounts we are importing in the way of military equipment. I have already referred to the 75 FA18s, which will probably cost us over $5 billion by the time that they are all delivered. I refer to the new submarines that we are buying through Sweden, although they are largely being put together in Australia. The same goes for the ANZAC frigates, and the new computers for the Department of Defence for the Geraldton spy base. We are buying all these from countries which are also exporting to offset their balance of payments. There are then the countries I have listed before with which Australia will have to compete-China, North Korea, South Korea, Singapore, Taiwan, India, Brazil, Argentina, Israel and South Africa.

In opposing this particular clause, I want to stress once again the wide amount of community concern about the decision to try to double our military exports in the next few years. On an earlier occasion, Senator MacGibbon referred to a few extremist groups opposing the decision. He actually mentioned the Australian Council for Overseas Aid (ACFOA) in this context. It is worth recalling that ACFOA represents 80 non-government organisations working in the field of overseas aid and development. The Australian Council of Churches, which passed a resolution on the subject and sent a letter to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) about its concern, is hardly an extremist group or a subset of the peace movement.

I do not know whether Senator MacGibbon has read the Autumn 1989 Community Aid Abroad Review, but it contains a four-page section on military exports and asks readers to write to their local members of parliament on the subject. I do not consider Community Aid Abroad an extremist group either; nor is it a subset of the peace movement. I know that there are a number of members of Parliament who will be taking part in the Community Aid Abroad walk against want on 16 April, even if they do not necessarily agree with my views or Community Aid Abroad's critique of military exports. It is not valid to write off critics of the Government's decision as a few loonies, which the supporters of this Bill will doubtless seek to do. I would rather that they addressed the substance of the argument instead of heaping personal abuse on the critics.

I do have an alternative, because I am concerned about jobs and the balance of payments. Rather than increasing defence exports, we should be opposing arms transfers worldwide. We should expand the debate about Australia's defence policy which has driven us to purchase such expensive military equipment from overseas, severely damaging our balance of payments. We should spend more money on promoting common security in our region. We should develop policies which address the issues of jobs and economic conversion for those already engaged in the defence industries sector.

If this legislation goes ahead, as seems inevitable, unfortunately, because of the unholy alliance on the matter between an Australian Labor Party which has forgotten its principles and an Opposition which does not have any on this issue, then I would at least urge the Government to give serious consideration to the following measures to prevent further supply of arms for repression: Firstly, extending the scope of our arms export controls to cover equipment, components and intangibles such as services and skills specifically intended for end use by foreign military, paramilitary or police clients, and to include the United States, the United Kingdom, Canada and New Zealand in the control procedure; secondly, to impose an arms embargo applying to all items I have just listed upon countries whose governments are repressive or engaged in, or likely to engage in, repressive intervention in other countries; thirdly, to control the retransfer of Australian made components incorporated into military equipment made by foreign manufacturers; fourthly, to control and reduce Australian collaboration in international military production.

I urge that there should be routine parliamentary and public scrutiny of arms exports. At present, this would hardly be possible in view of the difficulty of obtaining information on military exports. It is, therefore, important that the Government publish an annual register of Australian military exports. This should include a contract by contract list detailing the Australian supplier, the nature and quantity of the export, and the foreign recipient. It should also include details of Australian collaboration in international military production. In addition, I would recommend that any substantial military export proposals should require parliamentary assent. These proposals are not so far-fetched as both of them are in line with current United States practice. If they can do it, I do not see why we cannot. I would also suggest that there should be an attempt by the Government and the community to trace the fate of Australian arms exports.

I am indebted to St John Kettle from the Victorian Association of Peace Studies for some of this material. I want to remind the Senate that often people who are looking only at the business and dollars aspect of exporting anything forget about the end use of the products that they are promoting. Let us consider the point of impact-the suffering of the ultimate receivers of so-called defence exports. They would be more realistically labelled as components of offensive weapons systems, as instruments of repression.
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, I would like to underline, yet again, in concert with many of my colleagues in the Opposition, the parlous state that Australia is in with regard to science and technology. The future development of this nation for our children and our children's children depends upon the intellectual and technological investment we make in science, research and technology. Under the present Government we have seen the wastage of our developed resources in this important area. It is of great concern to many constituents in all States and Territories of the nation. Science and technology is the most important investment that we can make to create the new technologies that will be the basis of production and employment in the years ahead.

SPEECH.PARA: It is with that and the particular failures of the present Government in mind that I draw attention to my colleague Warwick Smith's paper entitled Whither Science? He was the Opposition's spokesman on science. We listened carefully to the statements that he made in this area. I seek leave of the Senate to table this paper.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this paper he calls for four things. First, that the Chairman of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) be replaced. We do not need a publicist; we need a scientist and an administrator to give leadership in this vital statutory authority. CSIRO's most successful years were under its first chief, Sir David Rivett, an eminent scientist. Secondly, we should allocate substantial funds to CSIRO, the flagship of Australian science. To return the CSIRO to the position it was in in 1982-83 we need to provide about $50m extra this financial year. Thirdly, we need to re-establish the science department or equivalent to provide a focus for politicians, scientists and the public. Science ought to be represented at Cabinet level. Fourthly, we ought to put in place a national science strategy for Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I commend those four matters that my colleague emphasised and will, on other occasions, along with many of my colleagues, keep on pointing out to this Government that this is an area which is one of the blackest marks against the Hawke Labor Government and one which is still in need of urgent repair in the final few months that this Government has left in office.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.34 p.m.
